column1: They can only do one thing, and that is what I, and many more, have had done, and it is not a pleasant experience.
column2: These brakesmen arm themselves with stones, and one of them no sooner sees a tramp under the car than he shouts to his fellow.
column3: After doing this the two brakesmen run with the train, throwing stones with all their might, and the tramp can hear their savage yells and the stones strike against the car.
column4: As it is, he is in a shaky position, without being helped to fall by receiving a blow on the head with a stone.
column5: Fortunately for him, they must soon stop throwing, for the train is going faster and faster, and if they do not board it soon they will be left behind.
column6: But they are so used to jumping on moving trains, that they can afford time to throw a number of stones.
column7: Another thing in the tramp's favour is that they only have a few stones in the first place, and then have to pick them up.
column8: But what favours the tramp most is that these men cannot aim straight, because the train is on the move, and they have to follow the car.
column9: This was one of my worst experiences, being stoned while riding the rods.
column10: Of course these brakesmen could rush forward and either pull a tramp out or push him off, but they could not do so without getting him caught in the wheels.
column11: This would be such plain murder that, in spite of their rage, it frightens them; so they stone him instead, and give him a chance for his life.
column12: Half the tramps in America will not ride a train if they cannot get the comfort of an empty car--not even on a road where the brakesmen are good and indifferent as to the number of tramps they carry.
column13: Still, there are so many that have had my experience that I would not mention it in the hearing of an old American tramp.
column14: But it must not be supposed that the dangers of beating one's way on freight trains in America are always caused by unsympathetic brakesmen.
column15: I know one good road which carried hundreds of tramps every week, and it was never known that a brakesman had ever put one off.
column16: In fact the brakesmen on this road used to look with indifference on tramps, as though they were part of the common freight.
column17: Some of these brakesmen were so used to tramps that they would confess a fear to run a train that had none, much the same as sailors look for rats on board a ship.
column18: But this road was spoilt by a gang of half robbers and half beggars.
column19: These men would board a train when it was standing still, and as soon as it was on the move, would go from car to car and search every man that they saw beating his way.
column20: This they would do with men riding outside, in coal cars or on flat cars.
column21: When the train stopped, they would get off and inspect the train.
column22: If they saw an empty car that contained one or two men, this gang--four, five, or six in number--would get in.
column23: A tramp would not know but what they were the same as himself, and would not feel any alarm, but welcome their company.
column24: But as soon as the train was again on the move, these new arrivals would then begin to question and search the first occupants of the car, and woe betide the man that refused to be searched or was not civil.
column25: Out through the open door he would be thrown, and the train would be going thirty or forty miles an hour, and it would be night.
column26: As I have said, these men were all beggars, for they would not make enough out of these petty robberies to keep them.
column27: For this reason a man had only to say, when questioned as to what he was, "I am a beggar," and they would then treat him with every respect.
column28: The men they wanted to find were those that were working men and had money in their pockets, but preferred to ride free on an easy road.
column29: The desperate methods of these men were so well known that tramps would often swarm together in one car, knowing that their number would make them safe.
column30: For all that, several dead men were found every week on this road, and the cause was well known to tramps.
column31: Some of the mutilated men that just escaped with their lives would have mentioned these things to the police, but the latter did not trouble, for it was all tramp work, from beginning to end.
column32: One of the worst experiences I have ever heard of was of a young cattleman whom I knew in Baltimore.
column33: When I met him he was only a lad of twenty years, and he had such a calm, pleasant face that no one would think that he ever had an hour's suffering in his life.
column34: Two years before this he had been a stowaway from England to America, and he was not discovered for several days.
column35: So, being too late to put him on shore, the captain set him to work, with the intention of handing him over to the police on arrival in America.
column36: But when they were in sight of land and saw the distant lights, it being night, this lad possessed himself of a life-belt and, without being seen, dropped overboard.
column37: He was under the impression that the tide and his own exertions would take him to land before morning and, no one being about, he would be safe.
column38: But instead of this, he got caught in a strong outgoing current, and was taken out to sea.
column39: He then had the experience of floating two days and two nights in the deep sea, before he was seen and picked up by a passing ship.
column40: Whatever his thoughts could have been, it was most certain that his mind was not affected, for when I knew him he was the most cheerful and sweetest tempered in the cattleman's office, and he was never heard to mention his experience.
column41: At this office was another cattleman, who had not only been in the hands of lynchers, but even had the rope round his neck and the other end of it thrown over the limb of a tree.
column42: A tramp had assaulted a woman, and a number of men were searching for him.
column43: Seeing a man at a camp-fire in the woods they at once pounced on him and, without any question, placed the rope round his neck and prepared to hang him.
column44: But, fortunately for him, another body of men came, led by the woman's husband, and with him was a little boy who had witnessed the assault.
column45: "That's not the man," said the little fellow--which saved the man's life.
column46: This cattleman was one of the ugliest men that I have ever seen, but he was really so harmless, simple, and innocent, that we all liked him and fed him, and got him to sing.
column47: We knew that women would be afraid of him, and for this reason he was apt to starve.
column48: So we better looking and less deserving tramps saved the poor fellow the humiliation of having doors slammed in his face, and hearing keys turned and bolts drawn.
column49: IX The American Lakes English sailors who run away from their ships in America, often do so with the intention of going inland and sailing on the fresh-water lakes.
column50: Other sailors, who have done so before, but felt that they had to return to the salt sea, talk of their former experience, so that almost every English sailor knows what sailing on the American lakes is like.
column51: On their deep-sea boats they get hard biscuits, salt meat, dried peas, and cheap molasses; but on the lakes they get soft bread, fresh meat, green vegetables, and luxurious fruit.
column52: It is no lie that common sailors and firemen on the American lakes get strawberries and cream, when such berries are in season, and other fruits when they are not.
column53: Therefore it is not to be wondered at when English sailors soon feel themselves in a strange position: they feel loth to break away from the splendid board and lodging on fresh water, and yet cannot help feeling restless to return to the salt sea and take long voyages.
column54: There are hundreds of English sailors on the American lakes that have either been in our navy or merchant service, and they live so well, in comparison with their deep-sea experience, that it is a great pity that fresh water cannot employ them all the year, as the sea could.
column55: Of course, they earn enough to keep them idle during the winter, but we all know that saving sailors are almost as scarce as white crows.
column56: The real fresh-water sailor, who has never been on the sea, and probably never saw it, is different to the deep-sea man in many ways.
column57: For instance, he walks straight and does not roll, which is owing to the different action of inland waters.
column58: His voice is gentle and soft, not rough and hoarse like a deep-sea sailor's.
column59: But, for all that, when it comes to money matters he is quite as extravagant as the man of long voyages, and is quite as easily fleeced by land-sharks, in spite of his greater knowledge of life on shore.
column60: And every lake town is as well supplied with land-sharks as a seaport of its size.
column61: But, fortunately for these lake sailors, they are nearly all beggars, owing to having no work in the winter when the lakes are frozen and navigation has stopped.
column62: This being the case, most of them think very little of begging a house, and if they are robbed or spend their money foolishly and have to wait for a ship, they are not likely to suffer hunger.
column63: One great advantage on the lakes is that when a man ships he has no particular need of top boots, oilskins, and many other things needed by the man of the deep sea.
column64: Indeed, the latter has to even supply himself with a knife, fork, and spoon.
column65: There is no law that a man must have a bag of clothes, for there is no need of them.
column66: He is allowed to ship as he stands, no matter whether he is clad like a sailor or a farmer, or is in rags like an unsuccessful beggar.
column67: As far as appearances are concerned, a great number of these fresh-water sailors end the season as they began it.
column68: Some of them look far worse, for they may have had good clothes and boots when navigation began, and have worn them all the summer and have not bought others.
column69: Therefore, when they are paid for their last trip, and spend the money foolishly, they are ill-shod and shabbily dressed.
column70: The fresh-water sailors are not nearly so illiterate as salt-water men, because they are so often on shore in large towns and cities.
column71: A popular song would not be more than three or four days old before they were on shore to hear it.
column72: They do not return, after one voyage, to be surprised that the town has built a large new dock since they left, or doubled its population, as deep-sea men may do.
column73: I was never, in all my life, seized with so great a desire for work as when I was in one of these lake towns and haunting the waterside.
column74: When I thought of the good pay, the rich food, and the easy work to be done, it was as much as I could do to keep from applying for a ship.
column75: In fact I made a special journey to Toronto for that very purpose, but was petted and spoilt by the many good people in that town.
column76: The first day I arrived I happened to find a green, open space where I could lie down and take my ease between meals.
column77: It did not take me long to find out that the houses around that green common were very good, for I had no difficulty at all in begging my first meal, which was breakfast.
column78: After doing this, I returned to the green common and lay down in the grass.
column79: But it was not long before the children came; so, wanting an active hour, I began to play ball with them.
column80: This exercise gave me a good appetite for dinner, and, when that hour came, I succeeded with as much ease as at breakfast-time.
column81: It was not long before I was back on the common, where I played ball with the children all the afternoon.
column82: Naturally, I now lost all inclination for work on the lakes, and even laughed at myself for ever having had such a thought.
column83: But, unfortunately, this life was too good to last long, for something happened the following day that not only put an end to my ball-playing, but forced me to leave the green common.
column84: I had gone to a house to seek dinner, and the door was answered by a man who, to my surprise, frowned at me.
column85: This unkind reception was so unusual on the great American continent that I made up my mind to demand, after he had refused me some dinner, an explanation as to why he received me in that way.
column86: But there was no need for me to speak, for the explanation came at once.
column87: "Look here," said he, "do you mean to tell me that you are looking for work?"
column90: he shouted; "didn't I see you playing ball with the children all day yesterday, only a few yards from here?
column91: Didn't I see you this morning holding the skipping-rope for some girls?"
column92: There was no escape from these questions, so I began to retreat.
column93: Perhaps that was the reason--that I had not made the least attempt to excuse myself--why he called me back and invited me indoors.
column94: And I must say that his good lady, who was smiling and laughing all the time, served me with an excellent dinner.
column95: In spite of this, I thought it wise not to be seen again in that happy green place, for fear that he might draw the attention of the police to me.
column96: So, being deprived of the pleasure of playing ball, I left Toronto, too down-hearted to seek enjoyment in any other part of that city, which was well known to be good all over.
column97: I could nearly always be sure of a dollar or two at these lake towns--Chicago, Cleveland, Buffalo, Toronto, and others--owing to my acquaintance with so many men.
column98: For almost all the cattlemen that sailed from Baltimore in the winter, worked on the lakes in the summer.
column99: They left Baltimore a week or two before navigation began on the lakes, and as soon as it stopped they returned to work as cattlemen between America and Europe.
column100: As there were scores of these cattlemen, and I not only knew them all, but was liked, it was to my advantage to make lake towns my haunts.
column101: Not one of them ever insulted me with a hint that I should do as he did--work for my money.
column102: The reason of this is that they all considered it their duty to assist me, for I had often assisted them in other ways.
column103: For instance, when they came back one by one and in twos and threes from the lakes, they were always loth to start begging again in Baltimore, which they must either do or starve.
column104: To make things worse, they would probably have to wait a week or two before they could get a chance to sail with cattle, for at this time the office would be full of men.
column105: Now, as I was always back before them, they could rely on me for a little assistance, for I would beg extra on their account.
column106: But for all that, the money I got from them was more of a curse than a blessing, for the reason that it often kept me several days in idleness; and, after living in lazy respectability for three or four days, I always found it hard to start again to earn my living as a beggar.
column107: It seems a mystery that these inland lakes should be sometimes visited by such terrific storms.
column108: One winter, when I was in Chicago, I went down to the waterside to see a ship in its last extremity.
column109: When I got there I saw thousands of helpless people, watching a vessel sinking before their eyes, no one being able to go to its assistance in small boats.
column110: We could expect to see this happen on the wild sea-coast, but this was an inland lake, and here was a city of more than a million inhabitants.
column111: It is more to be wondered at by men who have seen that beautiful lake almost without a ripple in summer-time.
column112: X The Happy Life It is certainly a mystery how man got into this tangle, having to conform to the rules of civilization--up in the morning at a certain hour, and to bed at a certain time at night, with certain limited intervals for meals; in fact a very slave to these conditions, and so often without power of being otherwise.
column113: If he breaks his fetters by indulging in more sleep, or prolonging his meals, he will starve, for nuts are not now free for the picking, and fruits are not now the free gift of Nature; for she herself is made the servant of landlords who are tyrannical over their rights.
column114: It is only the small boys who occasionally defy such laws by robbing an orchard and putting to shame their big, cowardly fathers.
column115: When I consider what pleasure it gives me to lie abed in the mornings at my own sweet will, I cannot help but feel pity for the great majority who must needs rise to answer the demands of civilization.
column116: Of course, I could not myself be so independent if I were not contented with very little, and did not prefer freedom to fine clothes and furniture and the luxuries of food.
column117: We know very well that the one happy hour in the week for a man of business is when he wakes on a Sabbath morn, or a holiday, at his usual time to rise, and finds, O joy!
column118: that he is privileged to lie in bed, a free and a happy man.
column119: What a strange contrast there is between the man who lives in a small house with just enough means, and no more, to keep him in idle content, and the man who, to keep up a position, has a large house with several servants, and worries himself night and day in business to keep things standing!
column120: What a wise man is the former, and what a poor fool is the latter!
column123: It is to be pestered by invitations to other people's houses, and to be worried again in returning those invitations.
column124: How foolish is that business man, that he does not sell out and retire to a small country cottage, with his little income of a pound or twenty-five shillings a week, where he could eat, sleep, and read in peace, and walk abroad admiring Nature.
column125: Thousands of business men could do this, and would, if they were wise enough to see what an empty thing position is.
column126: There are not many men in this world who appreciate more than I do that precious gift called sleep.
column127: When I wake in the morning and look at my watch, it may be seven o'clock.
column128: Then I question myself--"Shall I get up?
column130: No, gentle Sleep, one more hour with thee."
column131: Then I sleep again and wake the second time, and ask this question again--"Shall I get up?"
column132: What with yawning and stretching it usually takes a quarter of an hour to answer, which makes the time quarter past eight.
column133: Then I say to myself, "I will count fifty before I get up."
column134: This I begin to do, very slowly; but when I have done I usually make the fifty a hundred.
column135: This dallying with time is very pleasant.
column136: Sometimes I return to bed after I have got up, and have even undressed for that purpose.
column137: To make a candid confession, I have--not often--got up, dressed, and then returned to bed with my clothes on, so as to enjoy another nap and be at no pains to dress again.
column138: I remember making one trip on a cattle-boat, and on the return voyage to Baltimore there was no work to be done, we cattlemen being then counted as passengers.
column139: The nearest approach to work of any kind was that two men were commissioned each day to fetch food from the galley and to sweep the forecastle--the latter duty not to be strictly enforced.
column140: Now, it happened that there were fifteen cattlemen, so that one man would be exempt from even such petty duties as these.
column141: We therefore cast lots, and the laziest man was fortunate to win.
column142: It was Baldy, who, on hearing the decision, crept back into his bunk and remained there for the rest of the voyage.
column143: When the meals came, he sat up and requested some kind hand to pass him his food, and, after returning the empty dishes to the same kind hand, settled down for another sleep.
column144: One night the ship, being light, rolled so much that we were all thrown out of our bunks, all except Baldy.
column145: That same night we rushed on deck, cattlemen, sailors, and firemen, for the coal-bunkers had been broken in by the waves, and coal filled the galley, and the cattle-pens were smashed and taken to sea, and crash followed crash until we thought our end had come--and yet Baldy, whatever his feelings were, never left his bunk.
column146: When we arrived at Baltimore we were all, as usual, without money.
column147: On Baldy being roused and told we were about to go ashore, he began slowly to rise, but it was only after making several attempts that he succeeded in standing on his feet.
column148: My heart went out in pity for the poor fellow, for it was as much as three of us could do to get him up the forecastle steps.
column149: It was with great difficulty that he passed the doctor, for that gentleman happened to see him totter, and he had an idea that Baldy and, in fact, all the crew should be quarantined; but on receiving an explanation that Baldy's legs were weak through inactivity, he allowed us to go ashore.
column150: The distance to the cattlemen's office was over a mile, and poor Baldy could not possibly walk that distance, and, as I have said, we were all without money.
column151: But as luck would have it, a gentleman saw Baldy's condition and gave him five cents to pay car fare, so we helped the poor fellow into the car, which would take him right to the door of the office.
column152: Honestly, if I had not been cursed with ambition to excel in literature, I would have remained a beggar to the end of my days; to winter in such towns as Baltimore, and spend my summer months in travelling through the green country, with short stops here and there in cities and large towns.
column154: To study faces and the strange humours of different people.
column155: Yes, when I was about to call at a house for my dinner, the Baltimore Kid suddenly clutched my shoulders, and said impressively: "Whatever you do, do not address that woman as Lady, but call her Madam, or Mrs." Just to humour the Kid, for I thought such advice was ridiculous, I addressed the lady as Madam, and explained my needs.
column156: She motioned me to a small, wooden outhouse, which I entered, and seeing a chair and a table, sat down.
column157: In about two minutes the lady reappeared, carrying a hot dinner, for which I stood, as became a gentleman, and thanked her, saying: "I thank you, Madam," but was almost on the point of saying "lady."
column158: After having had dinner, I went to the back door and knocked, to thank her for her kindness.
column159: "You are quite welcome," she said; "the only people I refuse are those who say 'lady,' for I have cause to believe that such people are professional beggars."
column160: You see, by this instance, how one little word can assist or spoil a man in his profession.
column161: The Baltimore Kid was one of the keenest beggars in America.
column162: The sight or sound of money put the very devil in him.
column163: If he heard coins rattling in the pockets of a passer-by, he would follow that person side by side, up one street and down another until he had succeeded in talking the man out of a coin.
column164: If he saw a lady open her purse, he was at once at her side, and explaining his position.
column165: He boasted that he had begged the President, when the latter was visiting his paternal home.
column166: The Kid had intended to beg the house for clothes, but, seeing the President alone in the garden, quickly altered his mind.
column167: He claimed to have then talked the gentleman out of a five-dollar bill.
column168: Whether this story was true or not, I cannot say, but I am certain of one thing--that it was only the want of opportunity that would keep it from being attempted.
column169: The pomp and splendour of Solomon's throne would not have daunted the Baltimore Kid, if he saw the way clear of stern guards and meddlesome attendants.
column170: Many of the great capitalists of America, and many Europeans of title, had succumbed to the Kid's voice.
column171: Yes, he has often related to me how easy he found the Grand Duke of Gorgonzola, and how long it took to convince Tomkins the millionaire butcher.
column172: XI Boy Desperadoes The danger of our slums is not caused so much by men as by boys; and some of the latter are so young that they have not yet taken to drink, although they have smoked cigarettes for years.
column173: These half boys and half men are far more dangerous than full-grown bullies.
column174: The reason is that they do not think of the consequences, and they work themselves into an hysterical passion that often results in brutal murder.
column175: One time I was in a small town in America when a young outlaw of eighteen years was being tried for killing about half a dozen men, and half killing a number of others, all in his short career.
column176: No doubt this sounds like very high brutal courage, but the truth of the matter is that it was the lowest cowardice.
column177: He was too young to have that cool courage of a man who bids another to stand and deliver and, after committing robbery, walks away without more ado.
column178: This boy, full of fear, no sooner saw the motion of another than he pulled the trigger, in fear of his own life.
column179: I don't suppose that there was ever a man outlaw in America that was so dangerous as this youth.
column180: Again, men are robbers for gain, and nothing else; but when a number of these half boys and half men are together, they want sport and romance as well.
column181: They would not be satisfied with robbing a man, but would like to show their power after.
column182: What makes these youths so dangerous is that they obey the first impulse, which, more often than not, is a cruel one; and the cruelty increases with their strength of number.
column183: One time I saw a dozen boys on the levee in St. Louis hold up and rob every man they came to.
column184: They not only did this, but, as usual with them, started to beat the man after, kicking and punching him, until he had to run for his life.
column185: This happened in broad daylight; but they took care, as hysterical as they were, not to interfere with more than two men at a time, in spite of their number.
column186: These boys were quite dangerous, with revolvers, razors, knives, and clubs; and they uttered the most fearful oaths, and yelled like savages.
column187: No doubt, if they had met a stubborn man, who refused to either escape or humour them, they would have killed him.
column188: Now, what could a man do against these blind, desperate young bullies?
column189: If he had a revolver, he could hold back a dozen men by threatening to shoot the first man that advanced, and each man would have had enough sense to see the folly of risking his life.
column190: But these youths would have rushed on in their blind passion, and whether you shot one or not, you could not escape being half killed or killed by the others.
column191: These half boys and half men have no idea of fair play; if a man goes down, they will take good care that he does not rise again to renew the battle, for they will kick him into unconsciousness.
column192: It is these young bullies, and not grown men, that make the slums of London and other large cities so dangerous.
column193: They feel the strength of the coming man, and they are eager to try it.
column194: So, when they see a man drunk, and scarcely capable of looking after himself, they begin to jibe him.
column195: The poor fool, courageous in drink, and seeing that they are no more than boys, stops to abuse them.
column196: It is then that one of them steps forward and sometimes, to disguise his intention, holds out the hand of friendship, and the poor drunkard receives a blow in the face instead.
column197: Of course, this exasperates him, and he attacks them all.
column198: If it is day, the young bullies escape laughing, but if it is night, and the place quiet, they will all try their strength on him, and probably leave him insensible in the gutter.
column199: If they cannot trip a man or knock him down, they kick or use the buckles of belts, and they give him great cause to remember the occasion.
column200: Nearly all these young bullies wear strong leather belts with heavy solid buckles, and they know well how to use them.
column201: Any common lodging-house that harbours a gang of five or six of these half boys and half men is a very dangerous place in which to live.
column202: If there is a full-grown bully there, he will be very cautious not to offend any of these, however he may try to intimidate other lodgers.
column203: I left one lodging-house, after staying there a week, because of three of these young ruffians, who seemed to do as they liked.
column204: At that house there was a big bully, a man six feet in height and heavy in build.
column205: This big fellow was continually grumbling and threatening the old lodgers, but never interfered with the younger ones, although they often laughed at him in mockery.
column206: But one day, when he was cooking at the fire, one of these young ruffians, accidentally it seemed, pushed him, and the big bully turned with his usual oath and uplifted hand.
column207: Now, no doubt, if the kitchen had been empty, he would have pretended to be satisfied with the young ruffian's sneering apology, but seeing so many witnesses, he thought it was his duty to show what he was, so he gave the youngster a slap in the face.
column208: The latter did not attempt to retaliate, for he had not the assistance of his friends.
column209: No doubt he told them of it that night, when they were all together.
column210: A few mornings after this the big bully was found dead in bed; his death being caused by a blow in the back of the head, received in a fall.
column211: It seemed that he had had enough strength to walk to the lodging-house and get into bed, and had died afterward.
column212: There were several beds in that room, but none of the other lodgers had heard anything unusual in the night, although they saw that the man staggered into the room.
column213: There can be no doubt but what he was drunk, but drunken men do not often fall down and deal themselves death-blows--they only collapse.
column214: My opinion is that these young ruffians had waylaid him away from the house, and seeing that he was drunk, helped him to his fall.
column215: These young bullies never forgive, and never forget.
column216: If one is threatened when he is without the support of others, he will not rest satisfied until he gets their help and takes vengeance.
column217: What makes full-grown men so much afraid of these half boys and half men is their entire recklessness.
column218: They will use knife, poker, fork, or anything that is near their hands.
column219: One day I saw one of these young bullies deliberately poke an old man's eye out.
column220: The man was well known to be very quiet and not at all ill-tempered; and when he asked that the table should not be shaken because of his tea--this boy sprang to his feet and, without a word, poked the old man's eye out.
column221: A cruel, unfeeling action of this kind would never enter the mind of a full-grown man, however great a bully he might be; only an impulsive, irresponsible youth of this kind would do such a deed.
column222: In some lodging-houses the manager will not let beds to more than two of these half boys and half men, for he knows from experience the trouble they make; and that old and quiet lodgers will fear them so much that they will go elsewhere.
column223: For these young bullies have no sympathy with age or affliction, and it would not be well for a blind man to expect them to use restraint and humour him in everything.
column224: They feel the strength of manhood coming on them, and they do not know what to do with it.
column225: All these lads are out of steady employment and doing a few odd jobs often too light for them, and their growing strength is not getting sufficient use.
column226: So, when they are standing at street corners, they are always eager for action, and the man that takes notice of their insults or missiles, will most likely soon be in a pitiful state.
column227: It is these sober young bullies that smoke cigarettes at street corners, and not full-grown bullies in public houses, that a stranger has to fear.
column228: The latter make enough noise, when they are going home at night, singing or fighting among themselves, but they seldom interfere with strangers.
column229: But the young bullies, that are neither boys nor men, allow their animal spirits full play, and are only too eager to interfere with anyone.
column230: XII American and English Beggars A man that has camped out much in the open air must always after be on the look-out for places suitable for camps.
column231: So whenever I cross over a country bridge, under which runs a narrow stream, I often stand and look along the stream's banks in quest of a shady tree to sit out of the sun, happy to know that I can seek shelter under the bridge in case of rain.
column232: Yes, there is plenty of dry wood for cooking purposes, and fresh water in a delightful state of activity, and the bridge to be my shelter in a storm--such is an ideal spot for a camp.
column233: If I find this place in England there will be seen a sign that trespassers will be prosecuted, and for that reason the spot remains, and will remain, in its virgin state, untrodden by the foot of man.
column234: But if I am in America I shall not see that sign, and therefore at once take possession, and I know well that I shall find embers of past fires, and a quiet search in the adjoining bush will bring to light the rude cooking utensils used by former occupants.
column235: Alas for the strict regulations that govern this overcrowded land of ours!
column236: If I have a houseboat I cannot move it without first apprising the river commissioners and having their consent to do so.
column237: If I use a bit of wild woodland, untilled, and without fruit, cattle, or any other money-making stock, I am ordered to put out my fire by a man who can produce papers to show his authority.
column238: Our liberties extend so far, and no farther, and we are not free to periodically enjoy the sweet open-air life of our ancestors.
column240: Even if I own a cottage, with a piece of land, and have my title deeds to show for it, the sporting gentry can over-run it after a fox.
column241: And, although compensation can be claimed for damage done to a field of turnips, I would be laughed at for a mad eccentric if I asked compensation for the rude trampling of my garden flowers.
column242: But things are different in America, and, for that matter, in all new countries.
column243: The woods belong to all comers and all that is found therein--sunny glades and shady trees, birds, springs, flowers, and squirrels.
column244: No stranger to demand by what authority I camp there; and any respectable stranger that chanced to come near would no more think of entering my camp without an invitation than he would of entering my town house.
column245: For in America it is customary for all classes of families to forsake their homes for a few days in the summer and camp out, sometimes only on the outskirts of the town and within easy distance of their homes.
column246: These outings cost little, are healthy, and the whole family are together; and it only requires care that the smallest and youngest does not roll into the rill and get drowned--a rill that in certain parts is often as much as three inches deep.
column247: But the man to whom this kind of life properly belongs is the American tramp.
column248: His camp is to be found on the outskirts of every town, either on the northern, southern, eastern, or western end; and it is not uncommon to find a camp at each end.
column249: The camp is his great institution, a club and private residence; from which he sallies on his begging expeditions, and to which he returns with his spoils; at which place he cooks, eats, reads, discourses, takes his afternoon nap, washes his clothes, or discards them for others lately acquired.
column250: There they build their fires near running water, around which they sit at night and relate their day's experience.
column251: The Baltimore Kid was that morning offered work, but had taken the insult good-naturedly, having retired without wasting time in excuses.
column252: His companions laugh heartily at this, to imagine the Kid at work, and Philadelphia Baldy enquires philosophically, "What is work, boys?"
column253: These men are all downrighters; that is, none of them make any pretence of selling cheap goods, but beg food and money straight.
column254: Begging in England is certainly a fine art, and it is very difficult to live except beggars carry in their hands pins, needles, laces, wire goods, artificial flowers, a tin whistle, accordion, etc., and hide themselves as beggars behind these things.
column255: Even then they make very little, if they are indifferent to the art of begging; for it is not sufficient to sell a farthing pair of laces for a penny, but to tell such a pitiful story that the buyer--out of pity for your misfortunes--returns the laces after paying for them, and occasionally adds a piece of cake to her kindness.
column256: That is the real art of begging; and the man who cannot make threepence or more out of a farthing stud, a farthing's worth of pins, or a farthing pair of laces, is no more than a very small and unsuccessful business man, and is not worthy the name of a beggar.
column257: The art of begging is not nearly so fine in America as it is in England, for there is no necessity in that country of making any pretence of selling; and money, food, and clothes are to be had for the mere asking.
column258: The American beggar uses few words, for he knows well that whoever can afford will give, and he is too cunning to employ pitiful tales, which would be apt to encumber him with a quantity of common bread and butter, from people who have nothing ready cooked.
column259: For this reason he pockets the few trifles in the way of sandwiches and cakes, and proceeds leisurely from house to house, until he is seated at the table like a Christian, and supplied with a hot meal, which is the end he seeks, and which seldom fails.
column260: After which he returns to the camp, unloads his pockets of their trifles, and reads, and talks with his companions until supper-time, which we in England call tea-time.
column261: Then he takes a tin can to the spring, places it full of water on the fire, and makes hot coffee, with which he devours his trifles.
column262: He has had a hot breakfast and a hot dinner, and he is quite satisfied to eat one meal a day that only consists of cold meat, bread and butter, and a cake or two.
column263: The American tramp sits comfortably at his camp fire, waiting the sound of a shrill whistle, or bell, which proclaims dinner-time.
column264: Five or ten minutes after hearing this sound, he dances out of camp, humming a tune, and goes begging as though he were going to a wedding, and he is often served with a hot dinner before the man of business can finish his own.
column265: But the poor English beggar makes funeral steps between meals, and asks for a mouthful of bread.
column266: The American beggar pulls the door bell, and makes himself heard the first time; but the English beggar timidly uses his knuckles on the back door, many times before he is heard.
column267: The American beggar rides on trains from town to town, but the English beggar tramps the hard roads.
column268: The English beggar explains his wants to the servants and children, but the American beggar asks to see the mistress.
column269: The American beggar, feeling himself a proud and free citizen, addresses himself familiarly to anyone; but the English beggar, feeling himself a despised outcast, will not speak except in want, or when he is first spoken to.
column270: Yes, begging in America is fascinating, without doubt; and it is no wonder that the tribe has increased to such an enormous extent.
column271: But in England it is such a fine art, and requires so much persistence to attain small ends, that there are few that can master it thoroughly.
column272: What did Chicago Fatty do when he visited Liverpool on a cattle-boat?
column273: He asked forty men for a copper towards paying for a fourpenny bed, and the result was twopence threefarthings--and the workhouse.
column274: Begging in England nearly broke his heart and so sickened him that, when he returned to his own country, New York Slim and Boston Shorty had to feed him, as though he were a babe in arms, until he recovered sufficiently to help himself.
column275: Blacky--the half-breed--who claimed to have enough Indian blood in his veins to make himself dangerous if he had cause--Blacky, I say, thought that Fatty would never again be a good beggar.
column276: It certainly seemed, for a long time, that this would be the case, until one morning Fatty went out and begged his breakfast, but nothing more.
column277: He went out again, begged a meal, a shirt, and a handkerchief.
column278: In a day or two this good beggar--almost ruined by a trip to England--began to take a man with him to carry the spoils, as he had been accustomed to do in his prosperous days.
column279: XIII Beggars' Slang Women, strange to say, take far more pride than men in using slang.
column280: To listen to two women relating their experiences in a country common lodging-house is almost to hear a foreign language.
column281: I cannot think that a woman takes more pleasure or near so much, in a wandering, homeless life, as a man.
column282: Nevertheless, it is plain that women affect to enjoy it more.
column283: In fact, I have often heard women boast of being on the road a certain number of years, but have seldom heard a man take the trouble to mention such a thing.
column284: In spite of this, one thing proves that a woman of this kind speaks false and is trying to make the best of a strange life.
column285: It is this--when she and her husband are settled in a lodging-house, he is always the first to propose taking to the road again, and the woman always inclines to postpone that event for another day.
column286: If they are old travellers, they are sure to see in every lodging-house others they have met before, and that is why the woman would like to settle for a few days; but the man, being less sociable, is more restless.
column287: What surprised me, when I first went on the road in England, was to see how sociable these people were, calling each other by some kind of name, as though they had lived there always, or had always travelled together.
column288: It was some time before I discovered the reason of this.
column289: Naturally, my first impression had been that a score or more men and women would meet, coming from different towns, and not know each other; and, after having a night's lodging, would continue their travels and perhaps never meet again.
column290: But, to my surprise, I often entered a lodging-house where there would be a dozen lodgers or more, and I would be the only stranger there.
column291: I soon got to know that these temporary lodgers had been beggars for years, and one of them could not possibly appear in a lodging-house without meeting others he had met before.
column292: The reason of this is that most beggars have their favourite counties, which they seldom leave, and if they do not meet in a lodging-house they meet on the road.
column293: There are hundreds of beggars that work in a circle around London, within ten, fifteen, twenty, or thirty miles; and, seeing that some of them have been doing this for years, it is not surprising that they recognize one another at the different lodging-houses.
column294: The second night that I was on the road in England, I went to a lodging-house in Luton and, of course, expected to find a dozen or more strangers to the town, like myself, who would sleep there one night, part the next morning, and never meet again.
column295: But when I entered the kitchen I found a number of lodgers, men and women, who were calling each other by name--Brum, Norfolk, Sal, and Liz.
column296: In fact, I was the only stranger present, and yet all these were wanderers, and never travelled together.
column297: Very few of these were downright beggars, but had some trifle to sell.
column298: Their pride was in being able to beg under the disguise of selling.
column299: I never knew that beggars had so many slang words until I had been on the road for several weeks and was in Gloucestershire.
column300: I had heard a number of strange words, but had not heard any sustained conversation.
column301: But one day, when walking from Stroud into Gloucester, I happened to meet a real beggar.
column302: It was close on evening and, as I had done well enough to be able to pay for my bed, I was making all speed to a lodging-house.
column303: Soon I heard quick steps behind me, and was overtaken by another beggar, who walked at my side and entered into conversation.
column304: Hearing where I was going to he asked me if I knew Gloucester and, if so, what lodging-house I intended to go to.
column305: Telling him that I did not know that town, and would have to enquire about a lodging-house, he at once offered to conduct me to one, saying that there were several and that he knew the best.
column306: I was very glad of this offer, and we trudged along in pleasant conversation.
column307: Now, this man's conversation was as pure from slang as mine, which surprised me, for he was an old beggar, though perhaps not over thirty-five years of age.
column308: I may as well say here what kind of begging the man was doing at this time of his life, which became known to me after, for I had his company for several days.
column309: He had taken advantage of the South African War, saying that he had been invalided home.
column310: As you may guess, he was a fraud, and had never been in the Army.
column311: This man carried forged letters, supposed to be recommendations from officers under whom he had served.
column312: With these he called at the houses of old, retired military men and others, sending the papers in by a servant.
column313: All he had to do was to find out the names and addresses of these old officers, one or two of whom are to be found near every little hamlet or village.
column314: This was not difficult, for he knew the counties of Gloucestershire and Monmouthshire well; and every lodging-house has a town beggar who can give names, addresses, histories, and describe the position and appearance of houses wanted.
column315: Very well, then, this beggar would go to the house of one of these rich, retired military officers and, when the servant opened the door, would give her his papers to be taken to her master.
column316: In a few moments she would return with the papers and probably a shilling or a two-shilling piece on top of them.
column317: As can be expected, this man had several times been so closely questioned that he had compromised himself, and had been threatened with prison as a fraud.
column318: However, he was so bold, and knew his subject so well, that this had not often happened.
column319: At the houses of rich civilians he was safer, but, naturally, they would not give so much as a gentleman who had served in the Army.
column320: At this stage of his career this ambitious beggar did not often call at small houses for pennies, but large houses for silver.
column321: I soon found out his history, for he seemed nothing loth to talk of himself.
column322: He had taken to the road early, not having worked for a living since he was a youth.
column323: In those early days he had worked for a printer, and had caught his little finger in one of the machines.
column324: This accident did not handicap him in any way, and was no excuse for his leaving at once and becoming a beggar.
column325: In after years he never forgot to call two or three times a year on the printer, who had a fine business, and hold up his little finger; an action which won him a piece of silver every time.
column326: It was by his little finger that he proved his identity--that he was the boy that had worked for the printer in years gone.
column327: It was when I heard this man and another in conversation that I first became surprised at the number of slang words that beggars use.
column328: As I have said, he used no slang during our walk, but we had no sooner entered a lodging-house and he met a beggar he knew, than his language was completely changed.
column329: When we were entering the city of Gloucester, he had called at a big, red house, which he told me was always good for twopence and a parcel of food, no more or less.
column330: He explained to me that he would not go out of his way for it, but thought he may as well have it, seeing that he was passing the house.
column331: It was in relation to this house that he spoke to his companion, using the following words: "I called at the big, red kennel and got my eight farthings and scrand."
column332: To which the other said: "That kennel never yet failed a needy."
column333: This conversation quite interested me; kennel was house; eight farthings was twopence; scrand was food; and needy was beggar.
column334: Beggars in London lodging-houses use the slang of lodging-houses, and not of the road.
column335: They always say "fourpence for 'doss' or 'kip'"; but true, wandering beggars say "sixteen farthings for the feather."
column336: The former say "chuck" or "tommy," when they refer to food; but the latter say "scrand."
column337: The wandering beggar says "skimish" for drink, but city beggars say "bouse."
column338: The word "mouch" is not often heard outside towns, for wandering beggars say "call."
column339: For instance, "it is a good road to call," or "there is plenty of calling"; meaning that the road has many houses.
column341: When a beggar asks another if a certain town is good, the former is asked, "What is your lay?"
column342: or, "It depends on your lay"; meaning: "What do you do--sell, sing, or go in for downright begging?"
column343: What always surprised me was to hear old beggars use the dignified word "travellers," in preference to beggars, needies, or callers.
column344: When they are talking of a good town, they say "it is good for travellers."
column345: And if they see a selfish lodger monopolizing the fire, or not making room on the table for others, they say "he's not a true traveller."
column346: The following are a few slang words used by beggars:-- Beggars--travellers or needies; house--kennel; on the road--on the toe be; talk--patter; sing--griddle or chant; fourpence--sixteen farthings; bed--feather; soup--shackles; profit--bunts; food--scrand; drink--skimish; pins--pricks; needles--sharps; laces--stretchers; scissors--snips; combs--rakes; spectacles--glims; pictures--smuts.
column347: XIV Bony's Wits We called him "Bony," because he was all skin and bones.
column348: This condition must have been constitutional, for it certainly was not from too much activity, seeing that he went by tram on his expeditions, and returned in the same manner.
column349: Again, it could not have been for want of good food, for Bony was a good beggar, and scorned to sit down to a bread-and-butter meal.
column350: He was also a good ale drinker, and, if his bones had been capable of growing flesh, it is very likely that ale would have helped to bring about that result.
column351: He was always heard to be humming a tune--often an old familiar hymn--so that it could not have been mental worry that fastened his skin so tight to his bones.
column352: No, his condition must have been constitutional.
column353: I had known Bony for several months, and now that I had fallen on evil times, and would in less than a week be compelled to travel the country, I thought that perhaps my friend Bony could give me a few hints, that would assist me in procuring food and lodgings.
column354: Therefore, one evening, after he had had tea and was emptying his pockets of tram fare tickets, I invited him outside to have a drink.
column355: This invitation he would accept only on one condition--that I would then have another with him.
column356: Having no objection to this, we left the house together, and were soon comfortably seated in the warm corner of an alehouse.
column357: After we had had the second drink, I began by asking Bony what he considered to be the most essential gift for a good beggar.
column358: Without immediately answering this question, he called for two more drinks, and, after they had been served, and he had praised the colour of the ale, he began.
column359: "The one thing, above all others, is to have ready wit, so as to take advantage of opportunities that come and go in a second, and give no time for second thoughts.
column360: For instance," continued Bony, "when I was in the country some time ago, I called at a house for a glass of water.
column361: I did not think that there was the least prospect of getting tea, as the time was between meals; therefore, being dry, I asked for water.
column362: A little girl answered the door, and after hearing my wants, returned to tell her mother.
column363: 'Certainly,' said the mother; 'he could have had a cup of tea, if he had asked for it, but perhaps he prefers water.'
column364: These words were said so low that they could not have been heard, except by a man who had all his wits about him.
column365: So, when the little girl returned with the water, I told her, in a voice loud enough to be heard in the house, that I was really sick for a hot drink of tea, but that it was not the tea-hour, and I must be content with water.
column366: I lifted the glass of water slowly to my lips, so slowly that the lady had heard my remark, weighed it for a second, and then promised a cup of tea, before my lips had touched the water.
column367: And, of course, the kind lady asked me if I would like a piece of cake to eat with the tea.
column368: You see," continued Bony, "how a man needs to keep his wits at work.
column369: Nine beggars out of ten would not have heard or, having heard, would have accepted the water and cursed themselves inwardly that they had not asked for tea."
column370: I was so interested in this recital that I called for two more drinks.
column371: "Again," said Bony, after praising the colour of the liquor, "I happened one day to see a lady and gentleman approaching, and determined to accost them.
column372: As they drew near, I saw a crust of bread on the road, and that was my chance.
column373: Casting a hasty look behind me, as though I did not wish to be seen, I stooped, picked up the crust, and pretended to take a bite; and then I feigned seeing them for the first time, and hastily concealed the crust in my clothes.
column374: That little trick worked out well, for the lady gave me sixpence, and the gentleman gave me a shilling, and not a word passed between us."
column375: Bony now called for two more drinks, and, after remarking that the colour of the ale was getting no worse, continued his experiences.
column376: "One day," he began, "I was walking the high-road when a gentleman on a bicycle ran into me, knocking me down and throwing himself into the hedge.
column377: It did me no harm at all, for I was soon on my feet and going to his assistance.
column378: All my consideration was for him, thinking he might be seriously hurt.
column379: To my surprise he was not, but much shaken.
column380: After he had sufficiently recovered his breath he looked towards me and said: 'Are you hurt, my poor man?'
column381: Quick as a flash it occurred to me that I was, and I began to limp painfully.
column384: I mentioned a town four miles away, and said that I had no doubt but what I could walk there, but that on my reaching that place it would probably be a week or more before I would be able to work, even if I could get it, and that I had no means whatever to keep myself idle in lodgings for that length of time.
column385: 'Are you sure that you can walk there without assistance?'
column388: 'I am very sorry for you,' said he, 'and if this can be of help you are heartily welcome to it'--with that he placed in my hand a gold half-sovereign.
column389: Telling him I was ashamed to take advantage of what was no more than a pure accident, but that my straitened circumstances compelled me to do so, and saying how glad I was that he received no hurt, I left him, and began to limp painfully on my way.
column390: I had not got many yards, when he was again at my side, and, giving me his card, asked me to write in the course of a day or two, and let him know of my progress.
column391: And, you may depend on it," said Bony, with a grin, "that I did write on the third day, saying that I was doing well--for I feared a personal visit from him, with a doctor--and that in three or four more days I would be in a fit condition to work.
column392: He wrote a very kind letter in answer, with a postal order enclosed for ten shillings.
column393: Of course, I still keep the gentleman's address, and call on him occasionally, and I always receive a good meal and a shilling, and sometimes clothes as well."
column395: After the drinks were brought, and Bony had passed his usual comment on the colour, he went on to tell how necessary it was to keep a civil tongue on all occasions.
column396: "One day," said he, "a little man whom I could have crushed in my arms, called me all the big, idle vagabonds he could think of.
column397: But I allowed him free speech, knowing that he would be so pleased to see a man timid, who was almost twice his size, that he would at last become generous out of sheer delight, and such was the case.
column398: "On another occasion I called at a lady's house, and received sixpence for my trouble, which was the first bit of silver that I had seen for several days, and for which I thanked her from the bottom of my heart.
column399: She stood at the door, as I was leaving, and said: 'Poor, unfortunate man!'
column400: 'Madam,' I answered, returning, for I was almost at the gate--'Madam,' I said, 'I am thankful to say that I am not half so unfortunate as my poor brother, who has weak intellect.'
column401: 'Oh, I am deeply moved to hear that,' said the kind lady, 'and will give you another sixpence for your poor brother.'
column402: "These incidents," continued Bony, "prove how necessary it is to have quick wits.
column403: Only last week, within a mile of this alehouse, I got a two-shilling piece from a man in a very simple manner.
column404: I had been calling at the alehouses all the evening, and was returning home with three or four shillings worth of coppers in my pockets, not to mention the pleasant effect on my system of several free drinks of good strong ale.
column405: "When I was on the bridge, I had my attention drawn to the sound of voices in a small boat running under the bridge, which made me pause and, leaning on the balustrade, look down into the river.
column406: This was not done so much from curiosity, but that I was beginning to feel tired.
column407: At that hour of the night the bridge was almost deserted, and I was just on the point of moving on when a gentle hand fell on my shoulder, and a voice kind and earnest said: 'Don't, I entreat you, destroy your immortal soul; don't, my dear brother, plunge into the dark waters.'
column408: I must confess that, for one moment, my wits entirely deserted me, and if the speaker had not still held me in his grasp, and continued his persuasion, I should have been foolish enough to explain that such was not my intention.
column409: But I soon recovered from my astonishment, and allowed him to lead me over the bridge.
column410: When we stood safely on the other side, he asked me what could be done to save me from self-destruction.
column411: Of course I had by this time recovered my wits, and told him a harrowing tale of misfortune, which earned me that gentleman's pity to the extent of two shillings.
column412: After receiving my promise that I would live and face misfortune like a man, he left me, and I, well pleased at such good fortune, sought my lodgings."
column413: These incidents, as related by Bony, proved to me how necessary it was for a man to be quick-witted, if he would excel as a beggar.
column414: After several more drinks we left for home, for the colour of the ale did not seem so good as when we first entered the place.
column415: XV Favouritism One of the worst enemies to a poor man in a common lodging-house is favouritism.
column416: I have seen hundreds of instances where a man could be comparatively happy were it not for a prejudiced porter or kitchen-man.
column417: I was not long in one large house before I saw this, in the case of a porter, a bully, and a gentleman.
column418: The bully was drunk and going from place to place, insulting everyone, especially those that were better dressed than himself.
column419: Few of the lodgers took any notice of him, until he came to one that had on a silk hat and a frock-coat.
column420: This man lost his temper and told the bully that he had no right to interfere with men that wanted to be quiet.
column421: He was in the act of uttering this dignified rebuke when a porter came and stood before them.
column424: The well-dressed man began a quiet explanation, but the bully interrupted him; so the former stopped at once, thinking he would have a chance to speak when the other had done.
column425: "You had better go to bed," said the porter to the bully, "and"--addressing the well-dressed man--"you come with me to the office."
column426: When they arrived at the office the porter said a few words to the clerk, and the latter returned the well-dressed man his money, telling him to go elsewhere for a bed.
column427: There were very few lodgers in the house that did not know the meaning of this injustice.
column428: The well-dressed man was a gentleman, and, in spite of his low circumstances, did not forget it.
column429: He looked on the porters as his servants and, when he met them in the street, never invited them to have a drink.
column430: Again, there was no necessity for him to rise early, whereas the bully gave a porter sixpence a week to be called every morning.
column431: I was not many weeks at this house before I thoroughly understood these matters.
column432: One night, when I was going to bed, a man, who was quite tipsy, wanted to detain me in conversation, and I was doing my best to escape, when up the stairs ran one of the porters.
column435: "You haven't to get up in the morning, and others have."
column436: This porter had not heard my voice, and he could see that the other man was drunk, but of course he set upon me because the other paid to be called early.
column437: This porter became more civil after, which I could well understand.
column438: I used to tip the bath-porter twice a week, and seeing that they shared their tips--one being in a better position than another to get them--so, no doubt, the bath-porter had pointed me out for civility.
column439: There was no appeal against these porters.
column440: They allowed some men to do things which they got others turned out for, and it was no use trying to explain oneself to the manager.
column441: Although I believe that he was a very just man, he could not do otherwise than trust his men, say what they would.
column442: In fact, I believe that this manager was so just that he would have dismissed a porter at once if he could prove that that porter was prejudiced against any of the lodgers and having them turned out for his own spite.
column443: When I left this house and went to one that was in the hands of Christianity, I found the same state of things.
column444: The Christian officer behind the food-bar gave thick slices of bread to those he liked and thin slices to others; and he skimmed the top of the soup for those he did not like or was indifferent to, but his ladle went to the bottom for favourites.
column445: The consequence was that some lodgers would have hot, greasy water, while others would have thick soup that was almost Irish stew.
column446: It was well worth while to bribe this man with a drink of whisky.
column447: One artful lodger did better than that, as he told me in confidence.
column448: This man behind the bar was not supposed to take money for food; the lodgers had to buy tin checks at the office, with which they paid for what they wanted.
column449: But my artful dodger would go to the bar when no one was there to see, put a penny down and receive what he asked for.
column450: The officer behind the bar would quickly take this money, in spite of the strict rules and the severe discipline of that Christian army.
column451: But if a newly-arrived stranger put money down, that officer would shout, loud enough to be heard at the office--"We don't take money behind the bar; go to the office for checks."
column452: When I first went to that lodging-house I had a small bundle, in which were an extra shirt, a pair of stockings, a brush, razor, and a few other articles.
column453: Seeing that all the lockers were in use, I had no other option than to ask the kitchen-man to look after it, for which I gave him twopence, although he had no claim to anything.
column454: Whether the bar-man saw this deed or was told about it I cannot say, but I know that I soon became one of his favourites.
column455: I may as well say here that, judging by my later experience at this place, it was well that I did tip the kitchen-man, for he often took a notion to sell the things in his charge, only holding such property sacred as had been tipped for.
column456: And yet on a Sunday afternoon these two, the bar-man and the kitchen-man, would be seen one on each side of the captain, and heard crowing like two cocks that challenge each other.
column457: When the captain prayed one would shout "Hallelujah!"
column458: The other would no sooner hear this than he would stretch his neck, grow red in the face, and cry fiercely, "Praise the Lord!"
column459: These doings not only amused the lodgers, but the principals as well; for, judging by their faces, it was all they could do to keep from laughing outright.
column460: I was at one lodging-house where the beds were clean, the cooking accommodation good, and, according to the small rent to be paid, everything as could be desired.
column461: But this place was also spoilt by a common kitchen-man, who made things uncomfortable for all those that did not give him either money, ale, or tobacco.
column462: This man would build the fire up when a disfavoured lodger was in the middle of cooking a meal, and then sweep the dusty floor when he was at his meals.
column463: Of course, these things had to be done, so that there was no use in reporting him to the manager.
column464: Still, there was no reason why he should make more dust around _your_ food, and take longer under your table than others, and build up the fire before there was actual need of it.
column465: Yes, there was a reason--known to himself--you never gave him anything.
column466: This kitchen-man upset me so much that I agreed with another lodger to share a furnished bed sitting-room.
column468: I was soon back in the same lodging-house, in spite of its crazy kitchen-man.
column469: The man with whom I shared the room disappeared suddenly, and when I heard his character I did likewise.
column470: Without my knowledge, he borrowed of the landlady; and the vicar came to me saying that my friend had told him that I was on the point of starvation, and got a shilling on that account.
column471: Not knowing what else he had done in the neighbourhood, I could not feel at ease.
column472: Therefore, not having the courage to give my landlady notice, I put on all my clothes--two pairs of trousers, two shirts, a waistcoat, two jackets, and an overcoat--and crept to the front door.
column473: Seeing that I had filled the pockets with a number of small articles, it did not surprise me much to find great difficulty in moving.
column474: I do not know what I would have done if the landlady had been at the front door, because I could not have squeezed past her, and she could not have helped seeing that I was as broad as I was long.
column475: What upset me was that she had said she would not have let the room to him, but had trusted my face.
column476: However, I did not owe her any rent, and if I ever meet her when I am better off I will give her a sovereign.
column477: I have seen this favouritism even in prison.
column478: It came under my notice in an American jail, where I had to serve fifteen days, and I was as innocent as a new-born babe.
column479: All the prisoners were in one long room, with cells on each side, in which they slept at night.
column480: At the end of the room there was a square hole in the wall, which had a slide; and it was through this hole that the prisoners received their meals.
column481: When I went for my first meal, I could see the face of the old cook--who was a prisoner--and was rather surprised to see him nod and smile, as though he knew me.
column482: This smile was followed by a large plate of food, much more than others.
column483: Perhaps the old prisoner-cook thought he saw in me a fellow-prisoner in some other jail, and he may have been right, for I had been in many others; or perhaps I resembled a son of his.
column484: Whatever it was, it was quite clear that he did not give me the plate that came to my turn, but kept one apart.
column485: XVI A Law to Suppress Vagrancy We are all deeply interested in any scheme that proposes to suppress the workhouse tramp, who has not only become a pest to the ratepayers of our country--who support so many workhouses--but has also brought the true beggar to his wits' end to earn a livelihood.
column486: To all true beggars, who systematically pursue their calling, the workhouse tramp has become as much of an eyesore as he is to the working classes of our land.
column487: This vagrant--whom the Law seems so much to disfavour--is, without doubt, a madman; but, if rightly dealt with, is not, I believe, incapable of being cured.
column488: That he will not work to maintain himself in a good home, with food, bed, and clothing; and that he prefers to break so many hundredweight of stone--a heavy task to be performed on a bowl of thin gruel, or limited supply of bread and water--that he prefers to do the latter is sufficient proof of the man's mental deficiencies.
column489: To turn such a one into a useful member of society would be to confer as great a benefit on him as on the ratepayer of this country.
column490: Sometimes he cavils at the injustice of such tasks, and is sent to prison for refusing to perform them; or, the task being done, he tears in shreds his old rags, thinking to obtain a new outfit at the ratepayers' expense.
column491: For this he is also sentenced; for, though he has without doubt earned a cheap suit of clothes, he is by no means entitled to any--not even to a pair of stockings.
column492: Of course, our workhouses are not hotels, neither are they rough boarding camps, so that the ratepayers are, after supporting them, far from being relieved, seeing that this tramp is forced to make personal application for more food, or starve.
column493: But what I mention is that this man works hard and gets little for his trouble, and that he could be made a useful member of society and obtain more necessities--aye, even luxuries--by performing far less labour.
column494: For my own class, whom I as a proud member represent, the outlook is indeed serious.
column495: Only yesterday an incident occurred which will, I believe, explain how the workhouse tramp stands in the light of a true beggar.
column496: I had seen a gentleman approaching in the distance, and had in my own mind resolved that he should not pass without first hearing my story.
column497: Being a clean man, keeping myself well shaved and brushed, I had very little fear of disgusting him by my personal appearance, making him seek to escape my importunities.
column499: During my narrative he stood smiling for a minute or two, for, you may depend, I gave him no time for excuse or question.
column500: At last I finished, and stood waiting the result of my confessions, which had been unusually pathetic.
column501: "My good fellow," said he, "I have just given the last threepence to another unfortunate man, who apparently was in greater need of assistance; I am very sorry."
column502: There was no other course than to continue my journey, for it was impossible to talk money out of an empty pocket.
column503: In five minutes after I was hailed by a voice from the hedgerow, and, looking in that direction, saw the most ragged man I had ever set eyes on, with his matted hair a foot long.
column504: "Did you meet a gentleman on your way?"
column506: "I did," said I; "and what of that?"
column507: "That man," said this ragged tramp, "was a thoroughbred.
column508: He saw me sitting here and, without a word from either of us, he emptied his pocket into my hand"--saying which he withdrew his fingers from the palm of his hand and disclosed to my view three pennies.
column509: Now, here was a workhouse tramp--for he was no other, or he would at once have stepped into the road and accosted the gentleman--receiving unsolicited alms; and I, who earned my living by the use of my tongue, must suffer in consequence.
column510: But the worst charge to be made against this class of vagrant is that he does, by reason of his workhouse experience, look on common bread as a luxury, and receives it with so many thanks, from the various people on whom he calls, that these people soon become impressed with the notion that dry bread can be applied with satisfaction as a poultice in every case.
column511: In this way he spoils the road for good beggars who, not going into workhouses, need coppers for their beds, and who always make use of that indefinite term "something to eat," but would not, on any account, remind their hearers of "a crust of dry bread."
column512: Again, he spoils true beggars by his lack of system.
column513: A workhouse tramp has not that energy and concentration which is required for success.
column514: Sometimes he knocks at the first door in a street, after which he walks to the next street, where he knocks at the middle house, or perhaps the last; and, when the true beggar comes after him, and beholds this timid fool running from side to side of a street, he knows very well that the street is being spoiled, for he cannot tell exactly where the other has been.
column515: In a case of this kind it is best for the true, systematic beggar to go at once into the next street, and it is not unlikely then but what he will soon recognize the workhouse tramp at its other end.
column516: If the true beggar had no other system than this--running here and there to chance houses, at the sign of a green gate, or a church announcement in a front window--he would soon be so confused as to where he had, or had not been, that a good-sized town would in a very short time become useless to him.
column517: To a true beggar the workhouse tramp is a mystery.
column518: The former cannot understand how the latter can perform such stone-breaking feats on a bread-and-water diet, and he wonders where lies the fascination of such a life.
column519: He, himself, though he may rise penniless in the morning, has confidence in the day's fulfilment, and he sometimes meets with a surprise in the shape of a piece of silver.
column520: Sometimes he calls at an alehouse, where a merry party is in full song, and to them he offers to render harmony, provided they will favour him with a collection.
column521: This proposition is invariably favoured, and the true beggar then flatters the loudest and most persistent singer of the party by giving him his cap to make that collection.
column522: Of course, he is offered a glass of ale before he begins, and during the intervals between verses he is not forgotten.
column523: As a rule he is not a sweet singer, but his voice is thought to be remarkable, especially if he sings a familiar air with a good chorus.
column524: If his hearers are half blind with drink, and incapable of using their feet, it is well for the true beggar to end his song with a dance.
column525: The most awkward shuffling will appear to them as the movements of lightning.
column526: This kindness on his part calls forth extra coppers and a more liberal supply of ale.
column527: Now, what happens to shame this true beggar, and to spoil him in the act of earning a livelihood?
column528: Why, one of these ragged workhouse tramps walks in and begs a drink of water.
column530: mark you, when this true beggar is earning ale and money!
column531: Then what wonder that such a man should become an eyesore to all classes of men?
column532: He has no self-respect, for, whereas he often passes stores and houses without calling at them, he is nothing backward in making known his wants to true beggars.
column533: For sometimes he by accident picks up sixpence, works for it, or receives it unsolicited, with which he pays for his bed at a lodging-house.
column534: Then he, without shame or self-respect, begs tea of one, sugar of another, and makes himself a pest to all those who with an independent spirit do their begging outside instead of inside a lodging-house, as he does.
column535: It is fortunate for us that he does not get these sixpences often, and that he is compelled almost night after night to the workhouse for accommodation.
column536: The question is not altogether without humour, for these workhouse tramps actually call themselves our brothers on the road.
column537: They stop us familiarly on our way, and ask for information of workhouses, as though we were one of themselves.
column538: One advises me not to go to a certain workhouse, for they will make me break stones all the day following, on a little dry bread and water.
column539: As though I ever, for one moment, dreamed that such a lot would be mine!
column540: "My good fellow," says I, "_lodging-houses_ are made for true beggars, and not workhouses."
column541: For the above reasons I have become deeply interested in any scheme to improve the condition of the workhouse tramp, for, as I have said, he is not only a burden on the ratepayers of the country, but mars the success of all true beggars.
column542: We are often, when in the act of begging money for our beds, told to go to the workhouse; which is owing to this workhouse tramp having communicated the intelligence that he would be satisfied with bread, and that he is not in need of money for a place to sleep, seeing that the workhouse can accommodate him.
column543: For he becomes hardened to the indignities and heavy tasks set before him, and at last looks on such a cold, wretched place as a home, aye, even as a playground.
column544: XVII Stubborn Invalids It is a pathetic sight to see men dying in a lodging-house, fighting against death day after day.
