column545: The few healthy men that are present are quite indifferent to life, and do not care if their health is impaired through breathing in the same room as a dozen consumptives.
column546: These healthy men are so thoughtless of themselves that they offer their dying comrades saucers of tea, after which they drink with their own lips perhaps on the same place as their unfortunate fellows used.
column547: I have offered many a one of these poor fellows a drink of tea, but was always very careful not to use the saucer after them.
column548: When they wanted to return my kindness, and I did not like to wound their feelings by refusing them, I always took a clean saucer from the shelf, instead of using theirs.
column549: I well remember one man, who was in a terrible condition for the last three months before he was carried to the hospital.
column550: He was a man of about middle age, and his face was very white, and all day long he was coughing and spitting in the kitchen, with only enough strength in his body to take him to bed.
column551: Although I sat with my back to him at meals, I could not help but hear the poor fellow, and could not help a feeling of revulsion.
column552: In fact I began at last to look upon these consumptives as murderers who, by their stubbornness in not going to the hospital, were killing me and others with their breath.
column553: Some of these men are in receipt of small pensions, or get a little assistance from relatives on the outside, and for this reason they die sooner; for they have more leisure than others--who must go out to earn a few pennies--at the coke fire.
column554: Little Punch is dead, who might have lived for many more years, had he not been kept indoors so much by outside assistance.
column555: In the spring this little fellow used to set off with his pack as a pedlar through the country, and when he returned at the end of summer was always in good condition, but was as bad as ever after a month in the lodging-house.
column556: I believe he could have prolonged his life ten or fifteen years, if he had rambled both winter and summer.
column557: These men fight against going to the hospital and sit dying day after day, making no complaint; until the lodging-house keeper is surprised some morning to find them lying in bed, without the strength to rise.
column558: Even then they swear it is only temporary indisposition, and that after a few hours' rest they will be well again.
column559: Then the doctor is called, and then comes the ambulance; but it is too late, for if the men do not die on the way, they die soon after they reach the hospital.
column560: Poor old Peter saw himself wasting away.
column561: He was six feet two inches in height, but thin enough to be exhibited.
column562: He kept himself alive by a merry heart, but his hollow, spasmodic laughter refused to make his body fat.
column563: Up to the last he affected great cheerfulness, but he could not cheat death any longer.
column564: It was impossible to feel any revulsion against Peter; he did not spit about the place, and though he was always coughing, the poor fellow had no strength to make a disturbing noise: he could not be heard if you were not seated next him.
column565: You could feel him cough, by the vibration of the bench or table, more often than you could hear him.
column566: I also believe that he had consideration for others, knowing that a sick man can make himself unpleasant.
column567: Peter did nothing but win pity and goodwill, and he returned it by endeavouring to be witty and cheerful.
column568: Old Scotty Bill, the flycatcher, is also dead.
column569: Consumption did not claim him as a victim, for he died at the advanced age of eighty-three, which was wonderful for a man who had spent the best part of his life in a lodging-house.
column570: No doubt if he had lived under better conditions, he would have reached a hundred years with ease.
column571: All his interest was in flies.
column572: While other lodgers were discussing the abundance of fish in Billingsgate, Scotty could be seen counting the flies in the kitchen, as a sign whether he should go out with his fly-papers or not.
column573: His language was very bad, and the last words he was heard to utter surprised even those who were accustomed to him, by their unusual weight and speed.
column574: He was another stubborn invalid, and fought hard against going to the hospital.
column575: His death was quite characteristic, and I can hardly imagine it otherwise.
column576: He, like many another one, was found one morning helpless in bed, and the manager, seeing that he was very ill, in spite of his assurance to the contrary, sent at once for the doctor.
column577: But when the latter arrived he and the manager were surprised to find the bed empty.
column578: On making enquiries they were told that Scotty was in the kitchen, and it was there that they found the old man, reading a newspaper.
column579: In spite of this the doctor saw that Scotty was not in good condition and tried to persuade him to go to bed, but this the old man swore that he would not do, and demanded some reason for such a request.
column580: Then there was a whispered consultation between the manager and the doctor, and it was decided to send for the ambulance and have him taken to the hospital whether he would or no.
column581: Now Scotty had lived in that same lodging-house for over thirty years, and for that reason was well known in the locality.
column582: Therefore, when the ambulance arrived at the door, and a woman outside enquired of a lodger as to who the ambulance was for, and was told of Scotty Bill, the news soon spread abroad.
column583: In less than five minutes between twenty and thirty women had assembled at the door.
column584: These women of the slums were never very clean, and at the present time not one of them was in a fit condition to answer her own door; but they forgot this in their anxiety to see poor Scotty Bill and wish him a speedy recovery.
column585: At last the old man appeared, and it staggered him to see the number of women at the door.
column586: But when he heard them say, "Poor Bill"; and "Good luck to you, Scotty"; his fury knew no bounds.
column587: Standing with one foot on the step, he paused, and then poured forth such a torrent of abuse that some of the women lost all sympathy with him and feebly retaliated.
column588: He told them to go home and scrub their dirty faces, instead of coming there to watch him--and other things not fit to mention.
column589: It was, they confessed, the worst language they had ever heard--and more than one of them was capable of using very strong words.
column590: That was the last seen of Scotty Bill, and that was his dying speech, for he died on his arrival at the hospital.
column591: I have heard of the death of a number more, men that lingered with such determination that it almost seems as if they have taken advantage of my absence and died; for they all seem to have gone one after the other since I left.
column593: A terrible cough he had, but his face and neck were always like raw beef.
column594: That one eye of his blazed with such power that I have often imagined the devil hard at work shovelling half a ton a coal a minute to supply its fierce light.
column595: He also went off suddenly, walking the kitchen floor on Monday, and lying cold and dead on the following day.
column596: "Rags" is also dead, the great drinker; the man who when abroad complained that whiskey made him totter, whereas it was an earthquake, that tumbled towers and made the firm-footed houses reel.
column597: "The whiskey's in my legs," said "Rags," not knowing it was an earthquake.
column598: "Monkey" Sam and the "Dodger" are both dead, and there is no doubt but what the Dodger's death hastened Sam's.
column599: These two were the slyest pair that I have ever met.
column600: I believe they understood each other's thoughts so well that when one's body itched the other could, without seeing his friend make a motion, scratch his own body at the exact place.
column601: These two conversed by looks, and uttered very few words.
column602: They were so well-matched and thought so much of one another, that something more than accident must have brought two such men together.
column603: It was always clear that if anything happened to part them, neither one would seek friendship elsewhere.
column604: I had seen all these men fighting against death day after day, but with such determination, that I can hardly believe the report that calls them dead; especially as there is no proof of lettered stone, seeing that they are all in paupers' graves.
column605: All these poor invalids in common lodging-houses are under the impression that doctors, when they find that their patients have no friends, and cannot be thoroughly cured, kill them.
column606: That is why they are so stubborn, and fight till they cannot move, before they will enter a hospital.
column607: XVIII The Earnings of Beggars In writing of the earnings of beggars, I do not, of course, include common tramps, who are satisfied with barns, sheds, empty houses and workhouses; I write of true beggars, who have not lost their self-respect, and who, by their exertions, are as sure of a bed at night--although it is a different one--as other people that have homes.
column608: If they sleep out of doors for a night or two in summer-time, they do so for pleasure; as people with homes will, when they sleep in hammocks under trees.
column609: The true beggar does not shirk business, or save money by sleeping out; he still follows his calling and makes the price of his bed, but in this instance he spends the money on ale instead of stifling with so many others in a common lodging-house.
column610: A good beggar is always ready to seize opportunities.
column611: He will never allow a man to pass on who greets him pleasantly, or requires information, without either begging a copper, a pipeful of tobacco, or even a match.
column612: I think now of that memorable morning in America, when Brum, an excellent beggar, saw a lady kiss a horse.
column613: We were at a camp fire making coffee, when I was startled by the unusual eagerness of Brum's voice crying, "Look!"
column614: Following the direction of his finger, I saw a lonely house on a hill, and near the house was a lady in riding-habit, and she was patting a horse's neck.
column615: Seeing nothing unusual in this, I said, "What's the matter?"
column616: "You were too late to see," answered Brum; "she kissed the horse!"
column617: Now I am very fond of dumb creatures, and was therefore very pleased to see Brum moved so nobly by such an incident; but I was not allowed much time to congratulate myself on meeting with such a kind-hearted companion, for these were Brum's next words; "A lady that kisses a horse ought to be good for a piece of silver"; and before I could utter a word he had gone.
column618: This incident plainly shows how quick a good beggar is to take advantage of an opportunity.
column619: And Brum was right, for he not only returned with a piece of silver in his pocket, but also a parcel of food in his hand.
column620: Of course, second-rate beggars in America earn more than first-rate beggars in Europe.
column621: In any of the large cities of America an active beggar can obtain as much as three dollars in a couple of hours, even if he suspends work for a drink.
column622: If a beggar is lucky enough to meet a gambler, he is just as likely to get a dollar as ten cents; in fact a number of beggars in that country make gambling places their haunts, for gamblers are well known to be superstitious, and few of them would think of refusing a beggar when on their way to the tables.
column623: One of the quickest ways to make a good haul is to beg a fast overland train, when it must stop at some out-of-the-way place to take in water or coal.
column624: A beggar often boards one of these trains and, taking off his hat--not out of respect, but to hold money--goes from passenger to passenger, from one end of the train to the other.
column625: It is necessary to do business very quick, for the train does not stop long, and the conductor must be avoided.
column626: If a man has the luck to get right through the train, he often has several dollars to his account.
column627: In this country beggars have different methods.
column628: No doubt singing hymns in Welsh towns and villages is one of the most profitable forms of begging.
column629: The Welsh are very kind-hearted and, being a musical people, it is almost impossible for them to resist an appeal made by song.
column630: When murder has been committed in a locality, you will always find a couple of men making a song of it in the streets, and they certainly do an excellent trade with their song-sheets.
column631: Good voices are not so necessary as a distinct enunciation of particular words such as blood, axe, bolster, etc.
column632: But even in less fortunate cases, when there has not even been an attempt at murder, beggars can still do well by singing well-known hymns.
column633: There is one kind of beggar in Wales whose earnings can water the mouth of many a beggar in America.
column634: We must approach this man very seriously, for he is forced to beg through a terrible affliction.
column635: He is either totally blind or paralysed, and is to be seen standing or sitting near a pit's mouth on pay-day.
column636: For this man the Welsh colliers have deep pity, and in a very short time they fill his hat with money, silver shining among the copper, although the contributors are only working men.
column637: But for a man with a more simple affliction the colliers have, of course, far less sympathy.
column638: A great number of colliers have suffered in accidents, and they are still working hard, so it cannot be expected that they will make much distinction between a man who has lost a finger and one that has not.
column639: Beggars that play music do well, whether it is an organ, a cornet, a concertina, or a tin whistle.
column640: Public-houses are the best stands, for men half drunk are always musically inclined.
column641: These men also do well at private houses.
column642: It seems strange to say that houses where a hungry man has difficulty in getting bread, can generally find a copper for a beggar musician.
column643: The reason is very simple: music pleases the children, and, naturally, a mother is always willing to assist men that make the children laugh and dance, and the baby bounce in her arm.
column644: In fact these men are not regarded as beggars, but entertainers.
column645: If they know their business well, they will keep a sharp eye on the door and windows, and when they see a child's face, nod and smile, and throw kisses to it.
column646: Then the child laughs and claps its little hands, and the mother hears the child and she laughs also.
column647: The meanest woman would not rob the child of this enjoyment, and if she allows the music to continue she is under a moral obligation to pay for it.
column648: I knew Billy the whistler well, and he only had one complaint--dogs.
column649: He could seldom blow three notes on his tin whistle before he was accompanied, against his wish, by a dog's voice.
column650: The bottom of his trousers was always in tatters, so much did dogs dislike a tin whistle.
column651: Manchester Jack was one of the best beggars that I have met in this country.
column652: He scorned to play music, sing, or sell.
column653: Although he was a big, strong, able-bodied man in the prime of life, he could earn more than a crippled young man or an old man feebled and paralysed.
column654: This sounds like a reproach to the world, but it is very easy to explain.
column655: Manchester Jack, being active and business-like, could call at three times more houses than a man that was afflicted by age or accident.
column656: He would certainly be refused at one or two places where the latter would succeed, but the greater number of houses he called at would give him the advantage.
column657: From a beggar's point of view, the world consists of two kinds of people--the good and the bad.
column658: The good will not refuse a man because he is able-bodied, and the bad can and will always find some excuse for not giving assistance.
column659: The very few that give in particular cases are in such a minority that a man like Manchester Jack would be very little affected.
column660: I travelled with him for ten days, and when I took one side of a street, and he the other, he not only finished his side first, but, starting at the other end of mine, would meet me half way.
column661: He was a kind-hearted fellow, always willing to give strangers information about good or bad towns.
column662: On one occasion, when we had just finished begging a street, Manchester Jack asked me if I had received any scrand (food).
column663: I told him yes; that I had taken fivepence and two parcels of food, which were in my pockets.
column664: "Well, lad," he answered, "I have taken ninepence, but no scrand.
column665: Let me have the scrand and I will make it all right later on."
column666: I gave him the two parcels, but was considerably taken by surprise; for I knew Jack was too proud a beggar to be seen eating in public, and preferred to sit comfortably in a warm lodging-house kitchen.
column667: Taking the food he went to a house that he had just left, knocked at the door, handed in the parcels and began to retreat, followed by a woman's voice, which made him hurry faster.
column668: When he came back he explained to me that he had called at that house, and the woman had begun to cry, saying at last that she was in want herself.
column669: "So," said Manchester Jack, "I have given her your parcels and a couple of pennies to get a bit of tea."
column670: On another occasion he was leaving a house when he ran into a very dirty-looking tramp, who was wasting his precious time looking at the doors instead of knocking at them.
column671: "Mister," said this dirty and timid man, judging Jack by his smart walk and confident smile to be the tenant of the house--"Mister," said he, "is the Mrs. any good for a mouthful of bread?"
column672: "Here," answered Jack, giving him a penny--"here, and get out of this street at once; for a beggar has just left this house, and the lady cannot give to everyone; take my advice and go to another street."
column673: I got on very well with Manchester Jack, and we might have been together for a long time, had he not been arrested for begging, and sentenced to a few days' imprisonment.
column674: XIX Charity in Strange Quarters A fine house is seldom worth a beggar's notice, for the simple reason that it has too many people to consult.
column675: The servant girl has to tell the cook, and the cook has her orders from the mistress; and either one of these has power to stop the flow of charity.
column676: The servant girl may, if no one is looking, dismiss a beggar with a shake of her head; or the cook may think she has quite enough work to do without waiting on tramps.
column677: The fact of the matter is that you can seldom find a servant and her mistress of one mind; if the latter is kind and charitable, it is often found that the servant is otherwise.
column678: If the mistress is mean and uncharitable, the servant is often--sometimes through spite, and no kindness in herself--inclined to charity.
column679: All tramps have experiences to relate of how kind-hearted ladies or gentlemen have come out of the house and called them back, or met them at the gate and, after enquiring their wants, led them back to the house and reprimanded the servants for sending poor men away empty-handed.
column680: Again, there are other cases of servant girls giving charity against the strict orders of their masters and mistresses--girls with good, kind hearts.
column681: So, you see, a fine house is so unreliable that it always pays a beggar to confine his efforts to small houses.
column682: There is not the least doubt but what bells cry hunger, common iron knockers spell charity, and shabby doors that cannot afford either bell or knocker, and require bare knuckles, are--from a beggar's point of view--the richest.
column683: Even when rich people are charitable, and give food, clothes, and money, they never seem to be impressed by the word workhouse; for they seem to regard that place as a comfortable home.
column684: But to mention workhouse to the poor is to send a shudder through them, and they will always try to assist a man to escape it.
column685: They see that dreadful place before themselves, when old age and poverty come, and they pity a man that has to go there, if only for one night.
column686: A man that played an accordion, whom I often saw, had a certain pitch.
column687: People that passed by could not help but pity him, thinking that he was a stranger in the town, and did not know the almshouses from other dwellings.
column688: But this musician knew well what the houses were, for he had been to them before and--in a whisper--these almshouses were almost his best pitch.
column689: Going up a narrow passage, he would take up a position in a large stone yard, where he would stand and play a few tunes, and would be rewarded with three or four pennies and a couple of parcels of food.
column690: This was certainly good, for it was all bunts (profit).
column691: He will not be so successful when he plays to a row of fine villas at the other end of the town.
column692: If it were not for making himself a nuisance, and being paid to go away, it would never be worth while to play to fine houses.
column693: I shall never forget the summer's day when I accidentally discovered a long row of small houses hidden away from all eyes.
column694: Having been given a sandwich, I had put it in my pocket, but on second thoughts decided to wrap it in paper.
column695: Seeing a dark, narrow passage between two shops, I entered, so as to have some privacy to do so.
column696: While I was in the act of wrapping this sandwich in paper, and returning it to my pocket, I was surprised at being passed by three small children, and wondered what they were doing there.
column697: But I lost sight of them at once, around a short bend in the passage.
column698: Being curious to know what was around this bend, I advanced, and what do you think I saw?
column699: A long yard, with more than a dozen small cottages in a row.
column700: This was a lovely sight for a beggar!
column701: In there a man could beg without fear of policemen, and without being annoyed by the stares of people passing in carts and on foot.
column702: But the best of it was that these houses would escape ninety-nine beggars out of a hundred.
column703: I lost no time in going to work, in spite of a number of children that were playing in the yard.
column704: Instead of beginning at the first house, as an amateur would, I passed them all by, intending to begin at the extreme end, calling at every house on my return.
column705: My motive for doing this will be approved by all true beggars; it was to advertise my presence, so that people would expect me, and save me the trouble of knocking and explaining my wants, and my time would not be wasted.
column706: This turned out well, for, after I had called at the end cottage, where I was not expected, I had nothing to do after but receive the ready pennies and food from the neighbours, as I came to them.
column707: As I have said, it was a summer's day, and all the doors were open, so that the people could hardly fail to know of my arrival.
column708: Moreover, the children had found time to run in and tell their mothers to expect me, and when.
column709: No beggar could ever have done business quicker, for in less than a quarter of an hour, I was finished, having received fivepence halfpenny and two parcels of food.
column710: At one house, where I was given a penny, the woman also gave me a glass of beer, saying that she was thirty-five years of age that day, and had been married fourteen years, and was respected wherever she went.
column711: Yes, sometimes charity comes from strange quarters, as only beggars know.
column712: One day an old lady gave me half a chicken and a sponge cake, with the information that she was getting parish relief.
column713: I don't know how to account for this, but suppose she was fortunate in being well looked after by some rich family for whom she had worked.
column714: Another time I went to a small cottage, and the door was answered by a very shabby-looking old lady.
column715: I was selling needles and laces, at the time, and, when the old lady was asked to buy, she answered that she had not one penny in the house.
column716: She looked so very poor that I felt ashamed of having called there, and felt much inclined to make her a present of a packet of needles.
column717: As I was about to leave, she said: "Would you like to have something to eat?"
column718: Not caring to take anything from this poor woman, I said: "No, thank you; I have plenty in my pockets."
column719: "No matter for that," she answered briskly.
column720: Saying this, she went indoors, and in a few moments returned with a brown-paper parcel in her hands.
column721: It looked very much like a suit of clothes, but when I received it I was astonished at its weight.
column722: Thanking her I left, and at the first opportunity sat down to examine the contents.
column723: To my surprise I had half a rabbit pie and a whole custard pudding.
column724: This woman, it seemed, was far from being poor, and lived well; and that she had not a penny in the house was not to say that she was in poverty, as I first supposed.
column725: When I was once followed by school-children, I could not help but see by their whispers that something unusual was about to happen.
column726: It was not long before a little girl came forward and put a penny in my hand.
column727: This was the most extraordinary charity that I ever received; for the child was old enough to know the value of money and the number of sweet things, so dear to childhood, that a penny could buy.
column728: Another, a little boy, seeing this wonderful deed of sacrifice, wanted me to take his slice of bread and jam, most of the jam being licked off.
column729: A beggar soon forgets a kindness, but it is most certain that the charity he receives from the young affects him longest.
column730: Sometimes boys, who take their dinners with them to work, have food left; and it gives them great pride to meet a beggar and give it to him.
column731: Sometimes--more often than not--it is only dry bread; and they offer it to a beggar who perhaps has better food in his pockets.
column732: Now, if a man or woman gave such a beggar this dry bread, he would most likely receive it with indifference and cold thanks, and throw it away, being none too particular in carrying it beyond the eyes of the giver.
column733: But when he is offered this dry bread by innocent, well-meaning boys, he not only takes it with a great show of gratitude and pleasure, but is very careful that the boys will get no chance to see him throw it away.
column734: XX Enemies of Beggars It is almost time that our streets were cleared of so many house-callers that, hour after hour, knock at doors and ring bells until a lady is not in a fit condition to listen to a beggar.
column735: It is commonly thought that policemen and dogs are a beggar's only enemies, but this is far from true; even the child that waits at the gate to see if he gets anything, and, if possible, what he does get--even this small innocent must be regarded as an enemy to a beggar; not to mention hundreds of adults that pester people for rent and instalments for goods received, and others that beg people to buy coal, wood, and oil, vegetables and fruit.
column736: Of course, these callers do not matter much to the true beggar, for he goes blindly to work, careless of his surroundings; but the timid beginner, who looks to the right and left of him, before and behind, is very apt to pass on if a neighbourhood is not kept more quiet for his work.
column737: The true beggar, as I have said, is not often annoyed by these pestilent callers.
column738: Sometimes he knocks at a door and, before his knock can be answered, some infernal agent comes to the same door.
column739: In a case of this kind, the new beggar would be flurried, and most likely leave the house in possession of his enemy--but it is far different with the true beggar.
column740: He wishes his enemy a cheerful good morning--although it is seldom that he gets a civil answer--and is not afraid to speak out when the lady comes.
column741: In fact, he would be the first to explain his business, whether he was there first or not.
column742: A first-class beggar like Brum would scorn to mention such little difficulties as these, and I know well that all good beggars will despise me for raising such paltry objections.
column743: But even Brum himself has given way before people that were not regarded as beggars; even he had to give way--not out of spite or ill-will, but through his kindness or generosity.
column744: One day, when we were both out begging, Brum surprised me with these words--"One beggar is quite enough in this street; let us go to another."
column745: I was quite surprised at these words, for I knew well that Brum would not have budged an inch if there were a dozen beggars in the street.
column746: But what surprised me more was that when I looked before and behind, I could not see anyone that could be mistaken for a beggar.
column747: "I don't see anyone," I said at last, looking at him for an explanation.
column750: "Well, there she is, and good luck to her!"
column751: And to my astonishment he nodded towards a Sister of Charity.
column752: It would never have occurred to me to regard such a person as a beggar, but she certainly was; and it proved how kind-hearted and considerate Brum was to give way to her, so that she might have every opportunity to get what the street was worth.
column753: I ought not to have been surprised to hear Brum say these words, for I had often heard him at the camps and elsewhere laud a certain Christian leader as "the greatest beggar that ever lived."
column754: To Brum this man was a perfect hero, whose prowess amazed him.
column755: Brum followed his career with as much interest as any man ever followed the doings of Napoleon; and every scrap of paper that came to hand, on which he saw the name of this Christian leader, was read and re-read by Brum, and commented on daily.
column756: In fact, Brum was never without two or three pieces of paper relating to "the greatest beggar that ever lived."
column757: "He does not beg a needle, a piece of thread, a cake, a sandwich, a pair of stockings, or a shirt," Brum would say, glancing with scorn at other beggars in the camp; "he knows nothing about our petty ways of doing business: he begs shiploads of provisions, wardrobes of clothes; aye, acres of land and barrels of money.
column758: And this man is an Englishman," Brum would add, with a slight sneer at any American beggars who happened to be present.
column759: The latter had to admit that their country had not yet produced so great a beggar.
column760: Curly Jack, of England, had never met Brum and never heard of him, but he was of exactly the same opinion; but whereas Brum admired the man as a hero, Curly Jack abused him for his success.
column761: Whereas Brum was as delighted as a child to see his hero's banner in charge of a trusty officer, and to hear the band--Curly Jack no sooner saw or heard, than he slunk off in an opposite direction, scowling and muttering curses.
column762: One Sunday morning Curly Jack and myself were in Northampton, and we had left the lodging-house together; after which we parted, he going down one street, while I went farther on, so as to give him plenty of room.
column763: I did not find Northampton very bad, although the boot trade--its main industry--had been declining for a long time.
column764: In about half an hour I had several pennies over my bed money, also a quantity of food, so I thought I would get a newspaper and return to the lodging-house, and take it easy for the rest of the day.
column765: As I was on my way back I saw Curly Jack going to a house, and waited--at his motion--until he was at liberty to come.
column768: "Very bad," he answered; "I was in a good street, where I have done well before, but twenty or thirty beggars have been there this morning before me, and played it out."
column769: These words surprised me not a little, and I asked him for an explanation.
column770: "There they are again," he cried, with an oath.
column771: I looked in every direction, but all I saw was three little children together, and one couple that appeared to be lovers.
column774: "I hear the Salvation Army," I said; "surely you don't mean them!"
column775: "Of course I mean them," he answered, with some impatience.
column777: I said, at a loss to understand him.
column778: "I should think their presence would be good for beggars--that they would open people's hearts."
column779: "Come with me, and I will show you how they spoil the street for a beggar," said Jack.
column781: In a few moments we were in the same street as the Salvation Army, and my companion walked boldly towards them, while I lingered a little behind.
column782: However, when I saw him standing near them, I joined him, and could not help but notice that several members of the Army rewarded our presence with smiles.
column783: It was not long before I saw how the Salvation Army could spoil a street for a beggar.
column784: While the meeting was going on, several members not only went from house to house, but even begged passers-by--aye, even came to me and my seedy friend.
column785: "Now," said Curly Jack, as we were leaving--"now, are you satisfied?
column786: What chance has a beggar, be he ever so good, against these people?
column787: It will be impossible for the rest of the day to get a single penny in this street, or any other street that they have been to."
column788: People will now be able to see, by these incidents, the great number of enemies a poor beggar has to contend with; enemies that would take the bread out of his mouth.
column789: It is very true that in the green country beggars have a little dread of policemen and dogs, but in towns they fear more the annoyance of other callers, who are not beggars.
column790: One thing they dread very much, in towns of some size, is to be offered a ticket to introduce them to a charitable organization that professes to attend to their wants.
column791: True beggars know well what these organizations are.
column792: But sometimes the man who is looking for work is only too glad to receive this ticket--and he certainly gets plenty of work.
column793: He does about three shillings' worth of labour for a bed whose only virtue is cleanliness, and about threepenny worth of food.
column794: However, the poor fellow is well satisfied, because he is a very timid man, and he feels less shame in being made a slave than a beggar.
column795: He is only too glad to perform these tasks at every opportunity, but the true English beggar is a Briton that never will be a slave.
column796: XXI The Lowest State of Man Some people think that a man cannot fall lower than to live in a common lodging-house; but men and women are occasionally met in London that are even stared at and pitied by those who live in such low places.
column797: The men and women of whom I speak would not be admitted into the lowest common lodging-houses in London.
column798: They are so ragged and filthy in appearance that if you gave one of them a sovereign it would be impossible to get a bed until an alteration was made in his or her appearance.
column799: Some of these have slept in their clothes so often and been outcasts so long that they are really without the least hope--not dejected for a few hours or days, as with others.
column800: Their dreams, if they have any, are recollections of days gone, but they have no hope in the future.
column802: Men and women in such a condition that if a man gives them a penny he has to avert his eyes; and the most kind-hearted women pass them by with as quick a glance as possible.
column803: There is only one place open to these poor wretches, and that is a Salvation Army shelter, where they pay twopence and sleep on the floor.
column804: They think nothing of suffering; one of them will sit on a seat, when it is raining hard, with the utmost indifference, and there may be an arch that he could reach in less than two minutes.
column805: So he gets wet and shivers all night, which is common for him.
column806: I have seen a man of this description refused a bed at a Salvation Army lodging-house, and it did not take the officer many seconds to come to that conclusion.
column807: Of course, it is not often--perhaps half a dozen times in a year--that one of these poor people can afford to pay fourpence for a bed; but sometimes they have the good fortune to find a silver coin, or some gentleman gives it to them.
column808: If the latter is the case, the gentleman is probably a stranger in London, and comes from some happy new land where such extreme poverty is not known.
column809: One night, when I was at the office paying for my bed, I heard a man come in at the front door and stand behind me, but did not turn my head, thinking that he was one of the many lodgers that lived there.
column810: When I was about to leave I heard this man put down some money and tell the lieutenant that he wanted a bed.
column811: As I did not hear that officer make any answer, but rise from his stool instead to come out of the office, I turned my head, thinking something strange was about to happen.
column812: The lieutenant was soon out and standing before the would-be lodger, looking at him from head to foot.
column813: "I should think not," he said at last with an amused smile to think that the man had asked such a question.
column814: "We have no bed for _you_," he continued; "you had better go to the shelter in Blackfriars."
column815: The man was certainly a pitiful, even disgusting, sight.
column816: His hair was very long, and so was his beard; and the colour of his hands, his neck, and the hairless part of his face was almost black.
column817: His clothes were in tatters, showing his naked legs; his boots had no soles or heels, and the uppers were kept together with string.
column818: This poor fellow had either found a silver coin or had received it in charity; and, having slept in his clothes for months, he wanted them off for one night and the luxury of a warm bed.
column819: Not only that, but if this man had a bed, he would also have the use of the washhouse all the next day, with plenty of hot water to clean himself.
column820: But this was not to be, for the lieutenant was too keen-eyed.
column821: This poor fellow, who was so ambitious, did not seem at all surprised at the refusal, but picked up his money and walked out without a word.
column822: Perhaps he had been to other places with the same result, and would still go to others.
column823: The Christian officer watched him going, and, when he was gone, turned to re-enter his office.
column824: Seeing me standing there, a witness to what had happened, he said, "What a face!"
column825: and entered the office laughing--he, he, he!
column826: Any person in London can see these poor wretches, who are in as low a state as it is possible to fall into.
column827: It is almost impossible to miss them, whether they are seated or walking, for if you are not looking their way you are almost certain of hearing strange sounds and having your attention drawn to them.
column828: They all talk to themselves, and laugh and swear; for cold nights and hunger have made them crazy to a great extent.
column829: Two of them are seldom seen together, for each one has just enough sense to know that he draws more attention than is good, without inviting more.
column830: Time is nothing to these; if they have enough bread to last the day, they are not likely to leave one particular seat.
column831: As a rule each one has a certain spot to spend the day, and, after being forced to walk all night, they return as soon as possible to their favourite place.
column832: It is in the early morning that they get their food, and where they get it is a secret each one keeps to himself.
column833: This secret is their living, and that is another cause why they should be reserved with one another.
column834: One of these men told me once that he knew a certain large private house where a paper parcel consisting of fragments of food was to be found every morning in the back alley, close to the ash-bin.
column835: This paper parcel had kept him for three years, but he had missed it several times.
column836: No doubt some stray beggar had found it on those occasions, but, not knowing that such a parcel was put there every morning, had never troubled to look for it again.
column837: When I heard this I could not help thinking how likely it was that something would happen to disappoint him; that the tenant's absence or death would alter such an arrangement.
column838: But I did not give the least hint of this, for I saw that the poor fellow thought he was sure of bread for life.
column839: He had not the least doubt but what the parcel would always be put there, and his only worry was that some other beggar would follow him and learn his secret, or discover the parcel by accident.
column840: In the winter this man spent all his days on one particular seat, when he could get it, and as near to it as possible when it was already taken.
column841: When I walked along the Embankment one morning, at nine o'clock, he was then seating himself.
column842: He had his paper parcel beside him, from which he had just taken a crust of bread.
column843: When I came back that way, at four o'clock in the afternoon, he was still there.
column844: Perhaps he would have a certain shady tree in one of the parks for his summer days.
column845: None of these are beggars; they never go to houses or beg of people in the street, for they know that their appearance is so bad that they dare not draw more attention than people like to give them.
column846: Sometimes, not very often, a man has the courage to give them a coin, but no woman ever has.
column847: They are so surprised at receiving unsolicited charity that they forget to offer any thanks.
column848: The man whom I have just mentioned, who had a parcel of food every morning, would rather you passed him by without giving him money, for fear a policeman would see the act and accuse him of begging, and move him from his favourite seat.
column849: As I have said, most of them know places where they can get food without begging, outside large factories and elsewhere.
column850: They are seldom to be seen in private streets, because they do not beg houses.
column851: I have often seen men standing outside large factories and workshops, waiting for the workmen, so as to get the food some of them have left from dinner and, being frugal husbands, are taking home; but who gladly give it to a man who they think wants it.
column852: These beggars generally ask a workman, when they see him with his food-tin, if he has anything left from dinner.
column853: Whether he has or not does not matter, for the question draws the attention of those that have, and in a few moments the beggar has enough for a couple of good meals.
column854: But these poor wretches, who have fallen so low in their appearance, have no need to speak at all, only to show themselves.
column855: For it is not only apparent to every eye that they are homeless, but it almost seems as if they never had homes.
column856: Such men are the only thorough outcasts, for whom nothing can be done.
column857: Neither the Salvation Army nor the Church Army will deal with them.
column858: And if one of these men went to the Charity Organization he would not be admitted inside the doors, much less receive the honour of being invited in and questioned.
column859: That particular Society would not be interested as to what his father did for a living or his grandfather's habits.
column860: In fact it does not need those hard, smart, detective qualities of charity officers to see that the date of social respectability must go back a very long way indeed in this man's past.
column861: XXII The Lodger Lover A lodger gave him the name of "Cinders," and he took to it kindly.
column862: I was present in the kitchen on the day he arrived as a stranger, nameless and alone, as far as the other lodgers were concerned, for they did not know what name he had entered at the office.
column863: He was in rags and tatters, and "Rags" or "Tatters" should certainly have been his name.
column864: In fact the name was offered to him, but he returned an unsatisfactory stare.
column865: He was preparing his tea at the same table as "Punch," and the latter being in need of a pinch of salt, and seeing none of his friends at tea, asked this stranger to oblige him, saying: "Would you oblige me, 'Rags,' with a pinch of salt?"
column866: The man stared at "Punch" for a moment, and then walked away without giving an answer.
column867: He was at that time cooking a herring at the fire.
column868: Now it so happened that a few moments later this man was pouring out tea, when all at once there was a loud cry of "Whose herring is this?"
column869: The man turned quickly at the sound, and beheld his herring making a few spasmodic motions, as it dangled on a long wire.
column870: He immediately ran to the rescue, but alas!
column871: too late; for the tatters of his loose clothes encompassed him like a deadly plant, and when he arrived the herring was lying motionless under the grate.
column872: After great care he succeeded in bringing it to the light, covered with ashes and cinders.
column873: Still, with great care, he washed it and, after placing it flat on a plate, returned it to the fire.
column874: "I hope you do not blame me for that accident, 'Cinders,'" said kind-hearted "Punch."
column875: "Oh, no," answered the man newly named "Cinders."
column876: "'Cinders' has too much sense for that," said "Red-Nosed Scotty," who happened to be sitting near.
column878: cried the kitchen-man, who was about to build the coke fire, and wanted all food and teapots removed.
column879: "It belongs to 'Cinders,'" said a number of voices.
column880: From that day to this his name is "Cinders," owing to the accident to his herring when he first came.
column881: If he was arrested, it would be--"'Cinders' is in jail"; and if he died it would be--"'Cinders' is dead."
column882: If a man who goes to live in a common lodging-house does not utter his own name in a very short time, the lodgers will give him one.
column883: Brown had a large nose, and would most certainly have been named "Nosey," had he not on the first day recorded a simple anecdote of his childhood, in which he had cause to call himself William Brown.
column884: I remember the day well, when the "Dodger"--a man who gladly helped others to spend their earnings on ale and, when they sat penniless and hungry, sat himself down alone to beefsteak and onions--I remember the day well when this man caused a never-to-be-forgotten sensation in the lodging-house kitchen.
column885: A letter was at the office for Algernon Dudley, and the manager had been in the kitchen several times in quest of that gentleman.
column886: It was near seven o'clock in the evening when he came into the kitchen for the fifth time and cried--"Is Algernon Dudley here?"
column887: "Yes," answered a man in the corner, and coming quickly forward.
column888: All eyes turned towards him, and who do you think Algernon Dudley was?
column890: "Fatty," who claimed to be a fighting man, whom no man had ever succeeded in knocking down, said, in conversation to Brown, "You could have knocked me down with a feather."
column891: Brown's remarks on this occasion were very sensible, as they usually were.
column892: "It was, is, and always will be the custom," said he, "for a woman that gives birth to a child to name it.
column893: For this reason she is no sooner on the trot again than she begins scheming to that end.
column894: Now," continued Brown, "we must not picture the 'Dodger' as he is--God help him!--but as he was, a child in the arms of a doting woman.
column895: Such was the case, and has been the same with others, including ourselves, and will always be.
column896: Now this poor woman--some people would call her foolish--no doubt had great respect for the 'Dodger' as a babe and, to distinguish him from the common race of mankind, named him in such a manner as we have just heard.
column897: Perhaps I am right, perhaps I am wrong; but if the true facts of the case were known, you would probably find that I was not far from the truth.
column898: In spite of all this, I quite agree with our friend's remark, that it fills us with astonishment."
column899: The "Dodger" had lived in the house for more than two years, when this incident caused so many comments.
column900: But let us return to the man "Cinders," for that gentleman was no helpless wreck in a doss-house; he was really a gay spirit and capable of love.
column901: He was a man with a long, melancholy face, seeing no humour in life and, if the truth must be told, he was positively ugly.
column902: Yet this man "Cinders" had been seen on several occasions walking the streets with a woman on his arm.
column903: One of the lodgers said her looks were passable, and another said that they were more than passable compared to "Cinders."
column904: Brown had seen them together and, said he, "Although a man ought to believe his own eyes, I would never believe such to be the case, had not 'Cinders' said, 'Good night, Mr.
column906: And if a man is not to believe both eyes and ears, then what is he to believe?"
column907: Of course, there could be no union between these poor souls; for she was in service, and he did odd jobs at the market, earning a shilling, or a little more on lucky days.
column908: As the manager said, it was amusing and could not amount to anything serious.
column909: They could go on walking arm in arm all their lives, for they would never be able to marry and walk apart.
column910: This courtship had been the talk of the house for over three months when, one night, it was brought to an end in a strange manner.
column911: "Cinders" and his love had been all the evening in the "Borough" drinking ale.
column912: He, seeing some smoked haddock, fancied some for his supper and, after making a purchase, rejoined his fair companion.
column913: It was near midnight when it suddenly occurred to "Cinders" that the manager closed the house at twelve p.m., and if he--"Cinders"--was not there by that time, he would be out for the night.
column914: Reminding his lady of this, they both started for home, her road lying the same way as his.
column915: The manager was just closing the door when "Cinders" arrived.
column916: Now, goodness knows what demon put it into this woman's head to cook her lover's fish, but this she seemed determined to do.
column917: "I am coming in to cook your supper," said she.
column918: "No," said the manager, "this is a house for men only, and we do not allow women to enter.
column919: Not only that, the kitchen is now closed, and I would not open it again for 'Cinders' or any other man.
column920: He will have to go supperless to bed, or seek lodgings elsewhere."
column921: The lady then started to abuse the manager in a loud voice, but that gentleman, not heeding her, caught "Cinders" by the shoulders, saying, "Go to bed, you old fool," at the same time shutting the door in the lady's face.
column922: The next morning, when "Cinders" was cooking his haddock, the manager lectured him severely on what had occurred the previous night; telling him that if he could afford to keep a lady cook he must seek better lodgings.
column923: Brown, who happened to be within hearing, gave evidence that he distinctly heard a woman's voice say, "I am going to cook his fish," but thought he must be dreaming.
column924: Even now he believed it was all a dream, and he would like to hear the truth from the manager's own lips, as to whether it was an actual fact or not.
column925: On being told that it was, Brown turned his eyes towards "Cinders" and, seeing that gentleman hold down his head in wordless shame, Brown was forced to believe it all.
column926: Probably that was the end of their courtship, for they were never seen together after that.
column927: XXIII The Handy Man The handy man is to be found in all places where men are either too poor to pay for professional experience, or, not being so poor, yet live in out-of-the-way camps which women have never visited, and which are too temporary for tradesmen to open business.
column928: The former places are common lodging-houses, where the handy man volunteers his services as laundryman, cook, tailor, cobbler, barber, etc.
column929: In fact, according to his boasted qualifications, it would be far more interesting to learn what he cannot do than what he can.
column930: He has learnt all these trades with his eye, and, when about to practise, his confidence is unshaken.
column931: Says he, "I will shave you, and you will not feel the razor going over your face."
column932: And when he covers your face with blood he blames pimples, which you never had, and expects to be thanked for removing them; for in addition to shaving you, has he not also performed a successful surgical operation?
column933: In this manner he earns a shilling or more a day, and he is not agreeable that any man should shave himself, sew or wash clothes; or he would not earn the price of his bed and board, and gifts of ale and tobacco.
column934: If he sees me preparing to shave, he makes a rush and possesses himself of the razor, and commands me to be seated.
column935: There is nothing else to do but obey, for he takes me by the shoulder and leads me to a seat; he then forces me down and pushes my head back until it is within an inch of the nape of my neck.
column936: For this indignity I give him a penny, and then, while I am washing, he shouts in a loud voice--"Next."
column937: He never thinks that I would object to my soap, brush, and razor being used on other faces; and truly it is for that reason--and not economy--that I shave myself.
column938: But thank goodness the kitchen is almost empty, and there is no answer to his "Next."
column939: Then, with an eye to future custom, he carefully wipes the razor, dries it on his clothes, washes the brush, rolls the soap in a piece of clean paper, and returns them to the owner.
column940: After which he again borrows the razor, for he has seen a hair on the throat, and, as he says--"A good craftsman likes to make a neat job."
column941: He then laments the number of pimples that had to be removed, and wanders in quest of other jobs.
column942: Probably he now sees a man in the act of repairing a boot.
column943: If he does, he rushes in that direction, wrestles with the man for the boot, and is soon heard hammering with all his might.
column944: He makes so much noise that any man would think him a man of confidence and great practice.
column945: Of course he blames the tools for every mistake, and says modestly that no man living could do better under such conditions.
column946: For rendering this assistance he receives two or more coppers.
column947: And now he sees a man whose eyesight is bad endeavouring to thread a needle.
column948: "Allow me," cries the handy man, springing forward, and wrestling with the other for the needle and thread.
column949: Getting possession of these, in spite of the other's loud-spoken annoyance, he, instead of returning them, demands the article to be sewn.
column950: "No, thank you," says the other; "I can manage it myself."
column951: With much reluctance the handy man surrenders, and begs a pipeful of tobacco for threading the needle.
column952: But he still keeps his eye on the other, and when he sees him take up a shirt and a patch, the handy man again springs forward and in a loud voice commands the other to halt.
column953: "I," says he, "have a piece of stuff that exactly matches your shirt, whereas yours is far different."
column954: Snatching the shirt from the other's hand, he disappears for a moment, and then reappears with a piece of stuff that, it must be admitted, is a better match.
column955: The other, being well pleased at this, says: "If you don't mind waiting we will have a drink after I have done this job."
column956: The handy man, hearing this, and not feeling inclined to wait long, also thinking that an additional kindness would meet its reward in an additional drink, answers: "You had better let me do it, for by the way you hold the needle it is plain that you are not used to such work."
column957: The other, seeing that he has already given tobacco, and is compromised for a drink, is now quite willing to have the handy man's assistance.
column958: "Now," says he, when the job is done, where every stitch is seen to lie in its own deep valley surrounded by hills--"Now," says he, "all it requires is to be pressed with a hot flat-iron, after which you need not be ashamed to show it to the best tailor in the land.
column959: If you like, we will use the interval, while the iron is in the fire, for refreshment."
column960: The handy man, though he often spoils good things which, with a little professional care, might be made almost as good as new, is not to be altogether despised.
column961: Though he is not the handy man of his claim, he certainly deserves credit for keeping handy tools.
column962: Wherever he finds discarded boots or clothes, he cuts patches and saves them for emergency.
column963: He always keeps a pair of scissors, a razor, strap, brush, pincers, and many other useful things, and he is seldom short of nails.
column964: But to one who is determined to do without his services, he is often a very unpleasant spectator.
column965: For instance, if I am shaving the handy man stands two feet away, glaring like a discomforted demon; and when I stand before the glass, and the razor is on my face, he stands behind my back, so that to my confusion and danger two faces are reflected.
column966: If he sees a man who has persistently declined his aid, and who is in the act of sewing, the handy man either stands in the light, or stands seemingly counting the stitches, critically watching, until the man must either prick his finger or spoil his work.
column967: When he sees a man repairing a boot he says sarcastically: "Take care you strike the right nail."
column968: The other laughs, but proves his confusion when the next instant he strikes off the nail of his left-hand thumb.
column969: The handy man even prescribes for the sick, but in nine cases out of ten his cure is an intoxicant, the time being immaterial.
column970: I allowed him to cut my hair, and he seemed well pleased at the result; but after one glance in the glass, I decided not to remove my cap for three weeks, whether at meals or not.
column971: Perhaps nothing worse could befall a house than to have two rival handy men.
column972: I was at one place where a man claimed to have given satisfaction for a number of years.
column973: He was certainly liked, for even those who scorned his talents could not resist his ways as a cadger of tea, sugar, tobacco, and other things.
column975: his fatal day came when a man, who was receiving a good pension, took lodgings at the same house, and, wanting something to occupy his mind, began shaving, cutting hair, and mending boots free of charge.
column976: "Look here," said the old handy man to the new one--"Look here, before you came I could always pay for my bed, tobacco, not to mention a glass or two of ale; but your coming here has spoilt all that."
column977: "Well," answered the good-natured pensioner, "you are one of the biggest and strongest men in the house, and why don't you look for a man's labour, instead of loafing about for a woman's work--sewing and washing clothes?
column978: I am not taking pennies from poor fellows old or broken in health who as paper-men, toy-sellers, and sandwichmen, barely earn enough for their own wants."
column979: Not many days after this the big, healthy schemer had to walk out for his living, and had heavy tasks put before him, which he was well able to perform.
column980: Then the poor lodgers had peace to do their own washing and mending, while the good-natured pensioner attended to their boots, beard, and hair.
column981: XXIV On Books I have never had much chance to enjoy books.
column982: Even after writing four books, which were regarded as literary successes, my library consisted of only about fifty volumes, some of which were magazines, and not worth a second reading.
column983: This being so, it is hardly likely that I can ever forgive this world for keeping me without books when my enthusiasm was great, for I don't want them now.
column984: I have often envied the thousands of rich people that have well-stocked libraries and no desire to use them.
column985: When my enthusiasm was greatest I was not able to enjoy books owing to the circumstances under which they had to be read.
column986: For instance, when I lived in a common lodging-house, preferring freedom on a small income to drudgery on a large one, I had plenty of time to visit free libraries.
column987: At those places I could, by signing my name and address, borrow any book mentioned in the catalogue, and read it on the premises.
column988: I often wish I now had some of the books I read at that time and could not enjoy.
column989: The reason I could not enjoy them at that time was owing to several causes, which were strong enemies against enthusiasm.
column990: In the first place, I had to give a false address, because the name of a lodging-house was not respectable, and condemned me as unclean.
column991: Owing to this I could never feel comfortable, for if I happened to look up from my book and saw the librarian looking my way, I always thought that he was weighing in his mind what manner of man I was.
column992: Sometimes a librarian would stare at me so boldly that I lost no time in returning the book, and leaving the place, thinking that he would soon come forward and tell me to do so.
column993: Of course, I was very suspicious, under those circumstances, but have often thought since that those men were not thinking of me at all, but were lost in their own business, and did not know what their eyes were doing.
column994: Another reason why I could not enjoy books then was owing to a low and insufficient diet, which kept my blood too cold to sit long in a room where the windows were often wide open.
column995: The consequence was that I often returned a very interesting book after an hour's reading, so as to take a walk and get warm; a book which would, if I had a cosy little room of my own, be read through at one sitting, though it took far into the night.
column996: And when summer came, I wanted to read in the open air, but had no friends to recommend me as a book-borrower.
column997: For that reason I could not borrow books to take away and read at my leisure, and in whatever place I liked.
column998: Since those days, and now that I have made one or two friends, I have other reasons to spoil my enjoyment of books.
column999: I cannot now read with enjoyment books that are borrowed or are likely to be wanted back.
column1000: Such books are never any good to me, for, if I enjoy them, I am robbed of that joy by the thought that they are not mine.
column1001: I want to see the books around me as my own property, else the sight of them grieves me.
column1002: My own books are kept on a shelf, and I look on them as pure thoroughbred; but I keep apart all borrowed books, treating them as wandering mongrels to whom I have given a temporary home, and am as anxious to drive away as I was to receive them in the beginning.
column1003: For this reason I would not now take advantage of a library, even if it were next door.
column1004: Unfortunately, in the country a book lover has to be well off, for he can only buy new books; whereas in London, and other large cities, a man can take, from stalls of second-hand books, an armful of classics for the price of a moderate meal.
column1005: And that leads me to another thought--I do not care for the look of new books, much preferring them to have lost their last coat of polish.
column1006: Somehow it hurts my conscience to see a dear old author shining before me in gold and spotless green or red.
column1007: I seem to hear his voice say: "You scorned my coming in years past, and left me for these late and colder days."
column1008: There is not much excuse for a man living in London not having a good stock of books.
column1009: I have seen Shakespeare for fourpence, and Milton for half that price.
column1010: At this rate a man could in a few months have a large stock of good books, and the outlay would not be much.
column1011: If I had been living in London during these last two years, my books would now run into several hundreds, and I would not have spent five pounds.
column1012: Perhaps one of the best week's enjoyment I have ever had was in the free library at Reading, in spite of the conditions under which I then lived.
column1013: I had left London three months before, and had been wandering about the country, and had not read a book or magazine during all that time.
column1014: At this time I was aching with all my heart for reading matter, dreaming of books day and night.
column1015: Now it happened that I had been in that town two months before, and on that occasion had been in the library long enough to see that it was very comfortable and had a good stock of papers and magazines.
column1016: For, being a large town, that library was really free, without any signs relating to tramps--as I had seen in smaller towns--silence only being requested.
column1017: Unfortunately, the town's trade was very bad at this time, and for that reason it would take me all day to sell enough laces to keep me, and I would have no spare time for the library.
column1018: So I left Reading, with much regret, but determined to return if I could make a few shillings to keep me idle for several days.
column1019: One Friday night I happened to be at Windsor and heard a couple of beggars in the lodging-house speaking in good terms of Slough, a mile and a half away.
column1020: So, the next morning, being Saturday, I left Windsor and started for Slough.
column1021: When I reached that town, I began to knock at doors without wasting any time, although it was quite early in the day, for some of the better-class people had not yet cleared away their breakfast things.
column1022: I certainly had extraordinary luck, for I took a shilling before dinner and, of course, the town would be much better after that, because of the men having come home with their pay.
column1023: To understand my good fortune people must know that Saturday morning is the worst time in the week for a beggar.
column1024: It is so bad that nine beggars out of ten attempt no business whatever until after dinner, so as not to spoil themselves by being refused at good houses that would gladly assist them later in the day.
column1025: It is really surprising the number of poor people there are who have spent the last penny in the house on a Saturday morning before dinner.
column1026: When I thought of this it suddenly occurred to me that Reading library was not far away.
column1027: No sooner had this idea occurred to me than I made up my mind to keep calling at houses until I had four shillings.
column1028: It was getting dark, and must have been about five o'clock, when I stopped and counted a pocketful of pennies.
column1029: First of all I counted my laces, and found that I had sold a dozen pairs, which had cost me threepence.
column1030: But so many people had given pennies for nothing that I was not at all surprised to find that I had four shillings and tenpence, although one lady had insisted on having two pairs for three-halfpence.
column1031: In addition to this money I had food enough given me for tea that night and breakfast the following morning.
column1032: I was quite delighted at this and started at once for Maidenhead, four miles away.
column1033: On the road there I sold three pairs of laces to men going home from work, and also had threepence given me by a gentleman taking a walk, which was unsolicited.
column1034: So that I now had five shillings and fourpence, a clear five shillings after paying for my bed at Maidenhead.
column1035: The next day, being Sunday, I walked with a light heart into Reading, with five shillings in my pocket.
column1036: That small amount kept me for six days, and I never did, and never will again, have so much enjoyment out of reading matter.
column1037: Of course, what increased my pleasure was the thought that I was letting a small income accumulate, so as to publish a book of my own; the manuscript was in my pocket then, and in two more months I would be an author.
column1038: XXV Narks A man cannot be a very long time on the road before he understands the meaning of the word "narks."
column1039: Beggars may forgive dirty beds, vermin, broken crockery and bad fires, but to tell them that a lodging-house is full of "narks" is the worst information that can be conveyed to them.
column1040: When I enquired of a beggar as to the comfort of the lodging-house in the town to which I was going, he said: "Well, mate, the bed is good, and a good fire is kept, but to tell you the truth the house is spoilt by 'narks.'"
column1041: As I was not an old traveller in England, I did not understand him, but thought I would find out for myself what a "nark" really was.
column1042: After I had reached the town, and paid the lodging-house keeper for my bed, I entered the lodgers' kitchen, and there saw three men seated before a good fire.
column1043: Of my cheerful "Good afternoon," they took not the least notice, neither did they offer to make room for a stranger coming in out of the cold.
column1044: I could see at once by this that they were not true beggars and travellers, who are always eager to make room for their fellows.
column1045: I may as well say at once that these three men were "narks."
column1046: In other words, they were town beggars; men that had lost their homes and had to take refuge in a common lodging-house; or, if they did not belong to the town, they had been there long enough to be known.
column1047: The "nark" is either a cattle-drover, a small hawker, a mechanic that only has a couple of days' work a week, or a man that earns a few pennies by doing odd jobs for people that know him.
column1048: Sometimes he is a man with a very small pension or income, and does nothing.
column1049: Although the lodging-house keeper often abuses him, and threatens to cast him adrift, for all that he is allowed privileges which the casual wandering tramp cannot like.
column1050: All true wanderers hate him; even the drunken, domineering grinder is treated with civility in a house where beggars see a "nark."
column1051: That the "nark," with his mean tricks, is a nuisance to wandering beggars is seen in a very short time.
column1052: For instance, he takes the utensils, which are meant for the common use of the kitchen, and after using them will hide them away for his own future use; so that strangers have often to make tea in a pot without a spout, and look in vain for a saucer or a small saucepan.
column1053: He also monopolizes the fire with newly-washed clothes, and hungry strangers find great difficulty in cooking their food.
column1054: He will not oblige by removing these things until the evening, when there would be less demand for the fire.
column1055: Again, he wants a certain place at the table to sit and eat his food, and he often frowns at innocent strangers who are enjoying their meal in his accustomed seat.
column1056: He is often mean enough to allow his things to remain on the table after he has done, in readiness for the next meal--instead of clearing them away and making room for hungry new-comers.
column1057: The worst charge to make against a "nark" is that he is a spy and a tell-tale, and that he lets the lodging-house keeper know all the transactions of the kitchen.
column1058: When lodgers are told the next morning that they cannot have a bed at that house for another night, and cannot get to know the reason why, they come to the conclusion that they have been reported by a "nark" for complaining about a bad fire, insufficiency of bed-clothes, teapots, saucers, or cups.
column1059: Most deputies in lodging-houses were in the first place "narks."
column1060: Sometimes a "nark" fails, in spite of being well known in the town, to earn the price of his bed, or to borrow it, and returns to the lodging-house for trust.
column1061: After that he shows his gratitude by sweeping the kitchen, or washing plates and tea-things, which the lodging-house keeper had to do himself.
column1062: The latter, seeing this, asks him to do other things, and of course gives him bed and board, and a shilling at the end of the week.
column1063: He no longer goes out as a drover, or seeking odd jobs, but sweeps, washes, scrubs, makes beds, etc.
column1064: Taking everything into consideration the work is not so unremunerative as it appears, for every man in the house solicits his friendship.
column1065: From morning till night he is offered saucers-full of tea from the many lodgers.
column1066: In fact, he is often at his wits' end to know how to spend his very small wages, for the lodgers supply him with tobacco, beer, and even clothes and boots.
column1067: He gets so many presents every week that he makes money by selling them.
column1068: As may be expected, it is from the "narks" that he reaps the most profit; for they never fail to share with him their titbits and give him the price of beer, which makes him favour that class, and prejudiced against casual lodgers.
column1069: Unfortunately the deputy has great power, against which there is no appeal.
column1070: He will allow a "nark" to cook on the fire until it is nearly out; but when he sees a stranger cooking he will interfere, saying that the fire must be attended to.
column1071: After which he will put on so much coke that the poor stranger is delayed an hour or more in doing what he has perhaps half done.
column1072: He has to put on one side a herring half cooked, or a singing kettle, until the fire burns.
column1073: It is a good policy for strangers, as soon as they enter a lodging-house kitchen, to not only speak pleasantly to the deputy, but to slip a penny into his hand, so that they may be installed on an equal footing with "narks."
column1074: Men that do not think of doing this must not be surprised if he "accidentally" overturns their teapots, or shovels coke into their frying-pans.
column1075: These little accidents always add to the gaiety of "narks," and they the more generously reward the deputy for affording them this extra entertainment.
column1076: I was in one lodging-house in the provinces that only had accommodation for twelve lodgers, and in that house were six "narks" and the deputy.
column1077: The night I was there, there were only three strangers, myself and two others, and we were almost afraid to move.
column1078: One "nark" was a rag-and-bone man, who worked the country for miles around.
column1079: While I was eating my frugal supper, he spread on the table his dirty rags and bones--so near that one bone was found on my plate, which I returned to him--with many thanks.
column1080: Seeing that the deputy appeared quite satisfied, I dared not say much, for if I got into trouble and had my money returned, there was not another lodging-house within six miles.
column1081: Another "nark" was a drunken drover, who left a saucepan on the fire while he went out for a drink.
column1082: When he returned he said that there were only four potatoes and a half in the saucepan, whereas he had put in five.
column1083: It never occurred to his suspicious mind that one potato had become small in the extra boiling, and we three strangers had to tolerate his savage looks.
column1084: Another "nark" was a blacksmith, who was out of work.
column1085: This man was lying drunk at full length on a bench, so that the two strangers had to wait until I had finished my meal before they could get a seat at the table, for, with the exception of the drover, all the other "narks" had had their supper.
column1086: The blacksmith had not paid his rent for two or three nights, and the landlady--a very old woman--had ordered the deputy not to allow him to go to bed.
column1087: While I was asleep that night, I was suddenly awaked by a slap on the face, and a croaking voice, which said--"Out of my house, blacksmith."
column1088: When I opened my eyes, I saw an old withered face bending over mine--there must have been a hundred years in that face.
column1089: "I am not the blacksmith," I said feebly.
column1090: "Liar," she shrieked, holding the candle near my face.
column1091: However, she saw her mistake, and went away muttering, without making any apology for her mistake.
column1092: No stranger would ever think of staying two nights in a house like that.
column1093: Of course, in a house where there is only one "nark," he tries to ingratiate himself with casual men, for the sake of social company, but they do not encourage his advances, knowing how careful they must be of what they say.
column1094: They are suspicious of him, in spite of his good-natured offers to oblige them with a shake of pepper.
column1095: By the way, the sight of a pepper-box in a lodging-house kitchen is always a sure sign that the man behind it is a "nark."
column1096: Wanderers, however much trouble they take to carry tea, salt, soap, thread, needle, comb, and many other little things which must not interfere with space for food--would never think of carrying a pepper-box, though they may carry a little pepper in paper.
column1097: No, a "nark" is not a desirable companion, and to inform a tramp that he is going to a house that is full of them, is to daunt him more than to say that the teapots are spoutless and cracked, the saucers have no rims, the beds are dirty, and that the fire is small and often out.
column1098: XXVI The Scribe in a Lodging-house A man who is seen writing in a common lodging-house will soon have his services sought so often that he must be offended, however kind-hearted he may be.
column1099: He will be pestered by illiterate seekers of work, and even begging-letter impostors.
column1100: In the latter case the men are cunning enough to invent pitiful tales, but they lack the education to write them.
column1101: Many a man who has only lived a short time in a lodging-house, and is innocent of the world, has written letters for these rogues, and not known what he was doing.
column1102: Strange to say, very few of these men are able to write their own letters; and, seeing that they usually pose for men that have lost good positions, it is not to be wondered at when they have no courage to face a personal interview.
