column1615: The lady also enclosed a list of fifty or sixty names of those who had obliged her, beginning with the head of the State.
column1616: That, I said to my Uncle T----, is what they call fame in England.
column1617: Now let us compare it to begging in America.
column1618: If I had been in that country, I could have begged a clean shirt in less time than it took to wash one, and no person there would have offered me such a ragged one.
column1619: Again, as a beggar in America I have sat down to meals consisting of turkey, sweet potatoes, mince pie, and bananas; but as a famous man in England----"I know," interrupted my Uncle T----, whose intentions had been to beg me, and whose hopes now vanished--"I know," said he, "you have to put up with anything; but why?
column1620: Why don't you return to begging?"
column1621: Not getting an answer to this, my Uncle T---- looked considerably perplexed for the time, but at last his face brightened, and he said: "Well, lad, if you are determined on the writing business, why don't you, in the name of goodness, go in for limericks?"
column1622: XXXV The Supper I had been thinking all day of my strange companions of the past, both in America and England, and that accounted for my dream at night.
column1623: In that dream I had invited them all to a grand supper, for I was now leading a different life.
column1624: I was seated at the end of the table, which was full of fine things, and Brum, of America--the greatest beggar I had ever met--was seated at my right hand.
column1625: After making them a short speech, in which I commended them on their way of living, and expressed deep regret that I had ever been cheated to follow Fame, who had led me into a treacherous swamp in which I stood up to the knees, with little power to either return or advance--after making this short speech, I invited them to help themselves, and to receive my undying friendship.
column1626: They then began to assist themselves with a hearty goodwill, all except Brum, who, to my surprise and confusion, sat motionless, glancing with scorn at his companions.
column1627: "There," said he, with deep disgust; "do you call these men good beggars?
column1628: See the way they rush at the food, as though they had starved themselves all day in anticipation of this meal."
column1629: Saying this, he began slowly to feel the lining of his coat, and, after much trouble, took out a greasy paper parcel, placed it on his knees and began to make room for it on the table.
column1630: This being done, he spread the contents before him and began to eat in a very slow and indifferent manner.
column1631: As for myself, I could not eat for joy, to see all these dear faces before me, and sat smiling at one and another, laughing and sighing in turns.
column1632: Sometimes I closed my eyes, and opened them again on my companions, endeared to me by a past that had few cares and worries.
column1633: By a strange coincidence, Irish Tim of London was paired with Oaklahoma Sam of America.
column1634: Now the latter was a man of very few words, and he always had in hand a long dangerous-looking knife, with which he trimmed his nails, whittled sticks, or threw at cracks in the door, flies, or any other object that caught his eye.
column1635: But he never allowed that knife to remain long out of his hand, for, if he threw it at a door nine feet away, he was sure to recover it at one leap, and ere it had finished trembling in the wood.
column1636: When I have seen him asleep at the cattleman's office, he always had this knife between his teeth.
column1637: As I have said, Sam was a man of few words, but on the subject of war he was more talkative than an old man.
column1638: His memory on that one subject was extraordinary; knowing the dates of battles, the number of their forces, names of generals and regiments, and the exact position of their entrenchments.
column1639: Tim must have unwittingly broached this subject, for I was suddenly startled by hearing Oaklahoma Sam say, "This is Napoleon"; at the same time down went his knife over half an inch into the table.
column1640: I had noticed from the first that Sam had scornfully pushed aside my table knife, preferring to use his own, although he had retained the use of my fork.
column1641: Looking at once in that direction, I saw Tim's face turned my way, with sarcasm trembling on his lips, which only needed a little encouragement, and he would then utter one of his scathing sentences, thinking to blight at once the newly-opened flower of Sam's eloquence.
column1642: "Don't look that way, look at me," cried the man from Oaklahoma, placing his left hand on Tim's shoulder, and speaking in a voice terribly quiet and firm.
column1643: "I see," answered Tim, leaning back, with his two hands resting on the table--"I see; this is Napoleon."
column1644: "Yes, and this is Blucher," continued Sam, taking the knife out of the table, and quickly planting it dangerously near to Tim's right hand.
column1645: "And this," cried Sam, forcing his words between his teeth, and holding the knife suspended in the air, "is Wellington," and down it flashed between the two big fingers of Tim's left hand.
column1646: Tim grew much paler as he removed that hand to his knee, and it was at once apparent to me that for the rest of the evening he was a spell-bound man, afraid to hazard even a civil question, for fear it would be misunderstood.
column1647: Next to Sam and Tim sat Chicago Slim, who was relating to Bony--an English beggar--his awful suffering for a week in the State of Utah, where a beggar had no other food than bread and milk confronting him on every threshold he approached, and how travelling in that part was known to all beggars as "the bread-and-milk route."
column1648: Such were his awful sufferings, related to the sympathetic ears of Bony, who, in exchange, mentioned his own disappointments in England, "where," said he, "I find public-houses to be the easiest, quickest, and most profitable places."
column1649: He was just about to cite instances when the Curly Kid, who had been listening to their conversation, asked Chicago Slim this question: "How is it that, when I was in Utah, the citizens did not baby _me_ with bread and milk?"
column1650: "Don't know," answered Slim, disconcerted not a little.
column1651: "I went to no houses, but begged on the fly, and people had to give money or nothing.
column1652: Slim, I reckon no true beggar would allow himself to be fed day after day on bread and milk."
column1653: Chicago Slim did not answer, and at once fell in the estimation of Bony, who now considered him to be unworthy of further attention.
column1654: "I shall never forget," said Bony to the Curly Kid, who had by his remarks proved himself to be a beggar equal to any emergency--"I shall never forget my disgust when, one Sunday morning, I found myself accidentally in a town where public-houses are shut on the Sabbath day.
column1655: I had to beg of proud, neatly-dressed church-goers, for the good-natured drinking man had not the heart to come out of doors, and you can imagine my ill success.
column1656: How I wished all these people who were carrying Bibles and Prayer-books had bottles and jugs instead!"
column1657: How the hours passed, looking on these delightful companions!
column1658: The first to leave was Tim, for Oaklahoma Sam had become personal about his rough beard, and wanted to shave him, there and then, with his knife; and, in fact, was sharpening it on a stone for that purpose, which I had often seen him do before.
column1659: Tim civilly but firmly refused this kindness at Sam's hands, and, being afraid that he might be forced to undergo such an operation, got up, and saying "Good night, all," left the room.
column1660: Others followed, one by one, and two by two, until at last I was left alone with Brum.

column1663: "Here," said I, walking up the room, and looking affectionately at an empty chair--"here sat Wee Scotty; here sat Monkey Jim, and there sat Never Sweat; here sat Rags, and there sat Cinders; here sat Tim, and there sat Oaklahoma Sam."
column1664: Indeed, there could be no mistake as to where Sam sat, for he had used his knife to such purpose, in describing the position of Napoleon, Blucher, and Wellington, and their rapid movements in the heat of battle, that the table-cloth was all in rags, and that part of the table was in splinters for nearly two feet square.
column1665: I stood undecided, for I had tasted their life, and I knew that it was after all far better than the chained life I was now leading.
column1666: In an instant I made up my mind to follow Brum, and again enjoy the open-air camp fires, and saunterings in strange towns, and lying under shady trees in quiet woods, beside fresh springs.
column1667: But I had scarcely moved when the room turned into a stone cell, and the wooden door became steel, and thick iron bars crossed the window.
column1668: It must have been the strong feeling, incident to such a change, that made me wake.
column1669: I found myself sleeping alone in a small, poorly-furnished cottage, a stranger newly arrived in a strange village; and I had to admit, as a man in possession of all his senses, that I had far less cause to be happy than when I was a nameless wanderer with Brum in Louisiana, with Australian Red in Michigan, or cabined with Wee Scotty and Oaklahoma Sam on the cattleship _Tritonia_.
column1670: XXXVI The Literary Life One day, when I was small, my grandmother called me to her knee, and asked me if I knew where the White House was.
column1671: No doubt I did, for I not only knew the town well, being a truant, but the green country for many a mile around.
column1672: However, I did not know the house by name, and shook my head, at the same time looking at her with some anxiety, thinking that the White House was a place to whitewash the souls of wicked boys.
column1673: Then she began to describe its beautiful situation, its numerous windows, the long drive through trees and the acres of green land that surrounded it.
column1676: It stood a long way back off a main road, and we truants often passed it.
column1677: And we knew the apple orchard which belonged to that house, but was a long way from it; and it was less than a week before my grandmother asked this question, that I and a boy called "Trousers" had trespassed on the land, and filled our pockets and open shirts with red apples.
column1678: So, when she continued talking about this house, I became a great deal confused, thinking that someone had been to her making enquiries of me; and I only had one thought to console me--"Trousers" was guilty also.
column1679: My relief can be imagined when I found that such was not the case, but that my grandmother was thinking of her own days of childhood and, having no one else near, could not contain herself, but must make a confidant of a thoughtless boy, or--to use her own words--"a little black and a rodney."
column1680: She was looking at the child that was dead in her, and could not feel me tremble at her knee, nor see my colour come and go.
column1681: However, when I began to see that she knew nothing of my doings, and began to speak of her own childhood, I gradually became interested.
column1682: The White House, it seemed, had once belonged to a relative, and my grandmother had lived there for several months as a little girl.
column1683: Now, my grandmother was an only child, and that she was allowed out of her mother's care for several months seemed strange.
column1684: Perhaps it was owing to domestic strife.
column1685: Her mother had married a worthless fellow who had at last drunk himself to death.
column1686: So, I suppose she sent her only child away while she took steps to get rid of him and make a comfortable home of her own.
column1687: Having a little property, and being a woman of great spirit, she ordered him out of the house and dared him to enter again.
column1688: After which she started a small private school and, having the rent of four little houses, lived happy with her only child.
column1689: No doubt she had come of good birth and was well educated.
column1690: It was much against her wish that her daughter married my grandfather, in spite of his being captain of his own vessel--because of his want of education.
column1691: Nevertheless, she lived to see her daughter married to an honest and affectionate man, even though his grammar was bad, and his roaring voice was not ashamed of it.
column1692: However, what interested me now was to hear from my grandmother that the lady at the White House had not only been very beautiful, but had been clever enough to write a book.
column1693: As to her looks, my grandmother said that she and her husband made such a fine pair that even people that met them often turned and looked after them.
column1694: They were both very tall, he being six feet three inches, and she being six feet; and they looked so stately that people made their admiration heard.
column1695: My grandmother said that they were so fond of each other that they always walked arm-in-arm, as when lovers; and for this reason they were admired by those who would otherwise have frowned on their rich clothes and proud grace.
column1696: But one day, when they had returned from riding, he, in assisting her from her horse, squeezed her breast, and this accident somehow caused her death.
column1697: Such was my grandmother's account of former occupants of the White House.
column1698: When I told these things to "Trousers," saying that we ought not to have robbed that orchard, he claimed that we had a right to the apples, because my grandmother used to live there.
column1699: It was a great consolation to hear this, but still, I claimed the only right, and trusted that he would not lead others there on the sly.
column1700: But what I mean to say is this--the wonderful effect it had on me, young as I was, to hear that a relative of mine, however distant, had written a book!
column1701: My feelings will be understood by all those who remember what books were to them as children.
column1702: To children books do not reach millions, nor thousands; and when they have a book they think it is the first and last copy, and never dream that there are thousands more.
column1703: It would be very hard to describe a child's opinion of a book, but there are thousands of grown people who are as innocent of the business side of literature, and who are still children in their knowledge of books.
column1704: In fact, speaking of my own experience, I did not know until three or four years ago but what books must be published on their merit, and could not be published otherwise.
column1705: I did not know, what I know so well now, that any person with money can publish a book, and that merit has little to do with it before publication, however much it may assist it after.
column1706: Even now, speaking as the author of five books, I am still being surprised at the business side of literature.
column1707: I find that books are pleasant things to brood on in an egg state, but that they are no sooner hatched and begin to move than they fill one with disgust and disappointment; and the author feels like the hen that without knowing hatched a brood of ducklings and, to her disgust, saw them run into the water.
column1708: Even in those early days I had made up my mind to write a book, so that it can be imagined what a sacred place the White House became to me.
column1709: Day after day I thought of the lovely tall lady; and it was not her height, grace, or beauty, nor her wealth and social position that were uppermost in my thoughts--but that she had written a book!
column1710: Time and again I asked my grandmother the name of it, but she could not tell.
column1711: Of course I was too young to think of enquiring the author's name, and going to libraries, and trying to trace it that way.
column1712: Very few grown people would have had sense enough for that.
column1713: Thinking of these things has led me to the contrast of literature as it seems to the young, and what it really is to a man of experience.
column1714: You could never persuade a young man--and very few old men--that he could be one of the best writers of the day and yet starve, had he not the assistance of private means.
column1715: "True," people say, "men of genius have starved, but the fault was that they were not recognized in their day."
column1716: But the real truth is that a man may be so much recognized that the world's praise of his work would make a very large book indeed, and yet he may not have a second shirt to his back.
column1717: It would be impossible to make people believe that a man could be so famous as to be invited to the houses of the great and yet be so shabby in appearance that beggars meet him on the road and, taking him for one of themselves, say, "Hallo!
column1719: And that when he did meet people of consequence, he had to sneak into back slums at night and sleep in a common lodging-house.
column1720: People could not be made to believe any of these things while a man lives, but after he is dead they will believe anything.
column1721: XXXVII The Sport of Fame People have professed themselves amazed at my past life, and perhaps I can amaze them a little more by relating what great sport I and Fame have had; how she coaxed me into making several attempts to enrich the English language--some people think the attempts successful--and how she served me afterwards.
column1722: Other people can be amazed at my past life, but my turn to be amazed comes now.
column1723: The world has had its revenge for the few years I made it keep me as an idler.
column1724: In fact I have found Fame to be the most amusing companion I have ever had.
column1725: She has placed me in such a position that I am now regarded as a liar, a miser, and a woman-hater.
column1726: I am considered to be a liar by those who have read so much about my work, and who at last begin to doubt when I say that Fame in England does not pay so good as begging in America, and that a very small income of my own supports me.
column1727: They cannot believe this to be possible after reading such noble accounts of my work--therefore I am a liar.
column1728: Again, I am regarded in the neighbourhood as a miser and a woman-hater because I do my own cooking, washing, and housework, when there are plenty of women around that would be glad of such work.
column1729: Of course, these things are not done thoroughly and well, or I would have very little time to make attempts to enrich the English language.
column1730: The truth of the matter is that they are so ill done, that I have had to write and stop several people from coming to interview me, because of spiders that often rope me to the ceiling, Jacky Longlegs that dance on my head, and--fleas.
column1731: I am quite used to these things now, and take little notice of them, regarding them indeed as peculiar to the house of Fame.
column1732: Again, see what fun there must be when a man, grown famous, receives scores of letters, most of which address him as "Esquire"--"Esquire," mark you, and living in a three-shilling-a-week cottage!
column1733: How his Majesty's proud servant in uniform must be amused at this, knowing that a man who lives in a cottage no larger than his cannot be of much consequence.
column1734: He knows full well that innocent people far away mistake such a man for a fine gentleman, and he is apt to laugh at times, and in his serious moods to pity him.
column1735: He has seen inside the cottage of this man, called "Esquire," and he saw nothing but bare walls and a few common things on the floor.
column1736: If the poor man of genius said that he had enough praise to paper his walls, he would be laughed at for taking more pride in that than in a nice, comfortable home; and the idiot deserves to be laughed at, and to hang his head for shame.
column1737: Nothing worse could befall a living writer than to be compared to the mighty dead.
column1738: It is most certainly a great compliment, and a great help to a man's spirit, but the consequence is apt to be fatal to his flesh.
column1739: The mistake is that people are likely to think of him as one dead, and, of course, dead men need no food, clothing, or rent.
column1740: Being regarded as one dead, he is naturally not thought of when there is anything given away; and the vast multitudes of powerful English people who are so eager to reward struggling genius--foreign or native--must, in consequence, overlook a man so highly rated.

column2048: Beggars in the Making                 293 BEGGARS I The Nationalities as Beggars There is no question but that the American beggar is the finest in his country; but in that land of many nationalities he has a number of old-country beggars to contend with.
column2049: Perhaps it would interest--it certainly should--a number of people to know how well or ill their own nation is represented by beggars in that most important country; whether England, Ireland, Scotland, Germany, and other countries have cause to be proud or ashamed of their representatives.
column2050: Both France and Italy have much cause to complain, for you may often travel many miles and not be approached by a French or Italian beggar.
column2051: If you meet an Italian, you can safely despise him as a working man with hard-earned money in his pocket, though he may be stealing rides like a beggar, and making coffee with real beggars at their camps.
column2052: With regard to Germany, she can place in the field a very large army of second-rate beggars; but it is seldom that you meet a German beggar whose ambition raises him above that.
column2053: Other nationalities, who go to private houses and beg ready-cooked meals, despise the German beggar for his low taste in being satisfied with no more than common dry food.
column2054: All beggars make coffee at camp-fires, but it is only the German that takes the trouble to carry on his travels his own tin can; for every town has near it a beggars' camp, and cans are always to be found.
column2055: The German's method is to beg the baker for bread, the butcher for sausage, and the grocer for coffee.
column2056: When he is successful, he repairs to the camp, and makes what he calls "an excellent meal" on these dry materials; whereas other beggars have either had a good hot meal at a private house, or have begged a number of paper parcels, in which is buttered bread, and there is cake, and one parcel may have fish as a change from the meat in another, and there is often an apple, orange, or banana for dessert.
column2057: The German does not aspire to these luxuries, and is well satisfied to get the plain diet of his native land--without taking advantage of the offers of a richer country--and to do no work for it.
column2058: He is not a true beggar either, for he is always ready to do odd jobs, such as fruit or hop picking and potato digging, but is not eager for steady work.
column2059: Few people would think the Scotsman makes an excellent beggar, seeing that his manner is so undemonstrative.
column2060: Although he is seldom heard to raise his voice above one distinct pitch, or to indulge in loud laughter, or to show emotion of any kind, yet, for all this, he is an excellent beggar.
column2061: There is quite a large clan of Scotties among American beggars.
column2062: He is a good beggar for the simple reason that he is a good talker.
column2063: Almost every Scotch beggar I met in the States of America was inclined to be talkative, and yet they all managed to conceal their private affairs.
column2064: Although a Scotsman would be one of the last men to go hungry in a civilized land, yet he must be objected to as a true beggar in that he is avaricious for money, and would immediately take advantage of remunerative employment.
column2066: for he is the most timid beggar of all.
column2067: Though he is so independent in throwing up a job, he is always glad, when his money is gone, to seek another.
column2068: How the poor fellow does suffer hunger when seeking work, not having the courage to beg; and how independent and forgetful he is when his appetite is satisfied.
column2069: Even the German, who as a beggar is despised by American, English, and Scotch beggars, stands head and shoulders above poor Pat.
column2070: I am sorry to say so, but the truth of the matter is that Pat receives charity from other beggars--English, Scotch, and such American beggars as are proud of their Irish extraction.
column2071: If these men do not feed him, they often show him a good house where he only has to show his face and be fed.
column2072: I remember a very mean trick being served on two Irishmen, Pat and Tim.
column2073: The guilty one was a Cockney, and he was lucky to escape with his life.
column2074: Seeing at the camp two hungry and helpless Irishmen, he promised to show them a good house, at which no beggars, however often they came, were refused food.
column2075: The elated pair accompanied "Cockney" for this interesting purpose, and were soon shown a very large house, at which, the Cockney said, "he had been treated with as much consideration as though he were the Pope of Rome."
column2076: He then left them to make their own arrangements, and, after much indecision, it was arranged that Pat should go first, and, on his return, his companion Tim should try his luck.
column2077: Pat, with every confidence, approached the big house and rang the bell; but the door was almost immediately opened, as though the inmate had been lying in wait.
column2078: The Irishman had scarcely opened his mouth when the man that answered the door shouted, "What, you big, able-bodied rascal?
column2079: I'll give you something to eat," and rushed at the poor Irishman with a thick walking-stick.
column2080: This was very serious, for Pat also saw the grinning face of a stalwart nigger behind his master, and the Irishman thought the best thing he could do was to leave in a hurry without more words, which he did.
column2081: It quite upset Pat to think that he had been induced to go first, so he made up his mind that Tim should share his misfortune.
column2082: Therefore, when he returned and Tim asked, "What luck, Pat?"
column2083: Pat rubbed his body, saying, "Begorra, there was more mate than five min could ate."
column2084: On hearing this good news Tim braced himself and, after a long pause, walked with reckless determination towards the house.
column2085: But Tim had no time to ring, for the door was suddenly flung open, and, before he could utter one word, a white man and a nigger began to attack him with sticks.
column2086: Tim did not wait to argue or fight, but took to his heels at once.
column2087: "This is a noice thrick, an' the both from Kilkenny," said he to Pat.
column2088: "Spake out," said Pat innocently, although he had seen the whole transaction; "shure, we are frinds, and frinds should share and share aloike."
column2089: I am very pleased to say that the two Irishmen had their reward when they returned, for three good American beggars had thoroughly worked the town, and had in their possession enough food for ten men--but the Cockney never returned to the camp.
column2090: It was certainly a cruel joke to play on two hungry men, innocent and unsuspecting.
column2091: The English easily come next to Americans as beggars, especially when England is represented by the Cockney.
column2092: He will often attain his ends after failing in a cross-examination and discovered in a lie; for his witty excuses and peculiar manner of expression are not to be resisted by Americans.
column2093: Even the Irish-Americans, who are so bitter against Englishmen, make an exception of a Cockney, because of his witty talk and his disinclination to be serious.
column2094: This impudence and command of speech have become proverbial among American beggars, and he is so much liked that I have seen men, who were about to leave a town, remain at a camp for two or three days longer, so as to enjoy the anecdotes and queer sayings of a Cockney that has just arrived.
column2095: The Cockney--and he alone--is admired by those extraordinary beggars who are born Americans, and who are conceited enough to think that they could by their energies live well as beggars in the poorest slums in the cities of Europe.
column2096: Aye, even the beggars of the Western States, who, owing to the great distances between towns, must never be without a dollar or two in their pockets--even these energetic beggars have great respect for a Cockney, though they scorn the petty food-begging operations of others.
column2097: I never in all my acquaintance with "Brum" saw him look so alarmed as when he entered a camp and saw a man making coffee, and near him was a pile consisting of a number of parcels of food.
column2098: This man, who was a Cockney, confessed that he had just begged the town--and we soon had cause to know it, for I had great difficulty in getting one little sandwich, and though Brum brought to the camp enough for two, he must have had a great struggle, for he was away much longer than usual.
column2099: That he had struggled hard was apparent from his behaviour, for in spite of the Cockney's friendly advances, Brum would hardly give him a civil word.
column2100: Yes, there was not the least doubt but what Brum was jealous.
column2101: Although we three remained in the camp together for two days, I could not help but notice that Brum would never allow the Cockney to get the start on him, but every time we went begging he quickly followed the other.
column2102: And what do you think this Cockney had the impudence to say to Brum?
column2103: "Old man," said he, "I'll see if I can beg you a pair of trousers."
column2104: When he heard this Brum almost foamed at the mouth, for he prided himself on being one of the best beggars in America, whether it was in getting money, food, or clothes.
column2105: I know very little about the Welsh as beggars, as I have only met about half a dozen in America, and they were so timid that Wales had as little cause to be proud of them as Ireland of hers.
column2106: I don't think Welshmen take kindly to begging, for, according to my later experience at home, half the beggars in Wales are Englishmen, though many of them can explain themselves in Welsh, having been in the country a considerable time.
column2107: They certainly have good cause to remain there, for Wales runs America a good second in her generosity to beggars; as also does Ireland, but she is less able to give.
column2108: No doubt Russia, Spain, Greece, Japan, and other countries have their beggars by thousands at home, but they are ill represented in America.
column2109: England has only Germany to fear, who has six beggars to England's one; but they have little energy and are badly trained, and one Cockney is equal to ten.
column2110: II A Tramps' Camp in Texas It has borne in upon me lately, with great force, that in those vagabond days at camp-fires in America I was enjoying life as it will never be enjoyed again.
column2111: I was then in a land of plenty, where the people were so happy and good-natured that a bold beggar could often tell them straightforward that he would not work for ten dollars a day, which would cause more amusement than indignation, and he would still be assisted with the best of everything.
column2112: In fact, the common necessaries of life were so easily to be obtained that a superior beggar like Brum had to show his superiority over the ordinary beggar like myself by begging out-of-the-way luxuries--such as cough lozenges and chewing-gum, and a clean shirt and socks once a week, while I washed mine in the woodland stream, and dried them at the camp-fire, or in the wind and sun.
column2113: How often have I received unsolicited clothes and boots from houses at which I had simply asked for meals!
column2114: But when I exposed such articles at the camp, before the eyes of other beggars, I always took the credit on myself for having begged them, for fear of Brum's scorn.
column2115: At one house where I called, the lady wanted her garden cleared of fallen leaves, and offered me twenty-five cents and my breakfast to sweep the said leaves into a corner and set fire to them, which could be done in half an hour.
column2116: I at once accepted her offer, although I was very much afraid that Brum or another would pass, and I would be received with scorn on my return to the camp.
column2117: When I had done this task the lady gave me a good breakfast, with twenty-five cents placed at the side of my plate.
column2118: After I had sat down to this meal the lady left the room and shortly returned with a pair of boots.
column2119: I thanked her for her kindness, and she again left the room, and again returned, this time with a pair of trousers, a shirt, and a pair of socks.
column2120: These things she wrapped in a large journal, saying that my soul would not be any the worse for reading that journal--which had a religious tendency.
column2121: After leaving her I made separate bundles of these things, so as to pretend at the camp that I had received them at different houses, which would considerably enhance my reputation as a beggar, by showing my dogged determination to succeed.
column2122: When I reached the camp I found that not only Brum had returned, but two others were there, namely, "Wingy," who had lost an arm, and "Frisco Fatty."
column2123: I need scarcely say that when that pair of well-known beggars saw my success, they eyed me with great satisfaction and spoke with great respect, although they were too well bred as beggars to express any surprise.
column2124: Of course, I made no reference to work, which would have caused Brum to blush with shame, and would most likely have made Wingy and Frisco Fatty so disgusted that they would have left our fire and gone deeper into the woods, to make a fire of their own.
column2125: It was about ten o'clock, and we were sitting at the fire--Brum, Wingy, Frisco Fatty, and myself--all in the best of humours, each man having had a good breakfast.
column2126: Brum now proposed that we should beg food for our pockets, at dinner-time, so that there would be no need to leave the camp for the rest of the day, and we could then make coffee and have our supper together.
column2127: We had just agreed to this when into the camp walked a young fellow, not much more than a boy, who was picking his teeth.
column2129: he continued to pick his teeth, and at last remarked, "The people in this town keep tough chicken, and I shall be mighty glad to be out of it."
column2130: Saying this, he took hold of an old tin pot, turned it bottom uppermost, and seated himself next to Wingy.
column2131: At the mention of chicken I noticed Brum's ears cock, and then an amused smile came into his face, but he made no remark.
column2132: Although the new-comer made anything but a favourable impression, he appeared nothing daunted, for there he sat, looking at the fire, and whistling, until such time as one of us would start a conversation.
column2133: "I believe that I have seen your face before," said Wingy quietly, and looking the stranger full in the face.
column2134: Now, Wingy knew that he had not seen him before, but he did not want his own presence disgraced by a new-made beggar--who is known to the profession by the name of "fresh cat."
column2135: Therefore, if his thought had been truly expressed, it would have been, "Who are you?"
column2136: The new-comer certainly answered Wingy's thought instead of his language, for he answered with great dignity, "I am Cincinnati Slim."
column2137: As it happened that the city of Cincinnati was Wingy's winter quarters, and that he had never heard of or met this beggar there, you can imagine what a painful silence followed.
column2138: However, although Wingy plainly showed by his expression that the camp was imposed on by the arrival of a "fresh cat," he soon recovered his good humour.
column2139: But it was very fortunate that another fledgling beggar had not then arrived, or Wingy's Christian charity and forbearance would have gone up with the smoke of our camp-fire.
column2140: When dinner-time arrived we all left the camp, and each of us succeeded without much trouble in getting a hot dinner and extra cold food for supper.
column2141: I was very fortunate in getting dinner at the first house I called at, and on going to another house was given a paper parcel, which contained two sandwiches and a banana; this I thought would be ample for my own supper, and returned to the camp.
column2142: Now, my business could scarcely have been transacted quicker, and yet, when I arrived at the camp, I saw to my surprise Cincinnati Slim, picking his teeth.
column2143: "Chicken again," he said to me, pulling a long face, as he struggled with his back teeth.
column2144: At last we were all together, and a very happy supper we had that evening.
column2145: Cincinnati Slim had not arrived in the camp to hear our arrangements, so Brum, seeing more food than could be eaten, invited him to a share.
column2146: Slim remonstrated, saying that he wanted nothing, having had an excellent dinner of chicken and sweet potatoes, and had not known of our arrangements, or he would have begged enough for a dozen men.
column2147: Time after time I saw the same amused expression come into Brum's face as he watched Cincinnati Slim at supper, and I could not help but notice that the latter swallowed large mouthfuls of food with extraordinary speed.
column2148: The next morning Wingy proposed making a large stew, and each man was commissioned to beg certain articles after having had his breakfast.
column2149: Cincinnati Slim was to beg bread, which was very easy; and I had to account for meat, which was quite as easy to obtain, seeing that it was very cheap in that part of the country.
column2150: Wingy had the difficult task of begging coffee, sugar, pepper, and salt; and Brum's task to get raw vegetables was not to be envied.
column2151: These arrangements left Frisco Fatty free, but he was too good a beggar to take advantage of this, and said emphatically that he would get a supply of tobacco.
column2152: With these ideas we all sallied out.
column2153: On this expedition we all succeeded except Cincinnati Slim.
column2154: He walked into the camp, after we had all returned, picking his teeth as usual.
column2155: He complained that every time he asked for bread he was invited indoors to a hot meal, and that after this had occurred for the third time, he had been forced to give up in despair, for fear of another hot meal for an already overloaded stomach.
column2156: However, that did not matter, for Brum had begged a loaf of bread, in addition to onions, potatoes, and tomatoes.
column2157: He seemed to have expected the failure of bread.
column2158: At one o'clock the stew was ready, and we shared it out in tin cans, with which the camp was well supplied.
column2159: Cincinnati Slim had an extraordinary appetite, and certainly ate twice as much as any other, and was encouraged by Brum to do so.
column2160: He apologized for his third helping by saying that it was his favourite dish, and that it was a change from so much chicken.
column2161: It was certainly a good meal, and we were all contented to remain in the camp for the rest of the day, with hot coffee and bread for supper.
column2162: When I awoke the next morning my companions were asleep, but Brum was not to be seen.
column2163: After indulging in another nap, I awoke from my second sleep, and saw my companions washing and preparing to go for breakfast.
column2164: I was just about to enquire for Brum when into the camp that true beggar walked.
column2165: He, it seemed, had risen early, and begged his breakfast at a poor work-man's house--a deed that I had never known him to do before.
column2166: At last we were all ready to seek breakfast, and Brum, having had his, was left smoking his pipe at the fire.
column2167: It was certainly a most extraordinary town for good-natured people, for in less than half an hour we were all back in the camp.
column2171: The words were hardly out of my mouth when Cincinnati Slim appeared, still picking his teeth, and close at his heels came Brum.
column2172: After Wingy and Frisco Fatty had left the camp, for they were on their way to Galveston, Brum looked straight at Cincinnati Slim and said, "Well, Slim, what kind of breakfast did you have?
column2174: "Not this time," answered Slim; "ham and fried eggs."
column2177: "You have not been to a single house, for I have been following you all the time.
column2178: You have had nothing to eat since you came except what you have had at this camp.
column2179: If it were not for luck, young fools like you would starve.
column2180: Here, take this"--and he threw Cincinnati Slim a paper of food.
column2181: The latter sat down without a word and began to eat.
column2182: III Daring Beggars American beggars knock boldly at doors like kings' messengers.
column2183: An imposing mansion with marble pillars is a challenge to them, and they dance up its steps and press the button of an electric bell with a violence that no familiar friends of the house would dare use; but an English beggar almost sinks into the earth when his ears receive the report of his timid hand.
column2184: In fact, except in very rare instances, where a large house has been approached and--for a wonder--found good, and has become famous to the begging fraternity--except in these very rare instances, English beggars pass by large mansions as though they were empty churches or smallpox hospitals.
column2185: I don't suppose there is a more daring or more impudent rascal on earth than a good American beggar.
column2186: It is always his boast that he has begged an ex-president, or the present one, and he claims to have received benefits from a number of well-known millionaires, actors, and prize-fighters.
column2187: Such proud experiences never fall from the lips of an English beggar, for the simple reason that he lives on the working and middle classes.
column2188: A row of small cottages is of more benefit to him than an equal number of fine villas, and he thinks that he is in a hungry wilderness when there is nothing to be seen but very large houses--and he is quite right.
column2189: It has always seemed strange to me that Americans, who as a race are notoriously eager to make money, should be so generous to a beggar.
column2190: Even when they refuse it is often more on account of haste than meanness.
column2191: Not only that, but they give with such indifference, and are never annoyed at being solicited, whether they are reading papers on the verandahs of hotels, or promenading a sea-beach in the company of ladies.
column2192: And, what is more, they seldom pry into a beggar's past, except in such cases as when their interest is aroused by a beggar's speech.
column2193: For instance, a gentleman's father or mother may have been English, Irish or Scotch, and when he thinks that he can detect that tongue in the speech of a beggar, he is very apt to ask one or two questions, and the beggar is invariably more generously assisted.
column2194: The American tramp begs in such a quick, thorough, business-like manner, with such calm persistence and with such confidence, that he must at last meet with success in the very worst places; for that reason he will not stand for cross-examination, and if people attempt to pry into his life, he is just as likely as not to tell them straight that he is a beggar, that he does not work, and never will.
column2195: The blindest housewife must soon have her eyes opened to the ingratitude of these men.
column2196: Most of the houses in small American towns burn wood, so that a woman is often glad to give a tramp a good hot meal for five or ten minutes' wood-chopping.
column2197: But when beggars are asked to chop wood for a meal, they complain of working on an empty stomach.
column2199: for, after being served with a good meal, they often walk away without a glance at the wood-pile.
column2200: Some of them do worse--they take the axe, and after delivering one or two blows they manage to break the handle; then they take the axe to the mistress of the house, and after quietly apologizing for the accident, walk away with heavy bellies and light hearts.
column2201: One lady, who had been served this trick a number of times, had become so irritated, for she could no longer regard them as accidents, that she decided to feed no more tramps except when her husband was on the premises.
column2202: Brum, my friend and tutor, unfortunately happened to call at this lady's house, and was at once informed that if he wanted a meal he would have to chop wood for it.
column2203: Brum agreed to this, but suggested that he could work all the better for having the meal first.
column2204: He was soon seated at the table, and after enjoying a very fine meal, repaired to the wood-pile.
column2205: After chopping wood for five minutes he was just about to drop the axe and leave, when he heard a man cough.
column2206: Looking in that direction, he saw to his surprise a man seated on a chair, watching him with a sarcastic smile on his face, and, what was far worse, a shot-gun was lying across his knees.
column2207: There was nothing else for poor Brum to do than to continue chopping wood until the man gave him permission to go.

column2432: I and another had been treated well, night after night, in the various police stations of Connecticut and Massachusetts, and one night we came to a nice little town in the latter State.
column2433: We had not the least difficulty in begging supper.
column2434: In fact we hardly parted, for my companion was invited into the first house he called at, and the same thing happened to me at the house next door.
column2435: It was a very strange, neat piece of business; for we were both standing together at different doors, and even chatted while we waited; and the both doors were answered at the same time; and, at the same time as a man's voice said to him, "Come in," so a woman's voice said the same words to me.
column2436: We could hear one another's steps going to the supper table, and our movements could be heard so plain that one must be aware when the other was leaving the house.
column2437: My companion was an American and a fast eater, and I heard them letting him out when I was about three parts through with my supper.
column2438: However, he waited and, when I rejoined him, we both sought the police station, not dreaming but what it would be like the others visited on the previous nights.
column2439: Being strangers in that town, we were at a loss which way to turn.
column2440: Therefore, when I saw a boy coming near, I enquired of him as to where the marshal was to be found.
column2441: Seeing him look astonished, I rewarded his curiosity by telling him our business--that we wanted a night's lodging at the police station.
column2443: he cried in amazement; "what: not in the cooler?"
column2444: I was quite surprised to hear this word "cooler," for I had never heard it before.
column2445: However, just then the marshal came and, after hearing our wants, said, "Certainly, boys, follow me."
column2446: He then led the way down a dark side street and in a few minutes stood before a small stone building, with one storey, and one room--to all appearance--and with bars at the window.
column2447: Taking from his pocket a large key, he opened the door and walked in, inviting us to follow him.
column2448: When we were all three inside, he struck a match, and by its light motioned towards a dark corner, saying, "You will find blankets there, boys; make yourselves comfortable."
column2449: He had scarcely uttered these words when the light went out--and so did he; for, before we could ask one question, we heard the key turned in the lock, and we were left alone.
column2450: My companion shouted several questions after him, but he did not answer or return.
column2451: We wanted to know several things, the principal one being about drinking water.
column2452: By the light of a match, which I held, my companion found the blankets--two dirty, ill-smelling, thin blankets, and half a one.
column2453: Here was a difference in treatment.
column2454: Twelve miles from this place we were treated better, some people would think, than we deserved, but this was downright cruelty.
column2456: well I remembered the boy saying "cooler"!
column2457: For it was the dead of winter, and the floor was of stone, and we only had two thin blankets and a half between us.
column2458: The place was also very damp, for no fire had ever been lit in this building.
column2459: I need hardly say that we had to run about all night in the dark to keep our bodies from freezing, in spite of being good beggars and well-fed men.
column2460: There is so much difference in the prisons of America that tramps always--when they incline for a change, thieving instead of begging--discuss at the camps the accommodation of the prisons that await unsuccessful attempts.
column2461: The kind of thieving tramps mostly go in for is breaking seals and robbing cars of their merchandise; and the time of year they do these things is on the approach of winter; so that they may either be in a good warm jail during the cold months, or else have freedom with plenty of money in their pockets.
column2462: I knew one good jail, in Michigan, that was very hard to break into.
column2463: A man could beg with impunity at private houses or in the public streets without being arrested, and tramps had to resort to other methods to attain their ends.
column2464: They would go boldly and take things from the doorways of shops, and would then, to their delight, be arrested, charged with petty larceny, and sentenced to from twenty to sixty days.
column2465: They did not snatch the things and run, but deliberately took them under people's eyes.
column2466: When they were in their much-coveted jail, they had nothing to do but play cards, smoke, read, eat and sleep.
column2467: There was some difference between that place and the Old Prison at New Orleans.
column2468: When I was arrested there, with six others, for sleeping in a freight car, we were all sentenced to thirty days.
column2469: The judge--an old Southerner, who could never forgive the North for freeing the slaves without giving their owners some compensation--this old judge commented very severely and bitterly on our coming South, to live on its charity, instead of staying where we belonged.
column2470: "We don't want you down here," he said; "but now that you are here, we will keep you for a time."
column2471: Only niggers and the poorest white people were sent to this Old Prison, for there was a new place for the better-class prisoners.
column2472: Indeed as there were no clothes supplied, there could not be any mistake as to the class of prisoners.
column2473: No such a thing as a bath, no work, and no discipline.
column2474: At night we were lodged in large cells that had a number of bunks in each, and we could not sleep for the cold.
column2475: In the day we walked about in a large yard, several hundred prisoners.
column2476: Some of the new prisoners, not yet tamed by cold and hunger, would laugh, sing, and dance, and fights were not unusual.
column2477: Our food consisted of a small quantity of bread and some greasy water, almost starvation.
column2478: The men that had been confined there for a month or more were like skeletons.
column2479: The object seemed to be to keep us alive, and no more, so as to save the expense of burying us.
column2480: A number of prisoners had gone simple of mind.
column2481: There was one--a Chinaman--and no one seemed to know how long he had been there or what for, as he could not speak a word of English.
column2482: I often think of the poor wretch--the most pathetic figure I have ever seen.
column2483: When he was walking up and down the yard, he would suddenly come to a standstill and, in a very clear, high voice sing his grief like a bird.
column2484: Every prisoner would be startled by this sudden and unexpected wail, and a dead silence would come, which before was all buzz.
column2485: But, as can be expected, this effect would not last long, for some simple prisoner, as mad as the Chinaman himself, would begin to shout and laugh, and others would soon join him.
column2486: Then the poor Chinaman would stop and, wrapping his loose garment about him, begin again his silent walk to and fro.
column2487: In an hour or two after, the place would be again startled by that high, clear voice, and the same silence would come, and the same jeering would break the spell.
column2488: While I was in this prison we had a fall of snow--which is exceptional in that part--and we suffered very much on that account.
column2489: But the snow was very kind to the mad Chinaman, for he was found dead the next morning, with snow on his body.
column2490: And yet he was in a cell--but I am not prepared to enter into a description as to how this prison was arranged.
column2491: All I know is that I saw the cell with the door open and the dead man's feet just inside, covered with snow.
column2492: No doubt the governor gave a satisfactory account of the prisoner under his charge.
column2493: VIII Experiences of Others Some of my experiences may sound a little exciting to men that have led a quiet life at home, but I would not care to mention them in the hearing of some men that I have met.
column2494: One of my worst experiences was in riding the rods of a train, in the State of Texas, on a road that was notoriously hard to beat.
column2495: Riding the rods means to stretch one's body under a car, on a narrow board four inches wide, which is fastened to two thin iron rods.
column2496: Tramps never ride in this way, except when the brakesmen are very bad and would strike them off the bumpers, and there is not one unsealed, empty car on the train.
column2497: But when a tramp is safely on the rods, and the train is going, it is then impossible to reach him with anything until the train stops.
column2498: Of course if the rods broke, or anything happened to the board, or the tramp went to sleep, he must then fall and be cut to pieces.
column2499: All these freight trains have rods, but a great number are without boards; for that reason a tramp often gets his own board and drives a nail into each end.
column2500: When the train begins to move he throws his board across the rods, and then leaps under the car.
column2501: His life now depends on the nails keeping in their place, the board not breaking, and keeping awake.
column2502: But sometimes, unfortunately for the tramp, the brakesmen see a train out; which means that they will stand one on each side of the train, at the head of the engine, and inspect each side of the train as it passes them.
column2503: If they see a tramp on the top of a car, or on the bumpers, they shout to him to get off, and, when they have themselves boarded the train, they come back over the top to see whether he has obeyed them or not.
column2504: It would be wise for the tramp to do so, for the train would then be going slow; but if he does not, these brakesmen will force him after, at the point of a revolver, to jump off a train now going fast.
column2505: But if they see a tramp on the rods, they are in a strange position.
column2506: It is no use to tell him to get off, because he cannot do so until the train stops; and, as they cannot reach him, he rides in spite of them.
column2507: They can only do one thing, and that is what I, and many more, have had done, and it is not a pleasant experience.
column2508: These brakesmen arm themselves with stones, and one of them no sooner sees a tramp under the car than he shouts to his fellow.
column2509: After doing this the two brakesmen run with the train, throwing stones with all their might, and the tramp can hear their savage yells and the stones strike against the car.
column2510: As it is, he is in a shaky position, without being helped to fall by receiving a blow on the head with a stone.
column2511: Fortunately for him, they must soon stop throwing, for the train is going faster and faster, and if they do not board it soon they will be left behind.
column2512: But they are so used to jumping on moving trains, that they can afford time to throw a number of stones.
column2513: Another thing in the tramp's favour is that they only have a few stones in the first place, and then have to pick them up.
column2514: But what favours the tramp most is that these men cannot aim straight, because the train is on the move, and they have to follow the car.
column2515: This was one of my worst experiences, being stoned while riding the rods.
column2516: Of course these brakesmen could rush forward and either pull a tramp out or push him off, but they could not do so without getting him caught in the wheels.
column2517: This would be such plain murder that, in spite of their rage, it frightens them; so they stone him instead, and give him a chance for his life.
column2518: Half the tramps in America will not ride a train if they cannot get the comfort of an empty car--not even on a road where the brakesmen are good and indifferent as to the number of tramps they carry.
column2519: Still, there are so many that have had my experience that I would not mention it in the hearing of an old American tramp.
column2520: But it must not be supposed that the dangers of beating one's way on freight trains in America are always caused by unsympathetic brakesmen.
column2521: I know one good road which carried hundreds of tramps every week, and it was never known that a brakesman had ever put one off.
column2522: In fact the brakesmen on this road used to look with indifference on tramps, as though they were part of the common freight.
column2523: Some of these brakesmen were so used to tramps that they would confess a fear to run a train that had none, much the same as sailors look for rats on board a ship.
column2524: But this road was spoilt by a gang of half robbers and half beggars.
column2525: These men would board a train when it was standing still, and as soon as it was on the move, would go from car to car and search every man that they saw beating his way.
column2526: This they would do with men riding outside, in coal cars or on flat cars.
column2527: When the train stopped, they would get off and inspect the train.
column2528: If they saw an empty car that contained one or two men, this gang--four, five, or six in number--would get in.
column2529: A tramp would not know but what they were the same as himself, and would not feel any alarm, but welcome their company.
column2530: But as soon as the train was again on the move, these new arrivals would then begin to question and search the first occupants of the car, and woe betide the man that refused to be searched or was not civil.
column2531: Out through the open door he would be thrown, and the train would be going thirty or forty miles an hour, and it would be night.
column2532: As I have said, these men were all beggars, for they would not make enough out of these petty robberies to keep them.
column2533: For this reason a man had only to say, when questioned as to what he was, "I am a beggar," and they would then treat him with every respect.
column2534: The men they wanted to find were those that were working men and had money in their pockets, but preferred to ride free on an easy road.
column2535: The desperate methods of these men were so well known that tramps would often swarm together in one car, knowing that their number would make them safe.
column2536: For all that, several dead men were found every week on this road, and the cause was well known to tramps.
column2537: Some of the mutilated men that just escaped with their lives would have mentioned these things to the police, but the latter did not trouble, for it was all tramp work, from beginning to end.
column2538: One of the worst experiences I have ever heard of was of a young cattleman whom I knew in Baltimore.
column2539: When I met him he was only a lad of twenty years, and he had such a calm, pleasant face that no one would think that he ever had an hour's suffering in his life.
column2540: Two years before this he had been a stowaway from England to America, and he was not discovered for several days.
column2541: So, being too late to put him on shore, the captain set him to work, with the intention of handing him over to the police on arrival in America.
column2542: But when they were in sight of land and saw the distant lights, it being night, this lad possessed himself of a life-belt and, without being seen, dropped overboard.
column2543: He was under the impression that the tide and his own exertions would take him to land before morning and, no one being about, he would be safe.
column2544: But instead of this, he got caught in a strong outgoing current, and was taken out to sea.
column2545: He then had the experience of floating two days and two nights in the deep sea, before he was seen and picked up by a passing ship.
column2546: Whatever his thoughts could have been, it was most certain that his mind was not affected, for when I knew him he was the most cheerful and sweetest tempered in the cattleman's office, and he was never heard to mention his experience.
column2547: At this office was another cattleman, who had not only been in the hands of lynchers, but even had the rope round his neck and the other end of it thrown over the limb of a tree.
column2548: A tramp had assaulted a woman, and a number of men were searching for him.
column2549: Seeing a man at a camp-fire in the woods they at once pounced on him and, without any question, placed the rope round his neck and prepared to hang him.
column2550: But, fortunately for him, another body of men came, led by the woman's husband, and with him was a little boy who had witnessed the assault.
column2551: "That's not the man," said the little fellow--which saved the man's life.
column2552: This cattleman was one of the ugliest men that I have ever seen, but he was really so harmless, simple, and innocent, that we all liked him and fed him, and got him to sing.
column2553: We knew that women would be afraid of him, and for this reason he was apt to starve.
column2554: So we better looking and less deserving tramps saved the poor fellow the humiliation of having doors slammed in his face, and hearing keys turned and bolts drawn.
column2555: IX The American Lakes English sailors who run away from their ships in America, often do so with the intention of going inland and sailing on the fresh-water lakes.
column2556: Other sailors, who have done so before, but felt that they had to return to the salt sea, talk of their former experience, so that almost every English sailor knows what sailing on the American lakes is like.
column2557: On their deep-sea boats they get hard biscuits, salt meat, dried peas, and cheap molasses; but on the lakes they get soft bread, fresh meat, green vegetables, and luxurious fruit.
column2558: It is no lie that common sailors and firemen on the American lakes get strawberries and cream, when such berries are in season, and other fruits when they are not.
column2559: Therefore it is not to be wondered at when English sailors soon feel themselves in a strange position: they feel loth to break away from the splendid board and lodging on fresh water, and yet cannot help feeling restless to return to the salt sea and take long voyages.
column2560: There are hundreds of English sailors on the American lakes that have either been in our navy or merchant service, and they live so well, in comparison with their deep-sea experience, that it is a great pity that fresh water cannot employ them all the year, as the sea could.
column2561: Of course, they earn enough to keep them idle during the winter, but we all know that saving sailors are almost as scarce as white crows.
column2562: The real fresh-water sailor, who has never been on the sea, and probably never saw it, is different to the deep-sea man in many ways.
column2563: For instance, he walks straight and does not roll, which is owing to the different action of inland waters.
column2564: His voice is gentle and soft, not rough and hoarse like a deep-sea sailor's.
column2565: But, for all that, when it comes to money matters he is quite as extravagant as the man of long voyages, and is quite as easily fleeced by land-sharks, in spite of his greater knowledge of life on shore.
column2566: And every lake town is as well supplied with land-sharks as a seaport of its size.
column2567: But, fortunately for these lake sailors, they are nearly all beggars, owing to having no work in the winter when the lakes are frozen and navigation has stopped.
column2568: This being the case, most of them think very little of begging a house, and if they are robbed or spend their money foolishly and have to wait for a ship, they are not likely to suffer hunger.
column2569: One great advantage on the lakes is that when a man ships he has no particular need of top boots, oilskins, and many other things needed by the man of the deep sea.
column2570: Indeed, the latter has to even supply himself with a knife, fork, and spoon.
column2571: There is no law that a man must have a bag of clothes, for there is no need of them.
column2572: He is allowed to ship as he stands, no matter whether he is clad like a sailor or a farmer, or is in rags like an unsuccessful beggar.
column2573: As far as appearances are concerned, a great number of these fresh-water sailors end the season as they began it.
column2574: Some of them look far worse, for they may have had good clothes and boots when navigation began, and have worn them all the summer and have not bought others.
column2575: Therefore, when they are paid for their last trip, and spend the money foolishly, they are ill-shod and shabbily dressed.
column2576: The fresh-water sailors are not nearly so illiterate as salt-water men, because they are so often on shore in large towns and cities.
column2577: A popular song would not be more than three or four days old before they were on shore to hear it.
column2578: They do not return, after one voyage, to be surprised that the town has built a large new dock since they left, or doubled its population, as deep-sea men may do.
column2579: I was never, in all my life, seized with so great a desire for work as when I was in one of these lake towns and haunting the waterside.
column2580: When I thought of the good pay, the rich food, and the easy work to be done, it was as much as I could do to keep from applying for a ship.
column2581: In fact I made a special journey to Toronto for that very purpose, but was petted and spoilt by the many good people in that town.
column2582: The first day I arrived I happened to find a green, open space where I could lie down and take my ease between meals.
column2583: It did not take me long to find out that the houses around that green common were very good, for I had no difficulty at all in begging my first meal, which was breakfast.
column2584: After doing this, I returned to the green common and lay down in the grass.
column2585: But it was not long before the children came; so, wanting an active hour, I began to play ball with them.
column2586: This exercise gave me a good appetite for dinner, and, when that hour came, I succeeded with as much ease as at breakfast-time.
column2587: It was not long before I was back on the common, where I played ball with the children all the afternoon.
column2588: Naturally, I now lost all inclination for work on the lakes, and even laughed at myself for ever having had such a thought.
column2589: But, unfortunately, this life was too good to last long, for something happened the following day that not only put an end to my ball-playing, but forced me to leave the green common.
column2590: I had gone to a house to seek dinner, and the door was answered by a man who, to my surprise, frowned at me.
column2591: This unkind reception was so unusual on the great American continent that I made up my mind to demand, after he had refused me some dinner, an explanation as to why he received me in that way.
column2592: But there was no need for me to speak, for the explanation came at once.
column2593: "Look here," said he, "do you mean to tell me that you are looking for work?"
column2596: he shouted; "didn't I see you playing ball with the children all day yesterday, only a few yards from here?
column2597: Didn't I see you this morning holding the skipping-rope for some girls?"
column2598: There was no escape from these questions, so I began to retreat.
column2599: Perhaps that was the reason--that I had not made the least attempt to excuse myself--why he called me back and invited me indoors.
column2600: And I must say that his good lady, who was smiling and laughing all the time, served me with an excellent dinner.
column2601: In spite of this, I thought it wise not to be seen again in that happy green place, for fear that he might draw the attention of the police to me.
column2602: So, being deprived of the pleasure of playing ball, I left Toronto, too down-hearted to seek enjoyment in any other part of that city, which was well known to be good all over.
column2603: I could nearly always be sure of a dollar or two at these lake towns--Chicago, Cleveland, Buffalo, Toronto, and others--owing to my acquaintance with so many men.
column2604: For almost all the cattlemen that sailed from Baltimore in the winter, worked on the lakes in the summer.
column2605: They left Baltimore a week or two before navigation began on the lakes, and as soon as it stopped they returned to work as cattlemen between America and Europe.
column2606: As there were scores of these cattlemen, and I not only knew them all, but was liked, it was to my advantage to make lake towns my haunts.
column2607: Not one of them ever insulted me with a hint that I should do as he did--work for my money.
column2608: The reason of this is that they all considered it their duty to assist me, for I had often assisted them in other ways.
column2609: For instance, when they came back one by one and in twos and threes from the lakes, they were always loth to start begging again in Baltimore, which they must either do or starve.
column2610: To make things worse, they would probably have to wait a week or two before they could get a chance to sail with cattle, for at this time the office would be full of men.
column2611: Now, as I was always back before them, they could rely on me for a little assistance, for I would beg extra on their account.
column2612: But for all that, the money I got from them was more of a curse than a blessing, for the reason that it often kept me several days in idleness; and, after living in lazy respectability for three or four days, I always found it hard to start again to earn my living as a beggar.
column2613: It seems a mystery that these inland lakes should be sometimes visited by such terrific storms.
column2614: One winter, when I was in Chicago, I went down to the waterside to see a ship in its last extremity.
column2615: When I got there I saw thousands of helpless people, watching a vessel sinking before their eyes, no one being able to go to its assistance in small boats.
column2616: We could expect to see this happen on the wild sea-coast, but this was an inland lake, and here was a city of more than a million inhabitants.
column2617: It is more to be wondered at by men who have seen that beautiful lake almost without a ripple in summer-time.
column2618: X The Happy Life It is certainly a mystery how man got into this tangle, having to conform to the rules of civilization--up in the morning at a certain hour, and to bed at a certain time at night, with certain limited intervals for meals; in fact a very slave to these conditions, and so often without power of being otherwise.
column2619: If he breaks his fetters by indulging in more sleep, or prolonging his meals, he will starve, for nuts are not now free for the picking, and fruits are not now the free gift of Nature; for she herself is made the servant of landlords who are tyrannical over their rights.
column2620: It is only the small boys who occasionally defy such laws by robbing an orchard and putting to shame their big, cowardly fathers.
column2621: When I consider what pleasure it gives me to lie abed in the mornings at my own sweet will, I cannot help but feel pity for the great majority who must needs rise to answer the demands of civilization.
column2622: Of course, I could not myself be so independent if I were not contented with very little, and did not prefer freedom to fine clothes and furniture and the luxuries of food.
column2623: We know very well that the one happy hour in the week for a man of business is when he wakes on a Sabbath morn, or a holiday, at his usual time to rise, and finds, O joy!
column2624: that he is privileged to lie in bed, a free and a happy man.
column2625: What a strange contrast there is between the man who lives in a small house with just enough means, and no more, to keep him in idle content, and the man who, to keep up a position, has a large house with several servants, and worries himself night and day in business to keep things standing!
column2626: What a wise man is the former, and what a poor fool is the latter!
column2629: It is to be pestered by invitations to other people's houses, and to be worried again in returning those invitations.
column2630: How foolish is that business man, that he does not sell out and retire to a small country cottage, with his little income of a pound or twenty-five shillings a week, where he could eat, sleep, and read in peace, and walk abroad admiring Nature.
column2631: Thousands of business men could do this, and would, if they were wise enough to see what an empty thing position is.
column2632: There are not many men in this world who appreciate more than I do that precious gift called sleep.
column2633: When I wake in the morning and look at my watch, it may be seven o'clock.
column2634: Then I question myself--"Shall I get up?
column2636: No, gentle Sleep, one more hour with thee."
column2637: Then I sleep again and wake the second time, and ask this question again--"Shall I get up?"
column2638: What with yawning and stretching it usually takes a quarter of an hour to answer, which makes the time quarter past eight.
column2639: Then I say to myself, "I will count fifty before I get up."
column2640: This I begin to do, very slowly; but when I have done I usually make the fifty a hundred.
column2641: This dallying with time is very pleasant.
column2642: Sometimes I return to bed after I have got up, and have even undressed for that purpose.
column2643: To make a candid confession, I have--not often--got up, dressed, and then returned to bed with my clothes on, so as to enjoy another nap and be at no pains to dress again.
column2644: I remember making one trip on a cattle-boat, and on the return voyage to Baltimore there was no work to be done, we cattlemen being then counted as passengers.
column2645: The nearest approach to work of any kind was that two men were commissioned each day to fetch food from the galley and to sweep the forecastle--the latter duty not to be strictly enforced.
column2646: Now, it happened that there were fifteen cattlemen, so that one man would be exempt from even such petty duties as these.
column2647: We therefore cast lots, and the laziest man was fortunate to win.
column2648: It was Baldy, who, on hearing the decision, crept back into his bunk and remained there for the rest of the voyage.
column2649: When the meals came, he sat up and requested some kind hand to pass him his food, and, after returning the empty dishes to the same kind hand, settled down for another sleep.
column2650: One night the ship, being light, rolled so much that we were all thrown out of our bunks, all except Baldy.
column2651: That same night we rushed on deck, cattlemen, sailors, and firemen, for the coal-bunkers had been broken in by the waves, and coal filled the galley, and the cattle-pens were smashed and taken to sea, and crash followed crash until we thought our end had come--and yet Baldy, whatever his feelings were, never left his bunk.
column2652: When we arrived at Baltimore we were all, as usual, without money.
column2653: On Baldy being roused and told we were about to go ashore, he began slowly to rise, but it was only after making several attempts that he succeeded in standing on his feet.
column2654: My heart went out in pity for the poor fellow, for it was as much as three of us could do to get him up the forecastle steps.
column2655: It was with great difficulty that he passed the doctor, for that gentleman happened to see him totter, and he had an idea that Baldy and, in fact, all the crew should be quarantined; but on receiving an explanation that Baldy's legs were weak through inactivity, he allowed us to go ashore.
column2656: The distance to the cattlemen's office was over a mile, and poor Baldy could not possibly walk that distance, and, as I have said, we were all without money.
column2657: But as luck would have it, a gentleman saw Baldy's condition and gave him five cents to pay car fare, so we helped the poor fellow into the car, which would take him right to the door of the office.
column2658: Honestly, if I had not been cursed with ambition to excel in literature, I would have remained a beggar to the end of my days; to winter in such towns as Baltimore, and spend my summer months in travelling through the green country, with short stops here and there in cities and large towns.
column2660: To study faces and the strange humours of different people.
column2661: Yes, when I was about to call at a house for my dinner, the Baltimore Kid suddenly clutched my shoulders, and said impressively: "Whatever you do, do not address that woman as Lady, but call her Madam, or Mrs." Just to humour the Kid, for I thought such advice was ridiculous, I addressed the lady as Madam, and explained my needs.
column2662: She motioned me to a small, wooden outhouse, which I entered, and seeing a chair and a table, sat down.
column2663: In about two minutes the lady reappeared, carrying a hot dinner, for which I stood, as became a gentleman, and thanked her, saying: "I thank you, Madam," but was almost on the point of saying "lady."
column2664: After having had dinner, I went to the back door and knocked, to thank her for her kindness.
column2665: "You are quite welcome," she said; "the only people I refuse are those who say 'lady,' for I have cause to believe that such people are professional beggars."
column2666: You see, by this instance, how one little word can assist or spoil a man in his profession.
column2667: The Baltimore Kid was one of the keenest beggars in America.
column2668: The sight or sound of money put the very devil in him.
column2669: If he heard coins rattling in the pockets of a passer-by, he would follow that person side by side, up one street and down another until he had succeeded in talking the man out of a coin.
column2670: If he saw a lady open her purse, he was at once at her side, and explaining his position.
column2671: He boasted that he had begged the President, when the latter was visiting his paternal home.
