column2672: The Kid had intended to beg the house for clothes, but, seeing the President alone in the garden, quickly altered his mind.
column2673: He claimed to have then talked the gentleman out of a five-dollar bill.
column2674: Whether this story was true or not, I cannot say, but I am certain of one thing--that it was only the want of opportunity that would keep it from being attempted.
column2675: The pomp and splendour of Solomon's throne would not have daunted the Baltimore Kid, if he saw the way clear of stern guards and meddlesome attendants.
column2676: Many of the great capitalists of America, and many Europeans of title, had succumbed to the Kid's voice.
column2677: Yes, he has often related to me how easy he found the Grand Duke of Gorgonzola, and how long it took to convince Tomkins the millionaire butcher.
column2678: XI Boy Desperadoes The danger of our slums is not caused so much by men as by boys; and some of the latter are so young that they have not yet taken to drink, although they have smoked cigarettes for years.
column2679: These half boys and half men are far more dangerous than full-grown bullies.
column2680: The reason is that they do not think of the consequences, and they work themselves into an hysterical passion that often results in brutal murder.
column2681: One time I was in a small town in America when a young outlaw of eighteen years was being tried for killing about half a dozen men, and half killing a number of others, all in his short career.
column2682: No doubt this sounds like very high brutal courage, but the truth of the matter is that it was the lowest cowardice.
column2683: He was too young to have that cool courage of a man who bids another to stand and deliver and, after committing robbery, walks away without more ado.
column2684: This boy, full of fear, no sooner saw the motion of another than he pulled the trigger, in fear of his own life.
column2685: I don't suppose that there was ever a man outlaw in America that was so dangerous as this youth.
column2686: Again, men are robbers for gain, and nothing else; but when a number of these half boys and half men are together, they want sport and romance as well.
column2687: They would not be satisfied with robbing a man, but would like to show their power after.
column2688: What makes these youths so dangerous is that they obey the first impulse, which, more often than not, is a cruel one; and the cruelty increases with their strength of number.
column2689: One time I saw a dozen boys on the levee in St. Louis hold up and rob every man they came to.
column2690: They not only did this, but, as usual with them, started to beat the man after, kicking and punching him, until he had to run for his life.
column2691: This happened in broad daylight; but they took care, as hysterical as they were, not to interfere with more than two men at a time, in spite of their number.
column2692: These boys were quite dangerous, with revolvers, razors, knives, and clubs; and they uttered the most fearful oaths, and yelled like savages.
column2693: No doubt, if they had met a stubborn man, who refused to either escape or humour them, they would have killed him.
column2694: Now, what could a man do against these blind, desperate young bullies?
column2695: If he had a revolver, he could hold back a dozen men by threatening to shoot the first man that advanced, and each man would have had enough sense to see the folly of risking his life.
column2696: But these youths would have rushed on in their blind passion, and whether you shot one or not, you could not escape being half killed or killed by the others.
column2697: These half boys and half men have no idea of fair play; if a man goes down, they will take good care that he does not rise again to renew the battle, for they will kick him into unconsciousness.
column2698: It is these young bullies, and not grown men, that make the slums of London and other large cities so dangerous.
column2699: They feel the strength of the coming man, and they are eager to try it.
column2700: So, when they see a man drunk, and scarcely capable of looking after himself, they begin to jibe him.
column2701: The poor fool, courageous in drink, and seeing that they are no more than boys, stops to abuse them.
column2702: It is then that one of them steps forward and sometimes, to disguise his intention, holds out the hand of friendship, and the poor drunkard receives a blow in the face instead.
column2703: Of course, this exasperates him, and he attacks them all.
column2704: If it is day, the young bullies escape laughing, but if it is night, and the place quiet, they will all try their strength on him, and probably leave him insensible in the gutter.
column2705: If they cannot trip a man or knock him down, they kick or use the buckles of belts, and they give him great cause to remember the occasion.
column2706: Nearly all these young bullies wear strong leather belts with heavy solid buckles, and they know well how to use them.
column2707: Any common lodging-house that harbours a gang of five or six of these half boys and half men is a very dangerous place in which to live.
column2708: If there is a full-grown bully there, he will be very cautious not to offend any of these, however he may try to intimidate other lodgers.
column2709: I left one lodging-house, after staying there a week, because of three of these young ruffians, who seemed to do as they liked.
column2710: At that house there was a big bully, a man six feet in height and heavy in build.
column2711: This big fellow was continually grumbling and threatening the old lodgers, but never interfered with the younger ones, although they often laughed at him in mockery.
column2712: But one day, when he was cooking at the fire, one of these young ruffians, accidentally it seemed, pushed him, and the big bully turned with his usual oath and uplifted hand.
column2713: Now, no doubt, if the kitchen had been empty, he would have pretended to be satisfied with the young ruffian's sneering apology, but seeing so many witnesses, he thought it was his duty to show what he was, so he gave the youngster a slap in the face.
column2714: The latter did not attempt to retaliate, for he had not the assistance of his friends.
column2715: No doubt he told them of it that night, when they were all together.
column2716: A few mornings after this the big bully was found dead in bed; his death being caused by a blow in the back of the head, received in a fall.
column2717: It seemed that he had had enough strength to walk to the lodging-house and get into bed, and had died afterward.
column2718: There were several beds in that room, but none of the other lodgers had heard anything unusual in the night, although they saw that the man staggered into the room.
column2719: There can be no doubt but what he was drunk, but drunken men do not often fall down and deal themselves death-blows--they only collapse.
column2720: My opinion is that these young ruffians had waylaid him away from the house, and seeing that he was drunk, helped him to his fall.
column2721: These young bullies never forgive, and never forget.
column2722: If one is threatened when he is without the support of others, he will not rest satisfied until he gets their help and takes vengeance.
column2723: What makes full-grown men so much afraid of these half boys and half men is their entire recklessness.
column2724: They will use knife, poker, fork, or anything that is near their hands.
column2725: One day I saw one of these young bullies deliberately poke an old man's eye out.
column2726: The man was well known to be very quiet and not at all ill-tempered; and when he asked that the table should not be shaken because of his tea--this boy sprang to his feet and, without a word, poked the old man's eye out.
column2727: A cruel, unfeeling action of this kind would never enter the mind of a full-grown man, however great a bully he might be; only an impulsive, irresponsible youth of this kind would do such a deed.
column2728: In some lodging-houses the manager will not let beds to more than two of these half boys and half men, for he knows from experience the trouble they make; and that old and quiet lodgers will fear them so much that they will go elsewhere.
column2729: For these young bullies have no sympathy with age or affliction, and it would not be well for a blind man to expect them to use restraint and humour him in everything.
column2730: They feel the strength of manhood coming on them, and they do not know what to do with it.
column2731: All these lads are out of steady employment and doing a few odd jobs often too light for them, and their growing strength is not getting sufficient use.
column2732: So, when they are standing at street corners, they are always eager for action, and the man that takes notice of their insults or missiles, will most likely soon be in a pitiful state.
column2733: It is these sober young bullies that smoke cigarettes at street corners, and not full-grown bullies in public houses, that a stranger has to fear.
column2734: The latter make enough noise, when they are going home at night, singing or fighting among themselves, but they seldom interfere with strangers.
column2735: But the young bullies, that are neither boys nor men, allow their animal spirits full play, and are only too eager to interfere with anyone.
column2736: XII American and English Beggars A man that has camped out much in the open air must always after be on the look-out for places suitable for camps.
column2737: So whenever I cross over a country bridge, under which runs a narrow stream, I often stand and look along the stream's banks in quest of a shady tree to sit out of the sun, happy to know that I can seek shelter under the bridge in case of rain.
column2738: Yes, there is plenty of dry wood for cooking purposes, and fresh water in a delightful state of activity, and the bridge to be my shelter in a storm--such is an ideal spot for a camp.
column2739: If I find this place in England there will be seen a sign that trespassers will be prosecuted, and for that reason the spot remains, and will remain, in its virgin state, untrodden by the foot of man.
column2740: But if I am in America I shall not see that sign, and therefore at once take possession, and I know well that I shall find embers of past fires, and a quiet search in the adjoining bush will bring to light the rude cooking utensils used by former occupants.
column2741: Alas for the strict regulations that govern this overcrowded land of ours!
column2742: If I have a houseboat I cannot move it without first apprising the river commissioners and having their consent to do so.
column2743: If I use a bit of wild woodland, untilled, and without fruit, cattle, or any other money-making stock, I am ordered to put out my fire by a man who can produce papers to show his authority.
column2744: Our liberties extend so far, and no farther, and we are not free to periodically enjoy the sweet open-air life of our ancestors.
column2746: Even if I own a cottage, with a piece of land, and have my title deeds to show for it, the sporting gentry can over-run it after a fox.
column2747: And, although compensation can be claimed for damage done to a field of turnips, I would be laughed at for a mad eccentric if I asked compensation for the rude trampling of my garden flowers.
column2748: But things are different in America, and, for that matter, in all new countries.
column2749: The woods belong to all comers and all that is found therein--sunny glades and shady trees, birds, springs, flowers, and squirrels.
column2750: No stranger to demand by what authority I camp there; and any respectable stranger that chanced to come near would no more think of entering my camp without an invitation than he would of entering my town house.
column2751: For in America it is customary for all classes of families to forsake their homes for a few days in the summer and camp out, sometimes only on the outskirts of the town and within easy distance of their homes.
column2752: These outings cost little, are healthy, and the whole family are together; and it only requires care that the smallest and youngest does not roll into the rill and get drowned--a rill that in certain parts is often as much as three inches deep.
column2753: But the man to whom this kind of life properly belongs is the American tramp.
column2754: His camp is to be found on the outskirts of every town, either on the northern, southern, eastern, or western end; and it is not uncommon to find a camp at each end.
column2755: The camp is his great institution, a club and private residence; from which he sallies on his begging expeditions, and to which he returns with his spoils; at which place he cooks, eats, reads, discourses, takes his afternoon nap, washes his clothes, or discards them for others lately acquired.
column2756: There they build their fires near running water, around which they sit at night and relate their day's experience.
column2757: The Baltimore Kid was that morning offered work, but had taken the insult good-naturedly, having retired without wasting time in excuses.
column2758: His companions laugh heartily at this, to imagine the Kid at work, and Philadelphia Baldy enquires philosophically, "What is work, boys?"
column2759: These men are all downrighters; that is, none of them make any pretence of selling cheap goods, but beg food and money straight.
column2760: Begging in England is certainly a fine art, and it is very difficult to live except beggars carry in their hands pins, needles, laces, wire goods, artificial flowers, a tin whistle, accordion, etc., and hide themselves as beggars behind these things.
column2761: Even then they make very little, if they are indifferent to the art of begging; for it is not sufficient to sell a farthing pair of laces for a penny, but to tell such a pitiful story that the buyer--out of pity for your misfortunes--returns the laces after paying for them, and occasionally adds a piece of cake to her kindness.
column2762: That is the real art of begging; and the man who cannot make threepence or more out of a farthing stud, a farthing's worth of pins, or a farthing pair of laces, is no more than a very small and unsuccessful business man, and is not worthy the name of a beggar.
column2763: The art of begging is not nearly so fine in America as it is in England, for there is no necessity in that country of making any pretence of selling; and money, food, and clothes are to be had for the mere asking.
column2764: The American beggar uses few words, for he knows well that whoever can afford will give, and he is too cunning to employ pitiful tales, which would be apt to encumber him with a quantity of common bread and butter, from people who have nothing ready cooked.
column2765: For this reason he pockets the few trifles in the way of sandwiches and cakes, and proceeds leisurely from house to house, until he is seated at the table like a Christian, and supplied with a hot meal, which is the end he seeks, and which seldom fails.
column2766: After which he returns to the camp, unloads his pockets of their trifles, and reads, and talks with his companions until supper-time, which we in England call tea-time.
column2767: Then he takes a tin can to the spring, places it full of water on the fire, and makes hot coffee, with which he devours his trifles.
column2768: He has had a hot breakfast and a hot dinner, and he is quite satisfied to eat one meal a day that only consists of cold meat, bread and butter, and a cake or two.
column2769: The American tramp sits comfortably at his camp fire, waiting the sound of a shrill whistle, or bell, which proclaims dinner-time.
column2770: Five or ten minutes after hearing this sound, he dances out of camp, humming a tune, and goes begging as though he were going to a wedding, and he is often served with a hot dinner before the man of business can finish his own.
column2771: But the poor English beggar makes funeral steps between meals, and asks for a mouthful of bread.
column2772: The American beggar pulls the door bell, and makes himself heard the first time; but the English beggar timidly uses his knuckles on the back door, many times before he is heard.
column2773: The American beggar rides on trains from town to town, but the English beggar tramps the hard roads.
column2774: The English beggar explains his wants to the servants and children, but the American beggar asks to see the mistress.
column2775: The American beggar, feeling himself a proud and free citizen, addresses himself familiarly to anyone; but the English beggar, feeling himself a despised outcast, will not speak except in want, or when he is first spoken to.
column2776: Yes, begging in America is fascinating, without doubt; and it is no wonder that the tribe has increased to such an enormous extent.
column2777: But in England it is such a fine art, and requires so much persistence to attain small ends, that there are few that can master it thoroughly.
column2778: What did Chicago Fatty do when he visited Liverpool on a cattle-boat?
column2779: He asked forty men for a copper towards paying for a fourpenny bed, and the result was twopence threefarthings--and the workhouse.
column2780: Begging in England nearly broke his heart and so sickened him that, when he returned to his own country, New York Slim and Boston Shorty had to feed him, as though he were a babe in arms, until he recovered sufficiently to help himself.
column2781: Blacky--the half-breed--who claimed to have enough Indian blood in his veins to make himself dangerous if he had cause--Blacky, I say, thought that Fatty would never again be a good beggar.
column2782: It certainly seemed, for a long time, that this would be the case, until one morning Fatty went out and begged his breakfast, but nothing more.
column2783: He went out again, begged a meal, a shirt, and a handkerchief.
column2784: In a day or two this good beggar--almost ruined by a trip to England--began to take a man with him to carry the spoils, as he had been accustomed to do in his prosperous days.
column2785: XIII Beggars' Slang Women, strange to say, take far more pride than men in using slang.
column2786: To listen to two women relating their experiences in a country common lodging-house is almost to hear a foreign language.
column2787: I cannot think that a woman takes more pleasure or near so much, in a wandering, homeless life, as a man.
column2788: Nevertheless, it is plain that women affect to enjoy it more.
column2789: In fact, I have often heard women boast of being on the road a certain number of years, but have seldom heard a man take the trouble to mention such a thing.
column2790: In spite of this, one thing proves that a woman of this kind speaks false and is trying to make the best of a strange life.
column2791: It is this--when she and her husband are settled in a lodging-house, he is always the first to propose taking to the road again, and the woman always inclines to postpone that event for another day.
column2792: If they are old travellers, they are sure to see in every lodging-house others they have met before, and that is why the woman would like to settle for a few days; but the man, being less sociable, is more restless.
column2793: What surprised me, when I first went on the road in England, was to see how sociable these people were, calling each other by some kind of name, as though they had lived there always, or had always travelled together.
column2794: It was some time before I discovered the reason of this.
column2795: Naturally, my first impression had been that a score or more men and women would meet, coming from different towns, and not know each other; and, after having a night's lodging, would continue their travels and perhaps never meet again.
column2796: But, to my surprise, I often entered a lodging-house where there would be a dozen lodgers or more, and I would be the only stranger there.
column2797: I soon got to know that these temporary lodgers had been beggars for years, and one of them could not possibly appear in a lodging-house without meeting others he had met before.
column2798: The reason of this is that most beggars have their favourite counties, which they seldom leave, and if they do not meet in a lodging-house they meet on the road.
column2799: There are hundreds of beggars that work in a circle around London, within ten, fifteen, twenty, or thirty miles; and, seeing that some of them have been doing this for years, it is not surprising that they recognize one another at the different lodging-houses.
column2800: The second night that I was on the road in England, I went to a lodging-house in Luton and, of course, expected to find a dozen or more strangers to the town, like myself, who would sleep there one night, part the next morning, and never meet again.
column2801: But when I entered the kitchen I found a number of lodgers, men and women, who were calling each other by name--Brum, Norfolk, Sal, and Liz.
column2802: In fact, I was the only stranger present, and yet all these were wanderers, and never travelled together.
column2803: Very few of these were downright beggars, but had some trifle to sell.
column2804: Their pride was in being able to beg under the disguise of selling.
column2805: I never knew that beggars had so many slang words until I had been on the road for several weeks and was in Gloucestershire.
column2806: I had heard a number of strange words, but had not heard any sustained conversation.
column2807: But one day, when walking from Stroud into Gloucester, I happened to meet a real beggar.
column2808: It was close on evening and, as I had done well enough to be able to pay for my bed, I was making all speed to a lodging-house.
column2809: Soon I heard quick steps behind me, and was overtaken by another beggar, who walked at my side and entered into conversation.
column2810: Hearing where I was going to he asked me if I knew Gloucester and, if so, what lodging-house I intended to go to.
column2811: Telling him that I did not know that town, and would have to enquire about a lodging-house, he at once offered to conduct me to one, saying that there were several and that he knew the best.
column2812: I was very glad of this offer, and we trudged along in pleasant conversation.
column2813: Now, this man's conversation was as pure from slang as mine, which surprised me, for he was an old beggar, though perhaps not over thirty-five years of age.
column2814: I may as well say here what kind of begging the man was doing at this time of his life, which became known to me after, for I had his company for several days.
column2815: He had taken advantage of the South African War, saying that he had been invalided home.
column2816: As you may guess, he was a fraud, and had never been in the Army.
column2817: This man carried forged letters, supposed to be recommendations from officers under whom he had served.
column2818: With these he called at the houses of old, retired military men and others, sending the papers in by a servant.
column2819: All he had to do was to find out the names and addresses of these old officers, one or two of whom are to be found near every little hamlet or village.
column2820: This was not difficult, for he knew the counties of Gloucestershire and Monmouthshire well; and every lodging-house has a town beggar who can give names, addresses, histories, and describe the position and appearance of houses wanted.
column2821: Very well, then, this beggar would go to the house of one of these rich, retired military officers and, when the servant opened the door, would give her his papers to be taken to her master.
column2822: In a few moments she would return with the papers and probably a shilling or a two-shilling piece on top of them.
column2823: As can be expected, this man had several times been so closely questioned that he had compromised himself, and had been threatened with prison as a fraud.
column2824: However, he was so bold, and knew his subject so well, that this had not often happened.
column2825: At the houses of rich civilians he was safer, but, naturally, they would not give so much as a gentleman who had served in the Army.
column2826: At this stage of his career this ambitious beggar did not often call at small houses for pennies, but large houses for silver.
column2827: I soon found out his history, for he seemed nothing loth to talk of himself.
column2828: He had taken to the road early, not having worked for a living since he was a youth.
column2829: In those early days he had worked for a printer, and had caught his little finger in one of the machines.
column2830: This accident did not handicap him in any way, and was no excuse for his leaving at once and becoming a beggar.
column2831: In after years he never forgot to call two or three times a year on the printer, who had a fine business, and hold up his little finger; an action which won him a piece of silver every time.
column2832: It was by his little finger that he proved his identity--that he was the boy that had worked for the printer in years gone.
column2833: It was when I heard this man and another in conversation that I first became surprised at the number of slang words that beggars use.
column2834: As I have said, he used no slang during our walk, but we had no sooner entered a lodging-house and he met a beggar he knew, than his language was completely changed.
column2835: When we were entering the city of Gloucester, he had called at a big, red house, which he told me was always good for twopence and a parcel of food, no more or less.
column2836: He explained to me that he would not go out of his way for it, but thought he may as well have it, seeing that he was passing the house.
column2837: It was in relation to this house that he spoke to his companion, using the following words: "I called at the big, red kennel and got my eight farthings and scrand."
column2838: To which the other said: "That kennel never yet failed a needy."
column2839: This conversation quite interested me; kennel was house; eight farthings was twopence; scrand was food; and needy was beggar.
column2840: Beggars in London lodging-houses use the slang of lodging-houses, and not of the road.
column2841: They always say "fourpence for 'doss' or 'kip'"; but true, wandering beggars say "sixteen farthings for the feather."
column2842: The former say "chuck" or "tommy," when they refer to food; but the latter say "scrand."
column2843: The wandering beggar says "skimish" for drink, but city beggars say "bouse."
column2844: The word "mouch" is not often heard outside towns, for wandering beggars say "call."
column2845: For instance, "it is a good road to call," or "there is plenty of calling"; meaning that the road has many houses.
column2847: When a beggar asks another if a certain town is good, the former is asked, "What is your lay?"
column2848: or, "It depends on your lay"; meaning: "What do you do--sell, sing, or go in for downright begging?"
column2849: What always surprised me was to hear old beggars use the dignified word "travellers," in preference to beggars, needies, or callers.
column2850: When they are talking of a good town, they say "it is good for travellers."
column2851: And if they see a selfish lodger monopolizing the fire, or not making room on the table for others, they say "he's not a true traveller."
column2852: The following are a few slang words used by beggars:-- Beggars--travellers or needies; house--kennel; on the road--on the toe be; talk--patter; sing--griddle or chant; fourpence--sixteen farthings; bed--feather; soup--shackles; profit--bunts; food--scrand; drink--skimish; pins--pricks; needles--sharps; laces--stretchers; scissors--snips; combs--rakes; spectacles--glims; pictures--smuts.
column2853: XIV Bony's Wits We called him "Bony," because he was all skin and bones.
column2854: This condition must have been constitutional, for it certainly was not from too much activity, seeing that he went by tram on his expeditions, and returned in the same manner.
column2855: Again, it could not have been for want of good food, for Bony was a good beggar, and scorned to sit down to a bread-and-butter meal.
column2856: He was also a good ale drinker, and, if his bones had been capable of growing flesh, it is very likely that ale would have helped to bring about that result.
column2857: He was always heard to be humming a tune--often an old familiar hymn--so that it could not have been mental worry that fastened his skin so tight to his bones.
column2858: No, his condition must have been constitutional.
column2859: I had known Bony for several months, and now that I had fallen on evil times, and would in less than a week be compelled to travel the country, I thought that perhaps my friend Bony could give me a few hints, that would assist me in procuring food and lodgings.
column2860: Therefore, one evening, after he had had tea and was emptying his pockets of tram fare tickets, I invited him outside to have a drink.
column2861: This invitation he would accept only on one condition--that I would then have another with him.
column2862: Having no objection to this, we left the house together, and were soon comfortably seated in the warm corner of an alehouse.
column2863: After we had had the second drink, I began by asking Bony what he considered to be the most essential gift for a good beggar.
column2864: Without immediately answering this question, he called for two more drinks, and, after they had been served, and he had praised the colour of the ale, he began.
column2865: "The one thing, above all others, is to have ready wit, so as to take advantage of opportunities that come and go in a second, and give no time for second thoughts.
column2866: For instance," continued Bony, "when I was in the country some time ago, I called at a house for a glass of water.
column2867: I did not think that there was the least prospect of getting tea, as the time was between meals; therefore, being dry, I asked for water.
column2868: A little girl answered the door, and after hearing my wants, returned to tell her mother.
column2869: 'Certainly,' said the mother; 'he could have had a cup of tea, if he had asked for it, but perhaps he prefers water.'
column2870: These words were said so low that they could not have been heard, except by a man who had all his wits about him.
column2871: So, when the little girl returned with the water, I told her, in a voice loud enough to be heard in the house, that I was really sick for a hot drink of tea, but that it was not the tea-hour, and I must be content with water.
column2872: I lifted the glass of water slowly to my lips, so slowly that the lady had heard my remark, weighed it for a second, and then promised a cup of tea, before my lips had touched the water.
column2873: And, of course, the kind lady asked me if I would like a piece of cake to eat with the tea.
column2874: You see," continued Bony, "how a man needs to keep his wits at work.
column2875: Nine beggars out of ten would not have heard or, having heard, would have accepted the water and cursed themselves inwardly that they had not asked for tea."
column2876: I was so interested in this recital that I called for two more drinks.
column2877: "Again," said Bony, after praising the colour of the liquor, "I happened one day to see a lady and gentleman approaching, and determined to accost them.
column2878: As they drew near, I saw a crust of bread on the road, and that was my chance.
column2879: Casting a hasty look behind me, as though I did not wish to be seen, I stooped, picked up the crust, and pretended to take a bite; and then I feigned seeing them for the first time, and hastily concealed the crust in my clothes.
column2880: That little trick worked out well, for the lady gave me sixpence, and the gentleman gave me a shilling, and not a word passed between us."
column2881: Bony now called for two more drinks, and, after remarking that the colour of the ale was getting no worse, continued his experiences.
column2882: "One day," he began, "I was walking the high-road when a gentleman on a bicycle ran into me, knocking me down and throwing himself into the hedge.
column2883: It did me no harm at all, for I was soon on my feet and going to his assistance.
column2884: All my consideration was for him, thinking he might be seriously hurt.
column2885: To my surprise he was not, but much shaken.
column2886: After he had sufficiently recovered his breath he looked towards me and said: 'Are you hurt, my poor man?'
column2887: Quick as a flash it occurred to me that I was, and I began to limp painfully.
column2890: I mentioned a town four miles away, and said that I had no doubt but what I could walk there, but that on my reaching that place it would probably be a week or more before I would be able to work, even if I could get it, and that I had no means whatever to keep myself idle in lodgings for that length of time.
column2891: 'Are you sure that you can walk there without assistance?'
column2894: 'I am very sorry for you,' said he, 'and if this can be of help you are heartily welcome to it'--with that he placed in my hand a gold half-sovereign.
column2895: Telling him I was ashamed to take advantage of what was no more than a pure accident, but that my straitened circumstances compelled me to do so, and saying how glad I was that he received no hurt, I left him, and began to limp painfully on my way.
column2896: I had not got many yards, when he was again at my side, and, giving me his card, asked me to write in the course of a day or two, and let him know of my progress.
column2897: And, you may depend on it," said Bony, with a grin, "that I did write on the third day, saying that I was doing well--for I feared a personal visit from him, with a doctor--and that in three or four more days I would be in a fit condition to work.
column2898: He wrote a very kind letter in answer, with a postal order enclosed for ten shillings.
column2899: Of course, I still keep the gentleman's address, and call on him occasionally, and I always receive a good meal and a shilling, and sometimes clothes as well."
column2901: After the drinks were brought, and Bony had passed his usual comment on the colour, he went on to tell how necessary it was to keep a civil tongue on all occasions.
column2902: "One day," said he, "a little man whom I could have crushed in my arms, called me all the big, idle vagabonds he could think of.
column2903: But I allowed him free speech, knowing that he would be so pleased to see a man timid, who was almost twice his size, that he would at last become generous out of sheer delight, and such was the case.
column2904: "On another occasion I called at a lady's house, and received sixpence for my trouble, which was the first bit of silver that I had seen for several days, and for which I thanked her from the bottom of my heart.
column2905: She stood at the door, as I was leaving, and said: 'Poor, unfortunate man!'
column2906: 'Madam,' I answered, returning, for I was almost at the gate--'Madam,' I said, 'I am thankful to say that I am not half so unfortunate as my poor brother, who has weak intellect.'
column2907: 'Oh, I am deeply moved to hear that,' said the kind lady, 'and will give you another sixpence for your poor brother.'
column2908: "These incidents," continued Bony, "prove how necessary it is to have quick wits.
column2909: Only last week, within a mile of this alehouse, I got a two-shilling piece from a man in a very simple manner.
column2910: I had been calling at the alehouses all the evening, and was returning home with three or four shillings worth of coppers in my pockets, not to mention the pleasant effect on my system of several free drinks of good strong ale.
column2911: "When I was on the bridge, I had my attention drawn to the sound of voices in a small boat running under the bridge, which made me pause and, leaning on the balustrade, look down into the river.
column2912: This was not done so much from curiosity, but that I was beginning to feel tired.
column2913: At that hour of the night the bridge was almost deserted, and I was just on the point of moving on when a gentle hand fell on my shoulder, and a voice kind and earnest said: 'Don't, I entreat you, destroy your immortal soul; don't, my dear brother, plunge into the dark waters.'
column2914: I must confess that, for one moment, my wits entirely deserted me, and if the speaker had not still held me in his grasp, and continued his persuasion, I should have been foolish enough to explain that such was not my intention.
column2915: But I soon recovered from my astonishment, and allowed him to lead me over the bridge.
column2916: When we stood safely on the other side, he asked me what could be done to save me from self-destruction.
column2917: Of course I had by this time recovered my wits, and told him a harrowing tale of misfortune, which earned me that gentleman's pity to the extent of two shillings.
column2918: After receiving my promise that I would live and face misfortune like a man, he left me, and I, well pleased at such good fortune, sought my lodgings."
column2919: These incidents, as related by Bony, proved to me how necessary it was for a man to be quick-witted, if he would excel as a beggar.
column2920: After several more drinks we left for home, for the colour of the ale did not seem so good as when we first entered the place.
column2921: XV Favouritism One of the worst enemies to a poor man in a common lodging-house is favouritism.
column2922: I have seen hundreds of instances where a man could be comparatively happy were it not for a prejudiced porter or kitchen-man.
column2923: I was not long in one large house before I saw this, in the case of a porter, a bully, and a gentleman.
column2924: The bully was drunk and going from place to place, insulting everyone, especially those that were better dressed than himself.
column2925: Few of the lodgers took any notice of him, until he came to one that had on a silk hat and a frock-coat.
column2926: This man lost his temper and told the bully that he had no right to interfere with men that wanted to be quiet.
column2927: He was in the act of uttering this dignified rebuke when a porter came and stood before them.
column2930: The well-dressed man began a quiet explanation, but the bully interrupted him; so the former stopped at once, thinking he would have a chance to speak when the other had done.
column2931: "You had better go to bed," said the porter to the bully, "and"--addressing the well-dressed man--"you come with me to the office."
column2932: When they arrived at the office the porter said a few words to the clerk, and the latter returned the well-dressed man his money, telling him to go elsewhere for a bed.
column2933: There were very few lodgers in the house that did not know the meaning of this injustice.
column2934: The well-dressed man was a gentleman, and, in spite of his low circumstances, did not forget it.
column2935: He looked on the porters as his servants and, when he met them in the street, never invited them to have a drink.
column2936: Again, there was no necessity for him to rise early, whereas the bully gave a porter sixpence a week to be called every morning.
column2937: I was not many weeks at this house before I thoroughly understood these matters.
column2938: One night, when I was going to bed, a man, who was quite tipsy, wanted to detain me in conversation, and I was doing my best to escape, when up the stairs ran one of the porters.
column2941: "You haven't to get up in the morning, and others have."
column2942: This porter had not heard my voice, and he could see that the other man was drunk, but of course he set upon me because the other paid to be called early.
column2943: This porter became more civil after, which I could well understand.
column2944: I used to tip the bath-porter twice a week, and seeing that they shared their tips--one being in a better position than another to get them--so, no doubt, the bath-porter had pointed me out for civility.
column2945: There was no appeal against these porters.
column2946: They allowed some men to do things which they got others turned out for, and it was no use trying to explain oneself to the manager.
column2947: Although I believe that he was a very just man, he could not do otherwise than trust his men, say what they would.
column2948: In fact, I believe that this manager was so just that he would have dismissed a porter at once if he could prove that that porter was prejudiced against any of the lodgers and having them turned out for his own spite.
column2949: When I left this house and went to one that was in the hands of Christianity, I found the same state of things.
column2950: The Christian officer behind the food-bar gave thick slices of bread to those he liked and thin slices to others; and he skimmed the top of the soup for those he did not like or was indifferent to, but his ladle went to the bottom for favourites.
column2951: The consequence was that some lodgers would have hot, greasy water, while others would have thick soup that was almost Irish stew.
column2952: It was well worth while to bribe this man with a drink of whisky.
column2953: One artful lodger did better than that, as he told me in confidence.
column2954: This man behind the bar was not supposed to take money for food; the lodgers had to buy tin checks at the office, with which they paid for what they wanted.
column2955: But my artful dodger would go to the bar when no one was there to see, put a penny down and receive what he asked for.
column2956: The officer behind the bar would quickly take this money, in spite of the strict rules and the severe discipline of that Christian army.
column2957: But if a newly-arrived stranger put money down, that officer would shout, loud enough to be heard at the office--"We don't take money behind the bar; go to the office for checks."
column2958: When I first went to that lodging-house I had a small bundle, in which were an extra shirt, a pair of stockings, a brush, razor, and a few other articles.
column2959: Seeing that all the lockers were in use, I had no other option than to ask the kitchen-man to look after it, for which I gave him twopence, although he had no claim to anything.
column2960: Whether the bar-man saw this deed or was told about it I cannot say, but I know that I soon became one of his favourites.
column2961: I may as well say here that, judging by my later experience at this place, it was well that I did tip the kitchen-man, for he often took a notion to sell the things in his charge, only holding such property sacred as had been tipped for.
column2962: And yet on a Sunday afternoon these two, the bar-man and the kitchen-man, would be seen one on each side of the captain, and heard crowing like two cocks that challenge each other.
column2963: When the captain prayed one would shout "Hallelujah!"
column2964: The other would no sooner hear this than he would stretch his neck, grow red in the face, and cry fiercely, "Praise the Lord!"
column2965: These doings not only amused the lodgers, but the principals as well; for, judging by their faces, it was all they could do to keep from laughing outright.
column2966: I was at one lodging-house where the beds were clean, the cooking accommodation good, and, according to the small rent to be paid, everything as could be desired.
column2967: But this place was also spoilt by a common kitchen-man, who made things uncomfortable for all those that did not give him either money, ale, or tobacco.
column2968: This man would build the fire up when a disfavoured lodger was in the middle of cooking a meal, and then sweep the dusty floor when he was at his meals.
column2969: Of course, these things had to be done, so that there was no use in reporting him to the manager.
column2970: Still, there was no reason why he should make more dust around _your_ food, and take longer under your table than others, and build up the fire before there was actual need of it.
column2971: Yes, there was a reason--known to himself--you never gave him anything.
column2972: This kitchen-man upset me so much that I agreed with another lodger to share a furnished bed sitting-room.
column2974: I was soon back in the same lodging-house, in spite of its crazy kitchen-man.
column2975: The man with whom I shared the room disappeared suddenly, and when I heard his character I did likewise.
column2976: Without my knowledge, he borrowed of the landlady; and the vicar came to me saying that my friend had told him that I was on the point of starvation, and got a shilling on that account.
column2977: Not knowing what else he had done in the neighbourhood, I could not feel at ease.
column2978: Therefore, not having the courage to give my landlady notice, I put on all my clothes--two pairs of trousers, two shirts, a waistcoat, two jackets, and an overcoat--and crept to the front door.
column2979: Seeing that I had filled the pockets with a number of small articles, it did not surprise me much to find great difficulty in moving.
column2980: I do not know what I would have done if the landlady had been at the front door, because I could not have squeezed past her, and she could not have helped seeing that I was as broad as I was long.
column2981: What upset me was that she had said she would not have let the room to him, but had trusted my face.
column2982: However, I did not owe her any rent, and if I ever meet her when I am better off I will give her a sovereign.
column2983: I have seen this favouritism even in prison.
column2984: It came under my notice in an American jail, where I had to serve fifteen days, and I was as innocent as a new-born babe.
column2985: All the prisoners were in one long room, with cells on each side, in which they slept at night.
column2986: At the end of the room there was a square hole in the wall, which had a slide; and it was through this hole that the prisoners received their meals.
column2987: When I went for my first meal, I could see the face of the old cook--who was a prisoner--and was rather surprised to see him nod and smile, as though he knew me.
column2988: This smile was followed by a large plate of food, much more than others.
column2989: Perhaps the old prisoner-cook thought he saw in me a fellow-prisoner in some other jail, and he may have been right, for I had been in many others; or perhaps I resembled a son of his.
column2990: Whatever it was, it was quite clear that he did not give me the plate that came to my turn, but kept one apart.
column2991: XVI A Law to Suppress Vagrancy We are all deeply interested in any scheme that proposes to suppress the workhouse tramp, who has not only become a pest to the ratepayers of our country--who support so many workhouses--but has also brought the true beggar to his wits' end to earn a livelihood.
column2992: To all true beggars, who systematically pursue their calling, the workhouse tramp has become as much of an eyesore as he is to the working classes of our land.
column2993: This vagrant--whom the Law seems so much to disfavour--is, without doubt, a madman; but, if rightly dealt with, is not, I believe, incapable of being cured.
column2994: That he will not work to maintain himself in a good home, with food, bed, and clothing; and that he prefers to break so many hundredweight of stone--a heavy task to be performed on a bowl of thin gruel, or limited supply of bread and water--that he prefers to do the latter is sufficient proof of the man's mental deficiencies.
column2995: To turn such a one into a useful member of society would be to confer as great a benefit on him as on the ratepayer of this country.
column2996: Sometimes he cavils at the injustice of such tasks, and is sent to prison for refusing to perform them; or, the task being done, he tears in shreds his old rags, thinking to obtain a new outfit at the ratepayers' expense.
column2997: For this he is also sentenced; for, though he has without doubt earned a cheap suit of clothes, he is by no means entitled to any--not even to a pair of stockings.
column2998: Of course, our workhouses are not hotels, neither are they rough boarding camps, so that the ratepayers are, after supporting them, far from being relieved, seeing that this tramp is forced to make personal application for more food, or starve.
column2999: But what I mention is that this man works hard and gets little for his trouble, and that he could be made a useful member of society and obtain more necessities--aye, even luxuries--by performing far less labour.
column3000: For my own class, whom I as a proud member represent, the outlook is indeed serious.
column3001: Only yesterday an incident occurred which will, I believe, explain how the workhouse tramp stands in the light of a true beggar.
column3002: I had seen a gentleman approaching in the distance, and had in my own mind resolved that he should not pass without first hearing my story.
column3003: Being a clean man, keeping myself well shaved and brushed, I had very little fear of disgusting him by my personal appearance, making him seek to escape my importunities.
column3005: During my narrative he stood smiling for a minute or two, for, you may depend, I gave him no time for excuse or question.
column3006: At last I finished, and stood waiting the result of my confessions, which had been unusually pathetic.
column3007: "My good fellow," said he, "I have just given the last threepence to another unfortunate man, who apparently was in greater need of assistance; I am very sorry."
column3008: There was no other course than to continue my journey, for it was impossible to talk money out of an empty pocket.
column3009: In five minutes after I was hailed by a voice from the hedgerow, and, looking in that direction, saw the most ragged man I had ever set eyes on, with his matted hair a foot long.
column3010: "Did you meet a gentleman on your way?"
column3012: "I did," said I; "and what of that?"
column3013: "That man," said this ragged tramp, "was a thoroughbred.
column3014: He saw me sitting here and, without a word from either of us, he emptied his pocket into my hand"--saying which he withdrew his fingers from the palm of his hand and disclosed to my view three pennies.
column3015: Now, here was a workhouse tramp--for he was no other, or he would at once have stepped into the road and accosted the gentleman--receiving unsolicited alms; and I, who earned my living by the use of my tongue, must suffer in consequence.
column3016: But the worst charge to be made against this class of vagrant is that he does, by reason of his workhouse experience, look on common bread as a luxury, and receives it with so many thanks, from the various people on whom he calls, that these people soon become impressed with the notion that dry bread can be applied with satisfaction as a poultice in every case.
column3017: In this way he spoils the road for good beggars who, not going into workhouses, need coppers for their beds, and who always make use of that indefinite term "something to eat," but would not, on any account, remind their hearers of "a crust of dry bread."
column3018: Again, he spoils true beggars by his lack of system.
column3019: A workhouse tramp has not that energy and concentration which is required for success.
column3020: Sometimes he knocks at the first door in a street, after which he walks to the next street, where he knocks at the middle house, or perhaps the last; and, when the true beggar comes after him, and beholds this timid fool running from side to side of a street, he knows very well that the street is being spoiled, for he cannot tell exactly where the other has been.
column3021: In a case of this kind it is best for the true, systematic beggar to go at once into the next street, and it is not unlikely then but what he will soon recognize the workhouse tramp at its other end.
column3022: If the true beggar had no other system than this--running here and there to chance houses, at the sign of a green gate, or a church announcement in a front window--he would soon be so confused as to where he had, or had not been, that a good-sized town would in a very short time become useless to him.
column3023: To a true beggar the workhouse tramp is a mystery.
column3024: The former cannot understand how the latter can perform such stone-breaking feats on a bread-and-water diet, and he wonders where lies the fascination of such a life.
column3025: He, himself, though he may rise penniless in the morning, has confidence in the day's fulfilment, and he sometimes meets with a surprise in the shape of a piece of silver.
column3026: Sometimes he calls at an alehouse, where a merry party is in full song, and to them he offers to render harmony, provided they will favour him with a collection.
column3027: This proposition is invariably favoured, and the true beggar then flatters the loudest and most persistent singer of the party by giving him his cap to make that collection.
column3028: Of course, he is offered a glass of ale before he begins, and during the intervals between verses he is not forgotten.
column3029: As a rule he is not a sweet singer, but his voice is thought to be remarkable, especially if he sings a familiar air with a good chorus.
column3030: If his hearers are half blind with drink, and incapable of using their feet, it is well for the true beggar to end his song with a dance.
column3031: The most awkward shuffling will appear to them as the movements of lightning.
column3032: This kindness on his part calls forth extra coppers and a more liberal supply of ale.
column3033: Now, what happens to shame this true beggar, and to spoil him in the act of earning a livelihood?
column3034: Why, one of these ragged workhouse tramps walks in and begs a drink of water.
column3036: mark you, when this true beggar is earning ale and money!
column3037: Then what wonder that such a man should become an eyesore to all classes of men?
column3038: He has no self-respect, for, whereas he often passes stores and houses without calling at them, he is nothing backward in making known his wants to true beggars.
column3039: For sometimes he by accident picks up sixpence, works for it, or receives it unsolicited, with which he pays for his bed at a lodging-house.
column3040: Then he, without shame or self-respect, begs tea of one, sugar of another, and makes himself a pest to all those who with an independent spirit do their begging outside instead of inside a lodging-house, as he does.
column3041: It is fortunate for us that he does not get these sixpences often, and that he is compelled almost night after night to the workhouse for accommodation.
column3042: The question is not altogether without humour, for these workhouse tramps actually call themselves our brothers on the road.
column3043: They stop us familiarly on our way, and ask for information of workhouses, as though we were one of themselves.
column3044: One advises me not to go to a certain workhouse, for they will make me break stones all the day following, on a little dry bread and water.
column3045: As though I ever, for one moment, dreamed that such a lot would be mine!
column3046: "My good fellow," says I, "_lodging-houses_ are made for true beggars, and not workhouses."
column3047: For the above reasons I have become deeply interested in any scheme to improve the condition of the workhouse tramp, for, as I have said, he is not only a burden on the ratepayers of the country, but mars the success of all true beggars.
column3048: We are often, when in the act of begging money for our beds, told to go to the workhouse; which is owing to this workhouse tramp having communicated the intelligence that he would be satisfied with bread, and that he is not in need of money for a place to sleep, seeing that the workhouse can accommodate him.
column3049: For he becomes hardened to the indignities and heavy tasks set before him, and at last looks on such a cold, wretched place as a home, aye, even as a playground.
column3050: XVII Stubborn Invalids It is a pathetic sight to see men dying in a lodging-house, fighting against death day after day.
column3051: The few healthy men that are present are quite indifferent to life, and do not care if their health is impaired through breathing in the same room as a dozen consumptives.
column3052: These healthy men are so thoughtless of themselves that they offer their dying comrades saucers of tea, after which they drink with their own lips perhaps on the same place as their unfortunate fellows used.
column3053: I have offered many a one of these poor fellows a drink of tea, but was always very careful not to use the saucer after them.
column3054: When they wanted to return my kindness, and I did not like to wound their feelings by refusing them, I always took a clean saucer from the shelf, instead of using theirs.
column3055: I well remember one man, who was in a terrible condition for the last three months before he was carried to the hospital.
column3056: He was a man of about middle age, and his face was very white, and all day long he was coughing and spitting in the kitchen, with only enough strength in his body to take him to bed.
column3057: Although I sat with my back to him at meals, I could not help but hear the poor fellow, and could not help a feeling of revulsion.
column3058: In fact I began at last to look upon these consumptives as murderers who, by their stubbornness in not going to the hospital, were killing me and others with their breath.
column3059: Some of these men are in receipt of small pensions, or get a little assistance from relatives on the outside, and for this reason they die sooner; for they have more leisure than others--who must go out to earn a few pennies--at the coke fire.
column3060: Little Punch is dead, who might have lived for many more years, had he not been kept indoors so much by outside assistance.
column3061: In the spring this little fellow used to set off with his pack as a pedlar through the country, and when he returned at the end of summer was always in good condition, but was as bad as ever after a month in the lodging-house.
column3062: I believe he could have prolonged his life ten or fifteen years, if he had rambled both winter and summer.
column3063: These men fight against going to the hospital and sit dying day after day, making no complaint; until the lodging-house keeper is surprised some morning to find them lying in bed, without the strength to rise.
column3064: Even then they swear it is only temporary indisposition, and that after a few hours' rest they will be well again.
column3065: Then the doctor is called, and then comes the ambulance; but it is too late, for if the men do not die on the way, they die soon after they reach the hospital.
column3066: Poor old Peter saw himself wasting away.
column3067: He was six feet two inches in height, but thin enough to be exhibited.
column3068: He kept himself alive by a merry heart, but his hollow, spasmodic laughter refused to make his body fat.
column3069: Up to the last he affected great cheerfulness, but he could not cheat death any longer.
column3070: It was impossible to feel any revulsion against Peter; he did not spit about the place, and though he was always coughing, the poor fellow had no strength to make a disturbing noise: he could not be heard if you were not seated next him.
column3071: You could feel him cough, by the vibration of the bench or table, more often than you could hear him.
column3072: I also believe that he had consideration for others, knowing that a sick man can make himself unpleasant.
column3073: Peter did nothing but win pity and goodwill, and he returned it by endeavouring to be witty and cheerful.
column3074: Old Scotty Bill, the flycatcher, is also dead.
column3075: Consumption did not claim him as a victim, for he died at the advanced age of eighty-three, which was wonderful for a man who had spent the best part of his life in a lodging-house.
column3076: No doubt if he had lived under better conditions, he would have reached a hundred years with ease.
column3077: All his interest was in flies.
column3078: While other lodgers were discussing the abundance of fish in Billingsgate, Scotty could be seen counting the flies in the kitchen, as a sign whether he should go out with his fly-papers or not.
column3079: His language was very bad, and the last words he was heard to utter surprised even those who were accustomed to him, by their unusual weight and speed.
column3080: He was another stubborn invalid, and fought hard against going to the hospital.
column3081: His death was quite characteristic, and I can hardly imagine it otherwise.
column3082: He, like many another one, was found one morning helpless in bed, and the manager, seeing that he was very ill, in spite of his assurance to the contrary, sent at once for the doctor.
column3083: But when the latter arrived he and the manager were surprised to find the bed empty.
column3084: On making enquiries they were told that Scotty was in the kitchen, and it was there that they found the old man, reading a newspaper.
column3085: In spite of this the doctor saw that Scotty was not in good condition and tried to persuade him to go to bed, but this the old man swore that he would not do, and demanded some reason for such a request.
column3086: Then there was a whispered consultation between the manager and the doctor, and it was decided to send for the ambulance and have him taken to the hospital whether he would or no.
column3087: Now Scotty had lived in that same lodging-house for over thirty years, and for that reason was well known in the locality.
column3088: Therefore, when the ambulance arrived at the door, and a woman outside enquired of a lodger as to who the ambulance was for, and was told of Scotty Bill, the news soon spread abroad.
column3089: In less than five minutes between twenty and thirty women had assembled at the door.
column3090: These women of the slums were never very clean, and at the present time not one of them was in a fit condition to answer her own door; but they forgot this in their anxiety to see poor Scotty Bill and wish him a speedy recovery.
column3091: At last the old man appeared, and it staggered him to see the number of women at the door.
column3092: But when he heard them say, "Poor Bill"; and "Good luck to you, Scotty"; his fury knew no bounds.
column3093: Standing with one foot on the step, he paused, and then poured forth such a torrent of abuse that some of the women lost all sympathy with him and feebly retaliated.
column3094: He told them to go home and scrub their dirty faces, instead of coming there to watch him--and other things not fit to mention.
column3095: It was, they confessed, the worst language they had ever heard--and more than one of them was capable of using very strong words.
column3096: That was the last seen of Scotty Bill, and that was his dying speech, for he died on his arrival at the hospital.
column3097: I have heard of the death of a number more, men that lingered with such determination that it almost seems as if they have taken advantage of my absence and died; for they all seem to have gone one after the other since I left.
column3099: A terrible cough he had, but his face and neck were always like raw beef.
column3100: That one eye of his blazed with such power that I have often imagined the devil hard at work shovelling half a ton a coal a minute to supply its fierce light.
column3101: He also went off suddenly, walking the kitchen floor on Monday, and lying cold and dead on the following day.
column3102: "Rags" is also dead, the great drinker; the man who when abroad complained that whiskey made him totter, whereas it was an earthquake, that tumbled towers and made the firm-footed houses reel.
column3103: "The whiskey's in my legs," said "Rags," not knowing it was an earthquake.
column3104: "Monkey" Sam and the "Dodger" are both dead, and there is no doubt but what the Dodger's death hastened Sam's.
column3105: These two were the slyest pair that I have ever met.
column3106: I believe they understood each other's thoughts so well that when one's body itched the other could, without seeing his friend make a motion, scratch his own body at the exact place.
column3107: These two conversed by looks, and uttered very few words.
column3108: They were so well-matched and thought so much of one another, that something more than accident must have brought two such men together.
column3109: It was always clear that if anything happened to part them, neither one would seek friendship elsewhere.
column3110: I had seen all these men fighting against death day after day, but with such determination, that I can hardly believe the report that calls them dead; especially as there is no proof of lettered stone, seeing that they are all in paupers' graves.
column3111: All these poor invalids in common lodging-houses are under the impression that doctors, when they find that their patients have no friends, and cannot be thoroughly cured, kill them.
column3112: That is why they are so stubborn, and fight till they cannot move, before they will enter a hospital.
column3113: XVIII The Earnings of Beggars In writing of the earnings of beggars, I do not, of course, include common tramps, who are satisfied with barns, sheds, empty houses and workhouses; I write of true beggars, who have not lost their self-respect, and who, by their exertions, are as sure of a bed at night--although it is a different one--as other people that have homes.
column3114: If they sleep out of doors for a night or two in summer-time, they do so for pleasure; as people with homes will, when they sleep in hammocks under trees.
column3115: The true beggar does not shirk business, or save money by sleeping out; he still follows his calling and makes the price of his bed, but in this instance he spends the money on ale instead of stifling with so many others in a common lodging-house.
column3116: A good beggar is always ready to seize opportunities.
column3117: He will never allow a man to pass on who greets him pleasantly, or requires information, without either begging a copper, a pipeful of tobacco, or even a match.
column3118: I think now of that memorable morning in America, when Brum, an excellent beggar, saw a lady kiss a horse.
column3119: We were at a camp fire making coffee, when I was startled by the unusual eagerness of Brum's voice crying, "Look!"
column3120: Following the direction of his finger, I saw a lonely house on a hill, and near the house was a lady in riding-habit, and she was patting a horse's neck.
column3121: Seeing nothing unusual in this, I said, "What's the matter?"
column3122: "You were too late to see," answered Brum; "she kissed the horse!"
column3123: Now I am very fond of dumb creatures, and was therefore very pleased to see Brum moved so nobly by such an incident; but I was not allowed much time to congratulate myself on meeting with such a kind-hearted companion, for these were Brum's next words; "A lady that kisses a horse ought to be good for a piece of silver"; and before I could utter a word he had gone.
column3124: This incident plainly shows how quick a good beggar is to take advantage of an opportunity.
column3125: And Brum was right, for he not only returned with a piece of silver in his pocket, but also a parcel of food in his hand.
column3126: Of course, second-rate beggars in America earn more than first-rate beggars in Europe.
column3127: In any of the large cities of America an active beggar can obtain as much as three dollars in a couple of hours, even if he suspends work for a drink.
column3128: If a beggar is lucky enough to meet a gambler, he is just as likely to get a dollar as ten cents; in fact a number of beggars in that country make gambling places their haunts, for gamblers are well known to be superstitious, and few of them would think of refusing a beggar when on their way to the tables.
column3129: One of the quickest ways to make a good haul is to beg a fast overland train, when it must stop at some out-of-the-way place to take in water or coal.
column3130: A beggar often boards one of these trains and, taking off his hat--not out of respect, but to hold money--goes from passenger to passenger, from one end of the train to the other.
column3131: It is necessary to do business very quick, for the train does not stop long, and the conductor must be avoided.
column3132: If a man has the luck to get right through the train, he often has several dollars to his account.
column3133: In this country beggars have different methods.
column3134: No doubt singing hymns in Welsh towns and villages is one of the most profitable forms of begging.
column3135: The Welsh are very kind-hearted and, being a musical people, it is almost impossible for them to resist an appeal made by song.
column3136: When murder has been committed in a locality, you will always find a couple of men making a song of it in the streets, and they certainly do an excellent trade with their song-sheets.
column3137: Good voices are not so necessary as a distinct enunciation of particular words such as blood, axe, bolster, etc.
column3138: But even in less fortunate cases, when there has not even been an attempt at murder, beggars can still do well by singing well-known hymns.
column3139: There is one kind of beggar in Wales whose earnings can water the mouth of many a beggar in America.
column3140: We must approach this man very seriously, for he is forced to beg through a terrible affliction.
column3141: He is either totally blind or paralysed, and is to be seen standing or sitting near a pit's mouth on pay-day.
column3142: For this man the Welsh colliers have deep pity, and in a very short time they fill his hat with money, silver shining among the copper, although the contributors are only working men.
column3143: But for a man with a more simple affliction the colliers have, of course, far less sympathy.
column3144: A great number of colliers have suffered in accidents, and they are still working hard, so it cannot be expected that they will make much distinction between a man who has lost a finger and one that has not.
column3145: Beggars that play music do well, whether it is an organ, a cornet, a concertina, or a tin whistle.
column3146: Public-houses are the best stands, for men half drunk are always musically inclined.
column3147: These men also do well at private houses.
column3148: It seems strange to say that houses where a hungry man has difficulty in getting bread, can generally find a copper for a beggar musician.
column3149: The reason is very simple: music pleases the children, and, naturally, a mother is always willing to assist men that make the children laugh and dance, and the baby bounce in her arm.
column3150: In fact these men are not regarded as beggars, but entertainers.
column3151: If they know their business well, they will keep a sharp eye on the door and windows, and when they see a child's face, nod and smile, and throw kisses to it.
column3152: Then the child laughs and claps its little hands, and the mother hears the child and she laughs also.
column3153: The meanest woman would not rob the child of this enjoyment, and if she allows the music to continue she is under a moral obligation to pay for it.
column3154: I knew Billy the whistler well, and he only had one complaint--dogs.
column3155: He could seldom blow three notes on his tin whistle before he was accompanied, against his wish, by a dog's voice.
column3156: The bottom of his trousers was always in tatters, so much did dogs dislike a tin whistle.
column3157: Manchester Jack was one of the best beggars that I have met in this country.
column3158: He scorned to play music, sing, or sell.
column3159: Although he was a big, strong, able-bodied man in the prime of life, he could earn more than a crippled young man or an old man feebled and paralysed.
column3160: This sounds like a reproach to the world, but it is very easy to explain.
column3161: Manchester Jack, being active and business-like, could call at three times more houses than a man that was afflicted by age or accident.
column3162: He would certainly be refused at one or two places where the latter would succeed, but the greater number of houses he called at would give him the advantage.
column3163: From a beggar's point of view, the world consists of two kinds of people--the good and the bad.
column3164: The good will not refuse a man because he is able-bodied, and the bad can and will always find some excuse for not giving assistance.
column3165: The very few that give in particular cases are in such a minority that a man like Manchester Jack would be very little affected.
column3166: I travelled with him for ten days, and when I took one side of a street, and he the other, he not only finished his side first, but, starting at the other end of mine, would meet me half way.
column3167: He was a kind-hearted fellow, always willing to give strangers information about good or bad towns.
column3168: On one occasion, when we had just finished begging a street, Manchester Jack asked me if I had received any scrand (food).
column3169: I told him yes; that I had taken fivepence and two parcels of food, which were in my pockets.
column3170: "Well, lad," he answered, "I have taken ninepence, but no scrand.
column3171: Let me have the scrand and I will make it all right later on."
column3172: I gave him the two parcels, but was considerably taken by surprise; for I knew Jack was too proud a beggar to be seen eating in public, and preferred to sit comfortably in a warm lodging-house kitchen.
column3173: Taking the food he went to a house that he had just left, knocked at the door, handed in the parcels and began to retreat, followed by a woman's voice, which made him hurry faster.
column3174: When he came back he explained to me that he had called at that house, and the woman had begun to cry, saying at last that she was in want herself.
column3175: "So," said Manchester Jack, "I have given her your parcels and a couple of pennies to get a bit of tea."
column3176: On another occasion he was leaving a house when he ran into a very dirty-looking tramp, who was wasting his precious time looking at the doors instead of knocking at them.
column3177: "Mister," said this dirty and timid man, judging Jack by his smart walk and confident smile to be the tenant of the house--"Mister," said he, "is the Mrs. any good for a mouthful of bread?"
column3178: "Here," answered Jack, giving him a penny--"here, and get out of this street at once; for a beggar has just left this house, and the lady cannot give to everyone; take my advice and go to another street."
column3179: I got on very well with Manchester Jack, and we might have been together for a long time, had he not been arrested for begging, and sentenced to a few days' imprisonment.
column3180: XIX Charity in Strange Quarters A fine house is seldom worth a beggar's notice, for the simple reason that it has too many people to consult.
column3181: The servant girl has to tell the cook, and the cook has her orders from the mistress; and either one of these has power to stop the flow of charity.
column3182: The servant girl may, if no one is looking, dismiss a beggar with a shake of her head; or the cook may think she has quite enough work to do without waiting on tramps.
column3183: The fact of the matter is that you can seldom find a servant and her mistress of one mind; if the latter is kind and charitable, it is often found that the servant is otherwise.
column3184: If the mistress is mean and uncharitable, the servant is often--sometimes through spite, and no kindness in herself--inclined to charity.
column3185: All tramps have experiences to relate of how kind-hearted ladies or gentlemen have come out of the house and called them back, or met them at the gate and, after enquiring their wants, led them back to the house and reprimanded the servants for sending poor men away empty-handed.
column3186: Again, there are other cases of servant girls giving charity against the strict orders of their masters and mistresses--girls with good, kind hearts.
column3187: So, you see, a fine house is so unreliable that it always pays a beggar to confine his efforts to small houses.
column3188: There is not the least doubt but what bells cry hunger, common iron knockers spell charity, and shabby doors that cannot afford either bell or knocker, and require bare knuckles, are--from a beggar's point of view--the richest.
column3189: Even when rich people are charitable, and give food, clothes, and money, they never seem to be impressed by the word workhouse; for they seem to regard that place as a comfortable home.
column3190: But to mention workhouse to the poor is to send a shudder through them, and they will always try to assist a man to escape it.
column3191: They see that dreadful place before themselves, when old age and poverty come, and they pity a man that has to go there, if only for one night.
column3192: A man that played an accordion, whom I often saw, had a certain pitch.
column3193: People that passed by could not help but pity him, thinking that he was a stranger in the town, and did not know the almshouses from other dwellings.
column3194: But this musician knew well what the houses were, for he had been to them before and--in a whisper--these almshouses were almost his best pitch.
column3195: Going up a narrow passage, he would take up a position in a large stone yard, where he would stand and play a few tunes, and would be rewarded with three or four pennies and a couple of parcels of food.
column3196: This was certainly good, for it was all bunts (profit).
column3197: He will not be so successful when he plays to a row of fine villas at the other end of the town.
column3198: If it were not for making himself a nuisance, and being paid to go away, it would never be worth while to play to fine houses.
column3199: I shall never forget the summer's day when I accidentally discovered a long row of small houses hidden away from all eyes.
column3200: Having been given a sandwich, I had put it in my pocket, but on second thoughts decided to wrap it in paper.
column3201: Seeing a dark, narrow passage between two shops, I entered, so as to have some privacy to do so.
column3202: While I was in the act of wrapping this sandwich in paper, and returning it to my pocket, I was surprised at being passed by three small children, and wondered what they were doing there.
column3203: But I lost sight of them at once, around a short bend in the passage.
column3204: Being curious to know what was around this bend, I advanced, and what do you think I saw?
column3205: A long yard, with more than a dozen small cottages in a row.
column3206: This was a lovely sight for a beggar!
column3207: In there a man could beg without fear of policemen, and without being annoyed by the stares of people passing in carts and on foot.
column3208: But the best of it was that these houses would escape ninety-nine beggars out of a hundred.
column3209: I lost no time in going to work, in spite of a number of children that were playing in the yard.
column3210: Instead of beginning at the first house, as an amateur would, I passed them all by, intending to begin at the extreme end, calling at every house on my return.
