column3211: My motive for doing this will be approved by all true beggars; it was to advertise my presence, so that people would expect me, and save me the trouble of knocking and explaining my wants, and my time would not be wasted.
column3212: This turned out well, for, after I had called at the end cottage, where I was not expected, I had nothing to do after but receive the ready pennies and food from the neighbours, as I came to them.
column3213: As I have said, it was a summer's day, and all the doors were open, so that the people could hardly fail to know of my arrival.
column3214: Moreover, the children had found time to run in and tell their mothers to expect me, and when.
column3215: No beggar could ever have done business quicker, for in less than a quarter of an hour, I was finished, having received fivepence halfpenny and two parcels of food.
column3216: At one house, where I was given a penny, the woman also gave me a glass of beer, saying that she was thirty-five years of age that day, and had been married fourteen years, and was respected wherever she went.
column3217: Yes, sometimes charity comes from strange quarters, as only beggars know.
column3218: One day an old lady gave me half a chicken and a sponge cake, with the information that she was getting parish relief.
column3219: I don't know how to account for this, but suppose she was fortunate in being well looked after by some rich family for whom she had worked.
column3220: Another time I went to a small cottage, and the door was answered by a very shabby-looking old lady.
column3221: I was selling needles and laces, at the time, and, when the old lady was asked to buy, she answered that she had not one penny in the house.
column3222: She looked so very poor that I felt ashamed of having called there, and felt much inclined to make her a present of a packet of needles.
column3223: As I was about to leave, she said: "Would you like to have something to eat?"
column3224: Not caring to take anything from this poor woman, I said: "No, thank you; I have plenty in my pockets."
column3225: "No matter for that," she answered briskly.
column3226: Saying this, she went indoors, and in a few moments returned with a brown-paper parcel in her hands.
column3227: It looked very much like a suit of clothes, but when I received it I was astonished at its weight.
column3228: Thanking her I left, and at the first opportunity sat down to examine the contents.
column3229: To my surprise I had half a rabbit pie and a whole custard pudding.
column3230: This woman, it seemed, was far from being poor, and lived well; and that she had not a penny in the house was not to say that she was in poverty, as I first supposed.
column3231: When I was once followed by school-children, I could not help but see by their whispers that something unusual was about to happen.
column3232: It was not long before a little girl came forward and put a penny in my hand.
column3233: This was the most extraordinary charity that I ever received; for the child was old enough to know the value of money and the number of sweet things, so dear to childhood, that a penny could buy.
column3234: Another, a little boy, seeing this wonderful deed of sacrifice, wanted me to take his slice of bread and jam, most of the jam being licked off.
column3235: A beggar soon forgets a kindness, but it is most certain that the charity he receives from the young affects him longest.
column3236: Sometimes boys, who take their dinners with them to work, have food left; and it gives them great pride to meet a beggar and give it to him.
column3237: Sometimes--more often than not--it is only dry bread; and they offer it to a beggar who perhaps has better food in his pockets.
column3238: Now, if a man or woman gave such a beggar this dry bread, he would most likely receive it with indifference and cold thanks, and throw it away, being none too particular in carrying it beyond the eyes of the giver.
column3239: But when he is offered this dry bread by innocent, well-meaning boys, he not only takes it with a great show of gratitude and pleasure, but is very careful that the boys will get no chance to see him throw it away.
column3240: XX Enemies of Beggars It is almost time that our streets were cleared of so many house-callers that, hour after hour, knock at doors and ring bells until a lady is not in a fit condition to listen to a beggar.
column3241: It is commonly thought that policemen and dogs are a beggar's only enemies, but this is far from true; even the child that waits at the gate to see if he gets anything, and, if possible, what he does get--even this small innocent must be regarded as an enemy to a beggar; not to mention hundreds of adults that pester people for rent and instalments for goods received, and others that beg people to buy coal, wood, and oil, vegetables and fruit.
column3242: Of course, these callers do not matter much to the true beggar, for he goes blindly to work, careless of his surroundings; but the timid beginner, who looks to the right and left of him, before and behind, is very apt to pass on if a neighbourhood is not kept more quiet for his work.
column3243: The true beggar, as I have said, is not often annoyed by these pestilent callers.
column3244: Sometimes he knocks at a door and, before his knock can be answered, some infernal agent comes to the same door.
column3245: In a case of this kind, the new beggar would be flurried, and most likely leave the house in possession of his enemy--but it is far different with the true beggar.
column3246: He wishes his enemy a cheerful good morning--although it is seldom that he gets a civil answer--and is not afraid to speak out when the lady comes.
column3247: In fact, he would be the first to explain his business, whether he was there first or not.
column3248: A first-class beggar like Brum would scorn to mention such little difficulties as these, and I know well that all good beggars will despise me for raising such paltry objections.
column3249: But even Brum himself has given way before people that were not regarded as beggars; even he had to give way--not out of spite or ill-will, but through his kindness or generosity.
column3250: One day, when we were both out begging, Brum surprised me with these words--"One beggar is quite enough in this street; let us go to another."
column3251: I was quite surprised at these words, for I knew well that Brum would not have budged an inch if there were a dozen beggars in the street.
column3252: But what surprised me more was that when I looked before and behind, I could not see anyone that could be mistaken for a beggar.
column3253: "I don't see anyone," I said at last, looking at him for an explanation.
column3256: "Well, there she is, and good luck to her!"
column3257: And to my astonishment he nodded towards a Sister of Charity.
column3258: It would never have occurred to me to regard such a person as a beggar, but she certainly was; and it proved how kind-hearted and considerate Brum was to give way to her, so that she might have every opportunity to get what the street was worth.
column3259: I ought not to have been surprised to hear Brum say these words, for I had often heard him at the camps and elsewhere laud a certain Christian leader as "the greatest beggar that ever lived."
column3260: To Brum this man was a perfect hero, whose prowess amazed him.
column3261: Brum followed his career with as much interest as any man ever followed the doings of Napoleon; and every scrap of paper that came to hand, on which he saw the name of this Christian leader, was read and re-read by Brum, and commented on daily.
column3262: In fact, Brum was never without two or three pieces of paper relating to "the greatest beggar that ever lived."
column3263: "He does not beg a needle, a piece of thread, a cake, a sandwich, a pair of stockings, or a shirt," Brum would say, glancing with scorn at other beggars in the camp; "he knows nothing about our petty ways of doing business: he begs shiploads of provisions, wardrobes of clothes; aye, acres of land and barrels of money.
column3264: And this man is an Englishman," Brum would add, with a slight sneer at any American beggars who happened to be present.
column3265: The latter had to admit that their country had not yet produced so great a beggar.
column3266: Curly Jack, of England, had never met Brum and never heard of him, but he was of exactly the same opinion; but whereas Brum admired the man as a hero, Curly Jack abused him for his success.
column3267: Whereas Brum was as delighted as a child to see his hero's banner in charge of a trusty officer, and to hear the band--Curly Jack no sooner saw or heard, than he slunk off in an opposite direction, scowling and muttering curses.
column3268: One Sunday morning Curly Jack and myself were in Northampton, and we had left the lodging-house together; after which we parted, he going down one street, while I went farther on, so as to give him plenty of room.
column3269: I did not find Northampton very bad, although the boot trade--its main industry--had been declining for a long time.
column3270: In about half an hour I had several pennies over my bed money, also a quantity of food, so I thought I would get a newspaper and return to the lodging-house, and take it easy for the rest of the day.
column3271: As I was on my way back I saw Curly Jack going to a house, and waited--at his motion--until he was at liberty to come.
column3274: "Very bad," he answered; "I was in a good street, where I have done well before, but twenty or thirty beggars have been there this morning before me, and played it out."
column3275: These words surprised me not a little, and I asked him for an explanation.
column3276: "There they are again," he cried, with an oath.
column3277: I looked in every direction, but all I saw was three little children together, and one couple that appeared to be lovers.
column3280: "I hear the Salvation Army," I said; "surely you don't mean them!"
column3281: "Of course I mean them," he answered, with some impatience.
column3283: I said, at a loss to understand him.
column3284: "I should think their presence would be good for beggars--that they would open people's hearts."
column3285: "Come with me, and I will show you how they spoil the street for a beggar," said Jack.
column3287: In a few moments we were in the same street as the Salvation Army, and my companion walked boldly towards them, while I lingered a little behind.
column3288: However, when I saw him standing near them, I joined him, and could not help but notice that several members of the Army rewarded our presence with smiles.
column3289: It was not long before I saw how the Salvation Army could spoil a street for a beggar.
column3290: While the meeting was going on, several members not only went from house to house, but even begged passers-by--aye, even came to me and my seedy friend.
column3291: "Now," said Curly Jack, as we were leaving--"now, are you satisfied?
column3292: What chance has a beggar, be he ever so good, against these people?
column3293: It will be impossible for the rest of the day to get a single penny in this street, or any other street that they have been to."
column3294: People will now be able to see, by these incidents, the great number of enemies a poor beggar has to contend with; enemies that would take the bread out of his mouth.
column3295: It is very true that in the green country beggars have a little dread of policemen and dogs, but in towns they fear more the annoyance of other callers, who are not beggars.
column3296: One thing they dread very much, in towns of some size, is to be offered a ticket to introduce them to a charitable organization that professes to attend to their wants.
column3297: True beggars know well what these organizations are.
column3298: But sometimes the man who is looking for work is only too glad to receive this ticket--and he certainly gets plenty of work.
column3299: He does about three shillings' worth of labour for a bed whose only virtue is cleanliness, and about threepenny worth of food.
column3300: However, the poor fellow is well satisfied, because he is a very timid man, and he feels less shame in being made a slave than a beggar.
column3301: He is only too glad to perform these tasks at every opportunity, but the true English beggar is a Briton that never will be a slave.
column3302: XXI The Lowest State of Man Some people think that a man cannot fall lower than to live in a common lodging-house; but men and women are occasionally met in London that are even stared at and pitied by those who live in such low places.
column3303: The men and women of whom I speak would not be admitted into the lowest common lodging-houses in London.
column3304: They are so ragged and filthy in appearance that if you gave one of them a sovereign it would be impossible to get a bed until an alteration was made in his or her appearance.
column3305: Some of these have slept in their clothes so often and been outcasts so long that they are really without the least hope--not dejected for a few hours or days, as with others.
column3306: Their dreams, if they have any, are recollections of days gone, but they have no hope in the future.
column3308: Men and women in such a condition that if a man gives them a penny he has to avert his eyes; and the most kind-hearted women pass them by with as quick a glance as possible.
column3309: There is only one place open to these poor wretches, and that is a Salvation Army shelter, where they pay twopence and sleep on the floor.
column3310: They think nothing of suffering; one of them will sit on a seat, when it is raining hard, with the utmost indifference, and there may be an arch that he could reach in less than two minutes.
column3311: So he gets wet and shivers all night, which is common for him.
column3312: I have seen a man of this description refused a bed at a Salvation Army lodging-house, and it did not take the officer many seconds to come to that conclusion.
column3313: Of course, it is not often--perhaps half a dozen times in a year--that one of these poor people can afford to pay fourpence for a bed; but sometimes they have the good fortune to find a silver coin, or some gentleman gives it to them.
column3314: If the latter is the case, the gentleman is probably a stranger in London, and comes from some happy new land where such extreme poverty is not known.
column3315: One night, when I was at the office paying for my bed, I heard a man come in at the front door and stand behind me, but did not turn my head, thinking that he was one of the many lodgers that lived there.
column3316: When I was about to leave I heard this man put down some money and tell the lieutenant that he wanted a bed.
column3317: As I did not hear that officer make any answer, but rise from his stool instead to come out of the office, I turned my head, thinking something strange was about to happen.
column3318: The lieutenant was soon out and standing before the would-be lodger, looking at him from head to foot.
column3319: "I should think not," he said at last with an amused smile to think that the man had asked such a question.

column3433: XXIII The Handy Man The handy man is to be found in all places where men are either too poor to pay for professional experience, or, not being so poor, yet live in out-of-the-way camps which women have never visited, and which are too temporary for tradesmen to open business.
column3434: The former places are common lodging-houses, where the handy man volunteers his services as laundryman, cook, tailor, cobbler, barber, etc.
column3435: In fact, according to his boasted qualifications, it would be far more interesting to learn what he cannot do than what he can.
column3436: He has learnt all these trades with his eye, and, when about to practise, his confidence is unshaken.
column3437: Says he, "I will shave you, and you will not feel the razor going over your face."
column3438: And when he covers your face with blood he blames pimples, which you never had, and expects to be thanked for removing them; for in addition to shaving you, has he not also performed a successful surgical operation?
column3439: In this manner he earns a shilling or more a day, and he is not agreeable that any man should shave himself, sew or wash clothes; or he would not earn the price of his bed and board, and gifts of ale and tobacco.
column3440: If he sees me preparing to shave, he makes a rush and possesses himself of the razor, and commands me to be seated.
column3441: There is nothing else to do but obey, for he takes me by the shoulder and leads me to a seat; he then forces me down and pushes my head back until it is within an inch of the nape of my neck.
column3442: For this indignity I give him a penny, and then, while I am washing, he shouts in a loud voice--"Next."
column3443: He never thinks that I would object to my soap, brush, and razor being used on other faces; and truly it is for that reason--and not economy--that I shave myself.
column3444: But thank goodness the kitchen is almost empty, and there is no answer to his "Next."
column3445: Then, with an eye to future custom, he carefully wipes the razor, dries it on his clothes, washes the brush, rolls the soap in a piece of clean paper, and returns them to the owner.
column3446: After which he again borrows the razor, for he has seen a hair on the throat, and, as he says--"A good craftsman likes to make a neat job."
column3447: He then laments the number of pimples that had to be removed, and wanders in quest of other jobs.
column3448: Probably he now sees a man in the act of repairing a boot.
column3449: If he does, he rushes in that direction, wrestles with the man for the boot, and is soon heard hammering with all his might.
column3450: He makes so much noise that any man would think him a man of confidence and great practice.
column3451: Of course he blames the tools for every mistake, and says modestly that no man living could do better under such conditions.
column3452: For rendering this assistance he receives two or more coppers.
column3453: And now he sees a man whose eyesight is bad endeavouring to thread a needle.
column3454: "Allow me," cries the handy man, springing forward, and wrestling with the other for the needle and thread.
column3455: Getting possession of these, in spite of the other's loud-spoken annoyance, he, instead of returning them, demands the article to be sewn.
column3456: "No, thank you," says the other; "I can manage it myself."
column3457: With much reluctance the handy man surrenders, and begs a pipeful of tobacco for threading the needle.
column3458: But he still keeps his eye on the other, and when he sees him take up a shirt and a patch, the handy man again springs forward and in a loud voice commands the other to halt.
column3459: "I," says he, "have a piece of stuff that exactly matches your shirt, whereas yours is far different."
column3460: Snatching the shirt from the other's hand, he disappears for a moment, and then reappears with a piece of stuff that, it must be admitted, is a better match.
column3461: The other, being well pleased at this, says: "If you don't mind waiting we will have a drink after I have done this job."
column3462: The handy man, hearing this, and not feeling inclined to wait long, also thinking that an additional kindness would meet its reward in an additional drink, answers: "You had better let me do it, for by the way you hold the needle it is plain that you are not used to such work."

column3465: If you like, we will use the interval, while the iron is in the fire, for refreshment."
column3466: The handy man, though he often spoils good things which, with a little professional care, might be made almost as good as new, is not to be altogether despised.
column3467: Though he is not the handy man of his claim, he certainly deserves credit for keeping handy tools.

column3469: He always keeps a pair of scissors, a razor, strap, brush, pincers, and many other useful things, and he is seldom short of nails.

column3487: XXIV On Books I have never had much chance to enjoy books.
column3488: Even after writing four books, which were regarded as literary successes, my library consisted of only about fifty volumes, some of which were magazines, and not worth a second reading.
column3489: This being so, it is hardly likely that I can ever forgive this world for keeping me without books when my enthusiasm was great, for I don't want them now.
column3490: I have often envied the thousands of rich people that have well-stocked libraries and no desire to use them.
column3491: When my enthusiasm was greatest I was not able to enjoy books owing to the circumstances under which they had to be read.
column3492: For instance, when I lived in a common lodging-house, preferring freedom on a small income to drudgery on a large one, I had plenty of time to visit free libraries.
column3493: At those places I could, by signing my name and address, borrow any book mentioned in the catalogue, and read it on the premises.
column3494: I often wish I now had some of the books I read at that time and could not enjoy.
column3495: The reason I could not enjoy them at that time was owing to several causes, which were strong enemies against enthusiasm.
column3496: In the first place, I had to give a false address, because the name of a lodging-house was not respectable, and condemned me as unclean.
column3497: Owing to this I could never feel comfortable, for if I happened to look up from my book and saw the librarian looking my way, I always thought that he was weighing in his mind what manner of man I was.
column3498: Sometimes a librarian would stare at me so boldly that I lost no time in returning the book, and leaving the place, thinking that he would soon come forward and tell me to do so.
column3499: Of course, I was very suspicious, under those circumstances, but have often thought since that those men were not thinking of me at all, but were lost in their own business, and did not know what their eyes were doing.
column3500: Another reason why I could not enjoy books then was owing to a low and insufficient diet, which kept my blood too cold to sit long in a room where the windows were often wide open.
column3501: The consequence was that I often returned a very interesting book after an hour's reading, so as to take a walk and get warm; a book which would, if I had a cosy little room of my own, be read through at one sitting, though it took far into the night.
column3502: And when summer came, I wanted to read in the open air, but had no friends to recommend me as a book-borrower.
column3503: For that reason I could not borrow books to take away and read at my leisure, and in whatever place I liked.
column3504: Since those days, and now that I have made one or two friends, I have other reasons to spoil my enjoyment of books.
column3505: I cannot now read with enjoyment books that are borrowed or are likely to be wanted back.
column3506: Such books are never any good to me, for, if I enjoy them, I am robbed of that joy by the thought that they are not mine.
column3507: I want to see the books around me as my own property, else the sight of them grieves me.
column3508: My own books are kept on a shelf, and I look on them as pure thoroughbred; but I keep apart all borrowed books, treating them as wandering mongrels to whom I have given a temporary home, and am as anxious to drive away as I was to receive them in the beginning.
column3509: For this reason I would not now take advantage of a library, even if it were next door.
column3510: Unfortunately, in the country a book lover has to be well off, for he can only buy new books; whereas in London, and other large cities, a man can take, from stalls of second-hand books, an armful of classics for the price of a moderate meal.
column3511: And that leads me to another thought--I do not care for the look of new books, much preferring them to have lost their last coat of polish.
column3512: Somehow it hurts my conscience to see a dear old author shining before me in gold and spotless green or red.
column3513: I seem to hear his voice say: "You scorned my coming in years past, and left me for these late and colder days."
column3514: There is not much excuse for a man living in London not having a good stock of books.
column3515: I have seen Shakespeare for fourpence, and Milton for half that price.
column3516: At this rate a man could in a few months have a large stock of good books, and the outlay would not be much.
column3517: If I had been living in London during these last two years, my books would now run into several hundreds, and I would not have spent five pounds.
column3518: Perhaps one of the best week's enjoyment I have ever had was in the free library at Reading, in spite of the conditions under which I then lived.
column3519: I had left London three months before, and had been wandering about the country, and had not read a book or magazine during all that time.
column3520: At this time I was aching with all my heart for reading matter, dreaming of books day and night.
column3521: Now it happened that I had been in that town two months before, and on that occasion had been in the library long enough to see that it was very comfortable and had a good stock of papers and magazines.
column3522: For, being a large town, that library was really free, without any signs relating to tramps--as I had seen in smaller towns--silence only being requested.
column3523: Unfortunately, the town's trade was very bad at this time, and for that reason it would take me all day to sell enough laces to keep me, and I would have no spare time for the library.
column3524: So I left Reading, with much regret, but determined to return if I could make a few shillings to keep me idle for several days.
column3525: One Friday night I happened to be at Windsor and heard a couple of beggars in the lodging-house speaking in good terms of Slough, a mile and a half away.
column3526: So, the next morning, being Saturday, I left Windsor and started for Slough.
column3527: When I reached that town, I began to knock at doors without wasting any time, although it was quite early in the day, for some of the better-class people had not yet cleared away their breakfast things.
column3528: I certainly had extraordinary luck, for I took a shilling before dinner and, of course, the town would be much better after that, because of the men having come home with their pay.
column3529: To understand my good fortune people must know that Saturday morning is the worst time in the week for a beggar.
column3530: It is so bad that nine beggars out of ten attempt no business whatever until after dinner, so as not to spoil themselves by being refused at good houses that would gladly assist them later in the day.
column3531: It is really surprising the number of poor people there are who have spent the last penny in the house on a Saturday morning before dinner.
column3532: When I thought of this it suddenly occurred to me that Reading library was not far away.
column3533: No sooner had this idea occurred to me than I made up my mind to keep calling at houses until I had four shillings.
column3534: It was getting dark, and must have been about five o'clock, when I stopped and counted a pocketful of pennies.
column3535: First of all I counted my laces, and found that I had sold a dozen pairs, which had cost me threepence.
column3536: But so many people had given pennies for nothing that I was not at all surprised to find that I had four shillings and tenpence, although one lady had insisted on having two pairs for three-halfpence.
column3537: In addition to this money I had food enough given me for tea that night and breakfast the following morning.
column3538: I was quite delighted at this and started at once for Maidenhead, four miles away.
column3539: On the road there I sold three pairs of laces to men going home from work, and also had threepence given me by a gentleman taking a walk, which was unsolicited.
column3540: So that I now had five shillings and fourpence, a clear five shillings after paying for my bed at Maidenhead.
column3541: The next day, being Sunday, I walked with a light heart into Reading, with five shillings in my pocket.
column3542: That small amount kept me for six days, and I never did, and never will again, have so much enjoyment out of reading matter.
column3543: Of course, what increased my pleasure was the thought that I was letting a small income accumulate, so as to publish a book of my own; the manuscript was in my pocket then, and in two more months I would be an author.
column3544: XXV Narks A man cannot be a very long time on the road before he understands the meaning of the word "narks."
column3545: Beggars may forgive dirty beds, vermin, broken crockery and bad fires, but to tell them that a lodging-house is full of "narks" is the worst information that can be conveyed to them.
column3546: When I enquired of a beggar as to the comfort of the lodging-house in the town to which I was going, he said: "Well, mate, the bed is good, and a good fire is kept, but to tell you the truth the house is spoilt by 'narks.'"
column3547: As I was not an old traveller in England, I did not understand him, but thought I would find out for myself what a "nark" really was.
column3548: After I had reached the town, and paid the lodging-house keeper for my bed, I entered the lodgers' kitchen, and there saw three men seated before a good fire.
column3549: Of my cheerful "Good afternoon," they took not the least notice, neither did they offer to make room for a stranger coming in out of the cold.
column3550: I could see at once by this that they were not true beggars and travellers, who are always eager to make room for their fellows.
column3551: I may as well say at once that these three men were "narks."
column3552: In other words, they were town beggars; men that had lost their homes and had to take refuge in a common lodging-house; or, if they did not belong to the town, they had been there long enough to be known.
column3553: The "nark" is either a cattle-drover, a small hawker, a mechanic that only has a couple of days' work a week, or a man that earns a few pennies by doing odd jobs for people that know him.
column3554: Sometimes he is a man with a very small pension or income, and does nothing.
column3555: Although the lodging-house keeper often abuses him, and threatens to cast him adrift, for all that he is allowed privileges which the casual wandering tramp cannot like.
column3556: All true wanderers hate him; even the drunken, domineering grinder is treated with civility in a house where beggars see a "nark."
column3557: That the "nark," with his mean tricks, is a nuisance to wandering beggars is seen in a very short time.
column3558: For instance, he takes the utensils, which are meant for the common use of the kitchen, and after using them will hide them away for his own future use; so that strangers have often to make tea in a pot without a spout, and look in vain for a saucer or a small saucepan.
column3559: He also monopolizes the fire with newly-washed clothes, and hungry strangers find great difficulty in cooking their food.
column3560: He will not oblige by removing these things until the evening, when there would be less demand for the fire.
column3561: Again, he wants a certain place at the table to sit and eat his food, and he often frowns at innocent strangers who are enjoying their meal in his accustomed seat.
column3562: He is often mean enough to allow his things to remain on the table after he has done, in readiness for the next meal--instead of clearing them away and making room for hungry new-comers.
column3563: The worst charge to make against a "nark" is that he is a spy and a tell-tale, and that he lets the lodging-house keeper know all the transactions of the kitchen.
column3564: When lodgers are told the next morning that they cannot have a bed at that house for another night, and cannot get to know the reason why, they come to the conclusion that they have been reported by a "nark" for complaining about a bad fire, insufficiency of bed-clothes, teapots, saucers, or cups.
column3565: Most deputies in lodging-houses were in the first place "narks."
column3566: Sometimes a "nark" fails, in spite of being well known in the town, to earn the price of his bed, or to borrow it, and returns to the lodging-house for trust.
column3567: After that he shows his gratitude by sweeping the kitchen, or washing plates and tea-things, which the lodging-house keeper had to do himself.
column3568: The latter, seeing this, asks him to do other things, and of course gives him bed and board, and a shilling at the end of the week.
column3569: He no longer goes out as a drover, or seeking odd jobs, but sweeps, washes, scrubs, makes beds, etc.
column3570: Taking everything into consideration the work is not so unremunerative as it appears, for every man in the house solicits his friendship.
column3571: From morning till night he is offered saucers-full of tea from the many lodgers.
column3572: In fact, he is often at his wits' end to know how to spend his very small wages, for the lodgers supply him with tobacco, beer, and even clothes and boots.
column3573: He gets so many presents every week that he makes money by selling them.
column3574: As may be expected, it is from the "narks" that he reaps the most profit; for they never fail to share with him their titbits and give him the price of beer, which makes him favour that class, and prejudiced against casual lodgers.
column3575: Unfortunately the deputy has great power, against which there is no appeal.
column3576: He will allow a "nark" to cook on the fire until it is nearly out; but when he sees a stranger cooking he will interfere, saying that the fire must be attended to.
column3577: After which he will put on so much coke that the poor stranger is delayed an hour or more in doing what he has perhaps half done.
column3578: He has to put on one side a herring half cooked, or a singing kettle, until the fire burns.
column3579: It is a good policy for strangers, as soon as they enter a lodging-house kitchen, to not only speak pleasantly to the deputy, but to slip a penny into his hand, so that they may be installed on an equal footing with "narks."
column3580: Men that do not think of doing this must not be surprised if he "accidentally" overturns their teapots, or shovels coke into their frying-pans.
column3581: These little accidents always add to the gaiety of "narks," and they the more generously reward the deputy for affording them this extra entertainment.
column3582: I was in one lodging-house in the provinces that only had accommodation for twelve lodgers, and in that house were six "narks" and the deputy.
column3583: The night I was there, there were only three strangers, myself and two others, and we were almost afraid to move.
column3584: One "nark" was a rag-and-bone man, who worked the country for miles around.
column3585: While I was eating my frugal supper, he spread on the table his dirty rags and bones--so near that one bone was found on my plate, which I returned to him--with many thanks.
column3586: Seeing that the deputy appeared quite satisfied, I dared not say much, for if I got into trouble and had my money returned, there was not another lodging-house within six miles.
column3587: Another "nark" was a drunken drover, who left a saucepan on the fire while he went out for a drink.
column3588: When he returned he said that there were only four potatoes and a half in the saucepan, whereas he had put in five.
column3589: It never occurred to his suspicious mind that one potato had become small in the extra boiling, and we three strangers had to tolerate his savage looks.
column3590: Another "nark" was a blacksmith, who was out of work.
column3591: This man was lying drunk at full length on a bench, so that the two strangers had to wait until I had finished my meal before they could get a seat at the table, for, with the exception of the drover, all the other "narks" had had their supper.
column3592: The blacksmith had not paid his rent for two or three nights, and the landlady--a very old woman--had ordered the deputy not to allow him to go to bed.
column3593: While I was asleep that night, I was suddenly awaked by a slap on the face, and a croaking voice, which said--"Out of my house, blacksmith."
column3594: When I opened my eyes, I saw an old withered face bending over mine--there must have been a hundred years in that face.
column3595: "I am not the blacksmith," I said feebly.
column3596: "Liar," she shrieked, holding the candle near my face.
column3597: However, she saw her mistake, and went away muttering, without making any apology for her mistake.
column3598: No stranger would ever think of staying two nights in a house like that.
column3599: Of course, in a house where there is only one "nark," he tries to ingratiate himself with casual men, for the sake of social company, but they do not encourage his advances, knowing how careful they must be of what they say.
column3600: They are suspicious of him, in spite of his good-natured offers to oblige them with a shake of pepper.
column3601: By the way, the sight of a pepper-box in a lodging-house kitchen is always a sure sign that the man behind it is a "nark."
column3602: Wanderers, however much trouble they take to carry tea, salt, soap, thread, needle, comb, and many other little things which must not interfere with space for food--would never think of carrying a pepper-box, though they may carry a little pepper in paper.
column3603: No, a "nark" is not a desirable companion, and to inform a tramp that he is going to a house that is full of them, is to daunt him more than to say that the teapots are spoutless and cracked, the saucers have no rims, the beds are dirty, and that the fire is small and often out.
column3604: XXVI The Scribe in a Lodging-house A man who is seen writing in a common lodging-house will soon have his services sought so often that he must be offended, however kind-hearted he may be.
column3605: He will be pestered by illiterate seekers of work, and even begging-letter impostors.
column3606: In the latter case the men are cunning enough to invent pitiful tales, but they lack the education to write them.
column3607: Many a man who has only lived a short time in a lodging-house, and is innocent of the world, has written letters for these rogues, and not known what he was doing.
column3608: Strange to say, very few of these men are able to write their own letters; and, seeing that they usually pose for men that have lost good positions, it is not to be wondered at when they have no courage to face a personal interview.
column3609: With regard to honest seekers of work, a man will soon be sorry that he has obliged them, because of the awkward position in which it places him.
column3610: For instance, if they do not receive any answer to your letter, or one that is not favourable, they are very apt to blame the letter-writer.
column3611: One day a man came to me, who had often seen me writing, and asked if I would write him a few lines in answer to an advertisement.
column3612: Seeing that he brought a stamped envelope and a sheet of writing-paper, and I already had pen and ink before me, I did so at once, to my sorrow.
column3613: The poor fellow received no answer at all, and he was under the impression that I could so word a letter that it was certain to be successful.
column3614: It never occurred to him that the advertisement being in a leading paper would be answered by hundreds of men.
column3615: When several days passed, and no answer came, no doubt he came to the conclusion that he would have been more successful himself, and that I had spoilt him of that job by my manner of writing.
column3616: So he was very cold after, leaving me with one consolation--that I had not only received no benefits from him, but wanted none, whether he was successful or not.
column3617: One man, who could hardly read or write, brought me his aunt's letter to be deciphered, from whom he was getting assistance every week.
column3618: I had so much difficulty in reading her letter that I told him after that his aunt's writing was very bad.
column3619: Hearing this he began to throw out hints that the fault must be with me, for his aunt had married a rich brewer, and was now a widow with seven servants.
column3620: Seeing what a simple man I had to deal with, I tried to explain that the handwriting of some of the greatest people was bad, and that it was not their handwriting made them great, but the thoughts and language they used.
column3621: But I saw that he could not understand my meaning, and he brought me no more of his aunt's letters.
column3622: In fact, the letters I have written to oblige others have made me more enemies than friends.
column3623: The most grateful thanks I have received for doing this kindness was not from a man living in a lodging-house, but from one on the outside.
column3624: I was in the lodging-house kitchen one night when "Brummy" Sam brought a married friend of his to see me.
column3625: The former lost no time in explaining to me that his friend Alf had a daughter in service in the country.
column3626: Now this daughter had been written to several times, by her mother, sister, and brother, but none of them could get an answer; so Alf, "Brummy" Sam explained, "wanted to know the ins and outs of her reasons."
column3627: The latter, who had been drinking, confided to me with deep emotion that his friend Alf was a faithful old dog, and, "as for Alf's old woman, there wasn't a better-natured bleeding old cat in all London."
column3628: Although he whispered this information, it was quite loud enough for Alf to hear, and the big fellow looked at Sam with gratitude.
column3629: After saying these words Sam straightened himself and said: "I have been telling Alf about you, as how you can write, and we think you can put the letter in such a way that she will answer at once."
column3630: Hearing this I was not very well pleased, for I could hardly hope to be more successful than the girl's own mother.
column3631: It was most likely that there was nothing the matter at all, and that she was only waiting a convenient time to write.
column3632: However, I wrote a letter to Alf's daughter, which he received with so much delight, and such a pressing invitation to drink, that it quite upset me, thinking that the letter would be no more successful than others.
column3633: But I am pleased to say that she not only answered it at once, but asked her mother who had written it.
column3634: Perhaps she thought it was a lawyer, and was afraid that further neglect in not reporting herself at home would lead to the police court.
column3635: Alf was so grateful that his friendship became a nuisance, especially when he was drunk; and I was very glad that he only came to the house as a visitor, and did not live there altogether.
column3636: But in a very common lodging-house it is not often that a man is asked to write a letter.
column3637: I used to write for one man to his mother, about once a month, and he was very thankful to me, for I would never take anything from these poor fellows.
column3638: It was a dreadful task for me to write a letter of that kind, for he had nothing to say except--"Give my love and say I am all right, and remember me to Aunt Sarah."
column3639: And the simple man not only expected me to fill two or three papers on this meagre information, but wanted to know if I had enough paper.
column3640: This man was a consumptive, and when I wrote one letter for him he was about to go into a hospital.
column3641: He asked me then if I would write a few lines to his mother if anything serious happened to him.
column3642: I promised to do so, but am glad to say he was back in a few weeks, although not much better.
column3643: I shall never forget writing one letter for a man who was leading a double life.
column3644: He had only just come to our lodging-house, but he was so well known to all the old lodgers that I could see that he had been there before.
column3645: When this man first came under my notice, he was in the act of sewing a patch on the knee of his trousers, the latter being still on his body.
column3646: I may as well say here that he made a very bad job of it, for he sewed his trousers to a pair of drawers that were underneath; which made him swear so much that night, when he undressed, that irritated lodgers, disturbed from sleep, threatened to throw him out of the window.
column3647: One day I asked a lodger what this man did for a living, thinking that he was either a toy-seller, paper-man, or market porter.
column3648: The lodger began to chuckle, and said: "If you are down Brixton way to-morrow, you are likely to see him."
column3649: As I asked the question for the sake of being sociable, and not from curiosity, I thought no more of the matter.
column3650: However, some time after this I happened to be in Brixton, and saw the man I mention, standing in the gutter--blind.
column3651: He saw me too, for he made an awful expression, which I translated into these words--Don't stop and speak to me, pass on.
column3652: A few days after this unexpected meeting, he no sooner saw me entering the lodging-house kitchen than he came forward with an envelope and a sheet of writing paper.
column3656: Now, I had been out all day and was hungry, and was just about to prepare my tea.
column3657: So I told him sharply that if I wrote the letter I wanted nothing for doing it, and, whether I wrote it or not, he must give me a chance to have my tea first.
column3658: Nearly all men that live in common lodging-houses talk to each other in this strain, for they are all more or less short-tempered, or, as they say--"scatty."
column3659: So I knew that he would not take offence, and was not surprised to see him come forward, after he had given me ample time for tea.
column3660: "I am not much of a scholar," he began.
column3661: "What do you want me to write about?"
column3663: "Well," said he, "a gentleman saw me in the street and took my address, and has just sent me a parcel of clothes, and I want to thank him.
column3664: Here is his letter, with address, which was in the parcel."
column3665: "All right," I answered, and did so at once.
column3666: After I had done, I read aloud what I had written, and asked if it would do.
column3667: He considered for a moment, and then said: "Perhaps you will write a little more and say as how Heaven will reward him for pitying a blind man."
column3668: I could not help laughing at this, for he spoke so exactly that I believe the rogue had forgotten that he was not really blind.
column3669: It is very pathetic on a Christmas morning to see seventy or eighty men in a lodging-house, and not six of them receive any greetings from the outside world.
column3670: In one house, where the manager's charming little daughter received scores of letters and presents from school-friends and friends of her parents, there were not ten out of ninety lodgers who received a single letter--on a Christmas morning!
column3671: It was when I saw this that it came on me in full force to know what an isolated plague spot a common lodging-house is.
column3672: Men who have spent years in such places must feel deeply the loneliness of their lives at that season, when every person outside a lodging-house finds time to either visit friends and relatives, or write to them.
column3673: XXVII Licensed Beggars With all the tricks and dodges of beggars, the man that owns a pedlar's certificate--which is known as "a brief"--is, taking it all the year round, the most successful.
column3674: It matters not to him whether the police in a town are strict or not, and he is little interested when he hears street-singers or downright beggars approve or disapprove of the police in certain towns.
column3675: Armed with this authority, he is a man of cool courage and impudence, and, when he produces his "brief," he makes the inquisitive constable that interferes with him, flush painfully.
column3676: "Is that all the stock you have?"
column3677: asks the constable sternly, glancing at the man's paltry few laces, and knowing well that he is using them for begging purposes--"Is that all the stock you carry?"
column3678: "It is all I need," the other often answers impudently, shaking his laces in one hand, and his certificate in the other.
column3679: All towns are not favourable to the street-singer, even though they may be good for the more silent beggar; and the downright beggar is apt at any moment to have the door answered by a policeman, and where is he then?
column3680: But the licensed beggar is safe.
column3681: Now it is often very difficult to get this pedlar's certificate, although the man has the five shillings to buy it; especially in London, where a man has to be a resident in one place for six months, and must also give reasons for his request, that he is physically unfit to follow his trade or to do rough labour.
column3682: But beggars know of small towns in the provinces where they only have to show five shillings and tell a lie or two, and the certificate is theirs at once.
column3683: And when a man has one, the difficulty is over for all time, for he can get it renewed at the most particular town, without trouble or question.
column3684: A man may pursue his calling for a very long time without being asked to show his license, and another man may be asked to show his several times in one month, perhaps twice in one day.
column3685: I knew one man that went all through the year without interference, but the very first week that his license expired and he had not renewed it, he was accosted by a policeman and arrested.
column3686: This luckily turned out to his advantage, for when he explained to the magistrate his inability to save five shillings for its renewal, that gentleman generously gave him the amount out of the poor-box, and the license was renewed.
column3687: Of course the man had begged enough during the week to be independent of this aid, for one lady had given him two shillings towards that end, and from several others he had received small silver instead of pennies to enable him--as he told them--"to earn an honest livelihood by selling laces, instead of begging."
column3688: Yes, many a dear lady highly commended this fine, fat fellow for such a noble resolution.
column3689: As I have said, he had received more than twice five shillings in the week by showing ladies his expired license, but a terrible thirst was on him, and he could not possibly pass a public-house.
column3690: It will, no doubt, be interesting news to the police, and even a number of beggars, to know that men often hide their licenses in the lining of their clothes, taking out a few stitches, and sewing up again.
column3691: Quite a number of beggars sew up their valuables in their clothes, as a safeguard against loss; but the licensed beggar has another motive for doing so.
column3692: The reason why he hides his license is that when he exhausts his very small stock, in an hour or two, he then takes to downright begging for the rest of the day, as he does not wish to waste time; and there may not be a swag-shop (a shop where hawkers are supplied), near, or there may not be one in the town.
column3693: Now if he is arrested for begging, he will get ten days' imprisonment and, if a pedlar's license is found on him, he will receive the extra punishment of having it taken from him, and not returned.
column3694: So he serves his ten days, happy to think that his "brief" is safe in the lining of his clothes.
column3695: He can safely rely on this being so, for a common beggar is never subjected to a severe search.
column3696: I knew one man that had a wife and three very small children, and, on the day I made their acquaintance, she and the children remained in the lodging-house all day, so that she could do some washing.
column3697: When the husband went out that morning, rather late, all his stock-in-trade consisted of was six pairs of cheap mohair laces, which cost him threepence, and with these he went to work.
column3698: Soon he returned with one shilling and ninepence in coppers, four parcels of food, and two pairs of laces still left.
column3699: Eighteen pence had to be paid for their night's lodging, without a question of food for five bodies.
column3700: Giving his wife the money, he again sailed forth for the afternoon.
column3701: In four hours he returned with one and eleven pence, and no laces.
column3702: After which she, having finished her washing, went out shopping, and soon returned with bread, tea, sugar, milk, mutton chops, and a fresh stock of laces; also two separate half-ounces of tobacco, one for him and one for herself.
column3703: With this supply, and the contents of her husband's pockets--he regretted that he could not carry more--the family could do very well for tea, supper, and breakfast the next morning.
column3704: This industrious couple were always very successful on Sunday mornings, when they sang hymns in the street, with the three small children at their side.
column3705: One of the most versatile beggars that I have ever met was Harry the Whistler, who was so resourceful that he was indifferent whether his wife remained idle at home in the lodging-house or not.
column3706: He also carried a "brief," with a few pins and needles, for the benefit of odd houses scattered here and there; but when he saw a number of houses close together, or anything that looked like a street, he would immediately make a stand and blow a tin whistle.
column3707: Sometimes, to relieve the monotony, he and his wife sang together, but more often than not she stood silently at his side, and received the reward of his playing.
column3708: The first time I met this couple, Harry the Whistler had to go to bed early, so that his wife could mend the bottom of his trousers.
column3709: They almost came to blows on this occasion, for the wife maintained that she would not sit up late night after night to mend his trousers, and that if he would still persist in blowing a tin whistle, and having the bottom of his trousers torn by dogs, instead of going in for chanting, peddling, or straight begging, she would no longer travel with him.
column3710: After he had cursed dogs to his heart's content, he confessed that it was no more pleasure for him to go to bed early than it was for her to sit up late and mend his trousers, and that in the future he would cease playing as soon as his notes were answered by a dog's bark.
column3711: XXVIII Navvies and Frauds Navvies in common lodging-houses receive much contempt from pedlars, grinders, and true beggars.
column3712: They are always washing clothes and making shackles (soup) on Sunday, owing to their perspiration and dry food during the week; and while they are going about these long tasks, others cannot find accommodation.
column3713: They always manage to get the use of the whole fire--centre, sides, and front--just before public-houses open; after which they booze until closing time, and then return to fill every utensil in the kitchen--basins, teacups, and saucers--with their greasy shackles.
column3714: Although generous to one another, they would not let the smell of their shackles reach true beggars, if it could be prevented; and yet, when a navvy is reduced to the price of his bed only, he hints at his wants in a common lodging-house kitchen, expecting assistance from beggars, instead of making his wants known outside.
column3715: The navvy is more often than not a very timid beggar, and, when he can, lives upon stolen apples, turnips, blackberries, etc.
column3716: ; aye, and the picked-up bread that true beggars have cast away.
column3717: In spite of this, I have seen an exceptional navvy that had the impudence to stand pad in a crowded market-place; which means that he would stand in the street gutter with a few laces or pins in his hand, a thing that only afflicted ones are expected to do.
column3718: He does this on the night that follows pay-day, and it must be confessed that he meets with some reward.
column3719: Sometimes a servant girl gives him a penny through admiration of his stalwart form; sometimes an old lady gives him a penny because his nose is like her son's; and, seeing that on this particular night everybody is happy with money in their pockets, it is not to be surprised at that a number of stray coppers find their way into his pocket.
column3720: In this instance, charity is certainly not misplaced, for this man would rather work than beg.
column3721: If he was engaged to be at your house to do a job on the following day, you could have little doubt but what he would appear.
column3722: Only one thing would prevent him, and that is the arrival at the lodging-house of moneyed navvies that have just finished a job.
column3723: In that case he would not need the little work offered to him, and it would be the best policy not to absent himself from his new friends--not even for a few minutes, for, when men are drinking, they are apt to change suddenly.
column3724: As long as he is face to face with them, all goes well, but he no sooner turns his back than a word of suspicion is dropped, and he returns to find that his former friends are--if not drunk--cold and reserved; and if they are drunk he will find them not only ready to quarrel, but to murder.
column3725: The navvy is a real working-man, but he has to travel for work from place to place, and his jobs are very often short through no fault of his own.
column3726: Being a rough, uncouth, and ill-mannered man, fond of drink and freedom to chew and smoke tobacco, to spit, and use strong language, he has no other option than to live in a common lodging-house, even though he is earning as much money as a good mechanic.
column3727: Now, although a navvy spends the best part of his life among beggars in common lodging-houses, it is surprising how simple and innocent he is as to beggars' tricks and dodges.
column3728: If he saw a man in a fit in the street, the navvy would be one of the last to suspect that man of being a fraud.
column3729: If he saw a man making feeble attempts to climb a bridge's wall or railings, and drop into the river, the navvy would be the last to have suspicion that that man was doing so to introduce himself to one who would listen to his pitiful story, and help him with a shilling or more.
column3730: And the navvy would never suspect the child that pretends to lose money and begins to cry in a loud voice.
column3731: And yet this navvy spends his life in a lodging-house, where these cunning mortals live.
column3732: These tricks are not so common as people suppose; they are in fact very rare.
column3733: Many an honest man has fits, the rivers give up a number of suicides, and with regard to the child losing money--was there ever a child that did not?
column3734: Beggars have various ways by which they can get shillings instead of pennies.
column3735: When a beggar in a lodging-house kitchen produced a massive ring for the inspection of his fellow lodgers, it was eagerly commented on as "a good one"; by which they meant to say that it was a good imitation, for they all knew that it was a dummy.
column3736: But a navvy saw that it was marked so many carats, felt that it was heavy, saw that it was of good colour, and exclaimed, to the derision of the lodgers assembled: "It's real gold!
column3738: "Will you give me sixpence for it?"
column3740: The navvy did not answer, for this question seemed to enlighten him.
column3741: The ring dodge is a paying concern, for the sale of one ring often means dinner, drinks, supper, bed, and breakfast.
column3742: The ring is, to all appearance, valuable; according to its colour, finish, weight, and--the best sign of all--its mark of carats.
column3743: All that is to be done is to invite inspection, and if you are suspected of being a thief who is afraid to enter a pawnshop, so much the better, for you are almost certain to find an avaricious victim.
column3744: Very few men can resist giving a couple of shillings for an article which they feel satisfied can be again easily disposed of at a good profit.
column3745: I have often been invited as a would-be purchaser to examine a ring in the hand of a seedy-looking man, and, if he persists, I simply say, "I live in a doss-house," and he does not waste any more time on me.
column3746: Then there is the razor-man, with his very cheap razors, which look so very good.
column3747: It is generally in public-houses where the razor-man succeeds.
column3748: Producing a fine-looking razor, he invites inspection, and when it meets with approval he offers it for sale.
column3749: If he cannot get more than three times its worth, he is in bad luck indeed.
column3750: Then there is the man who carries a few cheap spectacles, which never cost him more than twopence-halfpenny a pair.
column3751: At night this man finds victims in public-houses, and by day the ladies must suffer.
column3752: Sometimes he carries a few laces, pins, and needles, etc., so as to get a few coppers at places where spectacles would not be needed.
column3753: When an elderly lady answers the door, he, after a while, introduces the spectacles, taking them from his inside pocket.
column3754: It is more than probable that she uses glasses to read and sew, even if she is not wearing them then.
column3755: In a case of this kind women, also men, are very curious, and they cannot resist the temptation to try the glasses, even though they are well suited with what they possess.
column3756: Moreover, it is well to have several pairs of glasses, in case of accidents.
column3757: Now, sometimes a very common pair of glasses will suit better than costly ones for which the eyes were tested; even as a brass watch may keep better time than a gold one, or a pair of ready-made boots fit better than a pair made to order.
column3758: If the old lady is satisfied that she can see as well as with her own, the glasses at once assume value, and this is known to the pedlar, for he never mentions a word about price until he hears her verdict.
column3759: First she tries one pair, and then another, until she confesses that one pair in particular suits her eyes.
column3760: On hearing this the man gives his price, which is according to what he thinks the woman can afford.
column3761: If she can afford to make a purchase, she does, and tells him that she can see better with his eighteen-penny glasses than with a pair for which her eyes were tested, and which cost her seven shillings and sixpence, or more.
column3762: And these spectacles cost the pedlar two shillings and sixpence per dozen.
column3763: A little originality converts a common beggar into a great one.
column3764: When I was in the Welsh hills, where common lodging-houses were scarce, I found a house to my liking, and, seeing that there were a number of good-sized towns near, within three or four miles, determined to make it my quarters for a month or more, and thoroughly work the country around.
column3765: I was selling laces at the time, and on my visit to one of the towns, I had remarkably good luck.
column3766: Seeing a long street, I called at every house and received in all one shilling and twopence for my trouble, with the sale of four pairs of laces, which cost me less than twopence.
column3767: I mentioned this to a fellow-lodger, who had been staying at the house for several days.
column3768: When at his request I described the position of the street, he said, with a quiet smile: "I got eight shillings and sixpence out of that street."
column3770: I asked, thinking he must be in a large way of business, and wondering why he lived at a common lodging-house.
column3771: "Nothing," he answered, to my amazement; "it was all profit."
column3772: This made me curious, for I knew that he, being a man apparently unafflicted and in good health, could not be very successful as a plain beggar.
column3773: Before we went to bed this man gave me a letter to read, and in this letter it said that he was one of the strikers at M----, and that he had a wife and four children to maintain, and ended with a polite and dignified request for assistance.
column3774: With this letter he did his business, simply handing it to whoever answered the door, with the request that they would take it in and read it.
column3775: His time was night, when the whole family were at home, probably two or three working sons and the father; and when he could go from door to door without attracting notice.
column3776: Who could insult this man with a common penny?
column3777: No doubt two or three people that had given me pennies refused this more ambitious man; but others, who thought a penny quite enough for me, gave him sixpence or a shilling.
column3779: It did not give a servant chance to dismiss him, for she had no suspicion of his wants; and it did not give one of the family power to speak for all.
column3780: And yet, in spite of knowing these tricks, I still continued the far less profitable traffic in laces.
column3781: XXIX A First Night in a Lodging-house I have lived so full a life that I forgot, till lately, an incident that other men would, if it was their experience, talk about till the end of their days; for it was at that time that I first became acquainted with common lodging-houses and shelters.
column3782: It was when I was young, twenty years of age, and had just finished my apprenticeship, that I paid my fare to London, and then had five weeks' experience of the worst side of life.
column3783: When I arrived in London, I had a gold sovereign and a few shillings; and, being full of hope, like all young people, went to a small hotel, had a good meal, and paid two shillings and sixpence for my bed.
column3784: At this rate I was soon bankrupt, and then commenced my experience of real life; for I was soon hungry and walking the streets at night.
column3785: But on the first night I had the good fortune to be assisted by a gentleman who, seeing me standing under an arch, asked a few questions and then gave me sixpence.
column3786: This was my first experience of acute hunger, and it so frightened me that when day came, and I had had a cup of tea and a slice of bread and butter, I bought half a pennyworth of stationery and a stamp and sent home for money, having the reply addressed to a post office in the Strand.
column3787: The following day I received a letter with a postal order for twenty shillings.
column3788: A few days had taught me much, and I was now determined to spend no more half-crowns on beds, but to make this money last as long as possible.
column3789: So I asked a ragged man what was the cheapest bed I could get, and he said fourpence, but that I could get a bunk at the Salvation Army shelter for twopence.
column3790: Leaving him I went in quest of a fourpenny lodging-house in the East End, and soon found one.
column3791: That was my first experience in a common lodging-house, but I cannot say that at that time the experience filled me with anything like horror.
column3792: I was young and romantic, and felt proud in having such a strange experience, which I could talk about when I would be in a better position, to people's amazement.
column3793: However, I only stayed there three nights, because I saw that I would soon be hungry again, if I did not seek cheaper lodgings.
column3794: So I made enquiries about a Salvation Army shelter, and was soon inside one in Ratcliff Highway.
column3795: I did not think this place quite so romantic as the common lodging-house, for here were so many men that not one could be seated with comfort, and these men were more ragged and dirtier.
column3796: Now, at this time I was a pure-minded youth, who had been a chapel-goer, by compulsion 'tis true; and I thought the world was divided into two classes--the wicked, who never went to a place of worship, and the good, who went every Sunday at least.
column3797: I had never given it a thought what a hypocrite was, and that people would go to church or chapel from other motives than religion.
column3798: For this reason what surprised and shocked me most at this shelter was to hear the Salvation Army soldiers using bad language.
column3799: I could hardly believe my ears, when I heard them, even on Sunday, before and after a meeting in which they had prayed and sung.
column3800: The bunks in this shelter were on the floor, and contained a mattress covered with leather, and a leather quilt.
column3801: This was quite sufficient for warmth, for every man lay in his clothes, and so many men together made the air warm and very foul.
column3802: Each bunk was about six feet long, two feet and a half wide, and six inches in height.
column3803: I need hardly say that I soon got homesick; and when I heard a couple of sailors say that they were going to South Wales to look for a ship, I at once offered to accompany them.
column3804: Luckily for me these two sailors were good cadgers, having often tramped across country to different seaports, so that I was not likely to starve in their company.
column3805: The next morning, when I told them I had a silver shilling left, and took their advice to spend it on ale and tobacco, they promised with many oaths that I should not want for food on the road.
column3806: But I only accompanied them a little more than half-way, and then left them; for they, having no sure prospects, were not inclined to tax their walking strength to the utmost.
column3807: My last stage was over sixty miles, with only one stop, and that was nine miles from home.
column3808: It was then night, and I met a policeman who wanted to know where I was going.
column3809: "Home," I answered, and added the name of the town.
column3810: I began to feel a bit tired now, and sat on a bank for a few moments' rest, after which I rose and continued my way.
column3811: But I had hardly gone twenty yards when I met a policeman again, who said: "Hallo!
column3813: I thought you were going home?"
column3814: "So I am," I answered, quite bewildered.
column3815: "You are going away from it," he said; "you have walked back two miles from where I met you before."
column3816: When I had sat on the bank I must have fallen asleep, and, waking, did not know in the dark but what I was going right.
column3817: However, at that time these experiences only made romance.
column3818: The truth is that as long as the young do not feel actual hunger, they care little for other things.
column3819: And I was very fortunate in these few weeks, for I was never forced to beg.
column3820: The two sailors not only fed me, but, when I left them, gave me as much food as I was likely to want on my way home.
column3821: It was years after, when I began to feel literary ambition and wanted privacy, that I experienced the horror of being mixed with thirty or forty men in a small lodging-house kitchen.
column3822: One day, when I had been in a common lodging-house for a considerable time, I met a man in Hyde Park, who had lately come from the country, and was now come to his last shilling, after selling whatever he had of value.
column3823: Hearing this, I could do no other than take him to the lodging-house where I lived.
column3824: I gathered from his conversation that he had no idea of such places.
column3825: Now it happened that I was living in a very low-class house in Blackfriars, whose inmates were not only very poor and ragged, but rough and brutal; so, when I began to think of this, I almost repented of my offer to take charge of him.
column3826: However, it was too late now, so on we went, and were soon at the house.
column3827: When we entered the kitchen there were three of the worst lodgers quarrelling, and not only drunk, but with a can full of beer on the table.
column3828: What must have been this man's thoughts, who had only just left a good home?
column3829: for he had been telling me about his mother and sisters.
column3830: I told him to sit down and wait until I returned from shopping, after which we would have tea.
column3831: I was away less than ten minutes, for there were several shops near, but when I came back he had gone.
column3832: Speaking to one of the lodgers about him, I was told that he had followed me out, close at my heels.
column3834: I believe that he was so disgusted with his strange surroundings that he started for home at once, although it was a hundred miles away.
column3835: His feelings must have been very strong, seeing that he had already paid for his bed, and that sum was now lost to him.
column3836: I have often wondered what must have been his final opinion of me, to whom he had entrusted his confidence.
column3837: Perhaps he thought that I had decoyed him there to be robbed of his very clothes.
column3838: The place must have seemed horrible to him, with its dark, underground kitchen, no woman there, and nothing, except a cat, to make it appear like a home.
column3839: Of course, I am speaking now of the very lowest lodging-houses--houses that are seldom written about; for journalists choose better-class lodging-houses for their visits.
column3840: Some time ago, I read an account of a journalist going to spend one night in a lodging-house.
column3841: He explained how he pocketed his briar pipe, and took a common clay one, and how he dirtied his face and hands.
column3842: Now it happened that the house he went to was a superior lodging-house where he would see a number of men with silk hats and watches and chains.
column3843: In fact, this innocent journalist made himself ill-looking enough for a fourpenny lodging-house, and I would not have been surprised if he had been refused a bed at the house to which he went.
column3844: After reading his account I have come to the conclusion that he did not visit the place at all.
column3845: Speaking of journalistic work, I know a book that describes low life in London, with pictures taken from life.
column3846: When I look at one picture I see a man and a woman with a handcart loaded with household furniture.
column3847: These two are leaving a house at night, for they owe rent.
column3848: But when I look closer still, I recognize both the man and the woman; and I know that the former has been in a lodging-house for twenty years, during which time he never had furniture.
column3849: I also know that the woman has not for thirty years had cause to do what the picture represents.
column3850: Of course, this does not matter, for such things are to be seen--but the picture was not taken from real life.
column3851: The picture was taken by day, when people do not make "moonlight flits"; and at night--which the scene represents--the great journalist was sleeping in his luxurious home.
column3852: XXX Gentleman Bill A man may not only play many parts in life, but sometimes even his real character undergoes a change and conforms to his surroundings.
column3853: Such was the case with Gentleman Bill.
column3854: When he first came to our lodging-house he was a quiet, modest man, who was almost too timid to hazard a suggestion on the most common subjects; but in less than three months conceit and importance was so thrust upon him that he was almost too proud to walk.
column3855: I was a witness of this development of a new character, right from the beginning, and saw that Bill was not in any way to blame; but that the ignorance of his associates shoved him, in spite of his modesty, shoulder-high above themselves.
column3856: Bill, it appeared to me, had mixed, ere his downfall, with people who were his equal, and not a few of whom were his superior--hence his modesty when he first came to our house as a needy lodger.
column3857: He was seen to be a very quiet man, always reading newspapers or books, or walking silently up and down the kitchen in deep thought.
column3858: For a month or more the lodgers took very little notice of him, but when his appearance had grown familiar to them, they began to ask his opinion on different subjects--cooking, physic, the nutritious value of foods, the meaning of words, the use of the House of Lords, and many other interesting things.
column3859: These questions were answered by Bill in such a high-flown manner, as became a great reader, that really his hearers were little the wiser, and came to the conclusion that Bill's knowledge was far too deep for them.
column3860: The lodgers were so awestruck at Bill's easy delivery of unusual words that they could not grasp the underlying thought.
column3861: It was not long before he became so puffed with his own importance, and so eager to express his opinions, that he did not wait an invitation to join in a conversation, but stood in the middle of the kitchen and spoke in such a masterly way that some of the lodgers thought that he was an ex-M.P.
column3862: He was not satisfied with giving his own opinions, but quoted poets, philosophers, lawyers, and statesmen; and the lodgers at last became so impressed that they sought him all over the house to hear him settle an argument.
column3863: One morning Little Brum actually took a cup of tea to Gentleman Bill, while the latter was in bed, so as to get him down to settle a dispute which was likely to make the principals lose a morning's work.
column3864: It was not long before Bill had to pay the penalty of being so important, for some of the more simple lodgers began to ask him such idiotic questions that Bill, who up to the present had never been at a loss for a word, could do little more than stand dumb with amazement.
column3865: For instance, one day a poor simple fellow asked the following question: "Is it right to post a letter to-day that was written yesterday?"
column3866: An Irishman asked him the belief of the laity, and whether they were for or against the Pope of Rome.
column3867: Another had heard that an egg boiled too hard could be again boiled soft, and wanted to know if it could be boiled to recover its first raw state.
column3868: Poor Bill began to lose patience and grumble, saying that he could not be expected to know everything.
column3869: The lodgers would not allow him peace to have a cup of tea, to shave, wash, or read.
column3870: I happened to be sleeping in the same room as Bill, a large room with seven beds to accommodate seven men.
column3871: Early one morning, about three o'clock, I was in that half-wakeful state when a man turns his body over in sleep, and thought I heard voices.
column3872: Curiosity getting the better of sleep, I listened, and sure enough the man in the next bed to Bill was asking him a number of questions.
column3873: The questions must have interested Bill, for he immediately sat up in bed and began a long talk.
column3874: When I fell asleep he was still sitting up and talking, and I did not wonder that he was a late riser.
column3875: On one occasion there was a terrible fuss in the house, and a lodger called Bill a damned conspirator.
column3876: It seemed that the man had claimed a letter at the office which did not belong to him.
column3877: When the clerk received letters he wrote the surnames on a sheet of paper, which he placed in the window.
column3878: The Christian names were kept secret, so that he could question applicants about them, this being the only plan of placing letters in the right hands.
