column3879: Where there were such a number of men there were certain to be several of the name of Smith, Jones, Brown, and other common names.
column3880: So when one morning the clerk received a letter for William Henry, he added the surname to his list.
column3881: Reading the list of names a simple lodger, whose Christian name was Henry, made application for the said letter.
column3882: The clerk got the letter and, glancing at the envelope, made his usual enquiry, "Your Christian name?"
column3883: Now it happened that the man did not know the meaning of this question, and to be on the safe side he gave his full name, which was Henry Brown.
column3884: The clerk lost patience at Brown's simplicity and said, "This letter is not for you; your Christian name is Henry, but the man to whom this letter belongs is surnamed Henry."
column3885: The dissatisfied and unconvinced lodger left the office and sought Gentleman Bill, whom he found and consulted.
column3886: Bill went into a long discourse as to the origin of surnames, but the lodger cut him short by asking what right the clerk had to place his name on the list and not give up the letter.
column3887: It was no use for Bill to try to explain the difference between surnames and Christian names, and he was no more successful than the clerk, although he took fifty times the time and words.
column3888: The upshot of it was that the infuriated lodger called Bill a damned conspirator, whereas Bill also lost his calmness and called the lodger a fool.
column3889: How Bill was spoilt by so much consultation was made apparent to me by a little incident that escaped the notice of others.
column3890: He had been having a glass or two of ale, and, coming into the kitchen with his book, which was a grammar, seated himself comfortably at the fire.
column3891: The effect of the ale, the heat of the fire, and the inactive state of his body, soon made Bill bow his head to the table, and in a minute or two he was fast asleep.
column3892: I happened to be sitting near him at the time, and was taken by surprise to hear his voice.
column3893: Thinking he was addressing me I turned, but saw that he was fast asleep and talking to himself.
column3894: All at once I heard him say, as distinctly as though he had been awake, "What I need is a silk hat and a frock-coat"; meaning, of course, that if he had those things, for the sake of appearance, his knowledge, conversation, and manners would be the making of him.
column3895: On one or two occasions I had the honour of being consulted by Bill--of which I am very proud, for he did not consider any other man in the house able to teach him anything.
column3896: I had always managed to satisfy him with my remarks, but when he approached me one night, with his grammar book in his hand, and asked me if I knew anything about the infinitive split, the question almost took my breath away.
column3897: Certainly I had heard of it, heard enough to know that it was to be avoided as a subject of argument, or it would soon worry a man to a shadow.
column3898: I told Bill at once that I could not enlighten him, and advised him not to worry over it.
column3899: This advice was not taken, for he bought two more cheap second-hand grammar books, and still could not get on the track of the infinitive split.
column3900: In less than three weeks his voice was low and weak, his face became haggard and thin, his hair lay uncombed on his forehead, and his bones began to show their shape under the skin.
column3901: He was not even civil in those days, and no longer felt the importance of being consulted.
column3902: He requested the lodgers not to bother him, that he had other things on his mind, and far more trouble than he could contend with.
column3904: Bill was a nice fellow when he first came to the house, modest and unassuming; he was also interesting to hear when he became confident and assertive; but after he fell foul of the infinitive split, he became a man to be avoided, and his curt answers made many a man frown.
column3905: XXXI Fallacies Concerning Beggars There are quite a number of fallacies, concerning beggars, which are sadly in need of contradiction, so that these much-misunderstood men may stand in their innocence before the public.
column3906: They do not mark houses, as is commonly supposed; they do not spend the money of charity on drink; they do not possess hidden hoards; and they have as much dread of meeting women in lonely places as the latter have of meeting them.
column3907: In the first place, why should they mark houses?
column3908: If you enter a common lodging-house in the country, you will find, on making enquiry, that two out of three beggars have been there before, and know from past experience one or more good houses; but they would rather share their spoils with you than show these houses, or explain their where-abouts.
column3909: Beggars, however good-natured they may be in a lodging-house, are all selfish on this one point.
column3910: They always live in expectation of future benefits from those houses, and it is not likely that they will risk spoiling them by giving information to others who may not approach them in a proper manner, or may even be impudent.
column3911: If you ever see a house marked you may be sure that it is by one of a family, who are working different parts of the town, and who will change about on the following days.
column3912: Private people seem to know more of this matter than beggars, for, after visiting more than a hundred lodging-houses, and hearing the conversation of thousands of beggars, I have not heard one whisper of a marked house.
column3913: Another belief is that beggars possess secret hoards.
column3914: Because people in years of reading have seen two or three accounts of cases of this kind, they are under the impression that half the beggars that approach them are misers that would rather beg than buy.
column3915: Now good beggars will still work on the public feeling with three or four shillings' worth of coppers in their pockets, but you could search the first thousand you met and be very unlikely to find gold.
column3916: The most persistent beggars will often beg hard until they have saved a few shillings, after which they feel justified in taking a much-deserved rest, and are often to be seen idling for a couple of days in a town that is no good for begging, but where the accommodation of the lodging-house is excellent.
column3917: Another fallacy is that they are eager to molest women and children.
column3918: It is a mystery how these charges can be made against them, for few cases of the kind get into the papers.
column3919: The only way to account for this belief is that all undiscovered violence and petty crime is put down to be the work of tramps, and the papers are only too eager to take such a view.
column3920: When a man fell from his bicycle, trying to avoid running over an old deaf tramp, the local press thought it would make better copy to say that the man was knocked off his bicycle by a vicious tramp, much to the surprise of the man himself.
column3921: Again, a tramp does not like to meet a woman in a lonely place, and he often whistles loudly so as to encourage her not to faint, and he never forgets to give her plenty of room to pass, and nothing annoys him more than to see timid children run into their houses at his approach.
column3922: A tramp likes to have women answer the door to him, when they have the confidence of being surrounded by neighbours; but when it comes to the open air, women are a nuisance to him, and he would be glad if no women walked abroad.
column3923: He can approach his own sex and speak, but he is afraid of being within ten feet of a woman's nerves.
column3924: Then there is the fallacy that he is spending money on drink, because he is seen going in or out of a public-house.
column3925: People do not know that he enters as a beggar, not as a customer, and that he often gets tipsy because beer is often easier to beg than bread or pennies.
column3926: I have seen hundreds of beggars drunk who had not spent one penny on drink.
column3927: On a Saturday night, almost every man in a common lodging-house is drunk, and often against his wish.
column3928: All beggars know that they can do almost as well on a Saturday night by telling their tales in public-houses, as they can by calling at private houses all through the week; and in doing so they get drunk on free drinks, without having spent one of the many pennies they have received from customers.
column3929: Another fallacy is that beggars are the authors of so many deeds of barn-burning, theft, and assaults on women who could not recognize their assailants in the dark.
column3930: It is quite a common thing to hear tramps in a common lodging-house say, "Tramps, of course, will be blamed for this," when one of them reads aloud of an undiscovered crime.
column3931: Sometimes the real culprits are at last found, and though they are not strange tramps, but people of the locality, yet no one thinks of apologizing for the unjust suspicion on tramps.
column3932: They do not often burn hayricks for spite, as is commonly supposed.
column3933: They may accidentally burn one through smoking.
column3934: It should be understood that they are very careful not to do so, or they would have to walk until they were miles away, and would rob themselves of a comfortable night's rest.
column3935: No, farmers have jealous neighbours and discontented labourers, who are worse enemies than strange tramps.
column3936: Idle threats, due to irritation, are generally the extent of their crime.
column3937: Is it likely that a beggar who has been refused food at a house will hide somewhere and nurse vengeance for hours, so that he may break into it or set fire to it at night?
column3938: He is hungry, and he must travel on in search of food, and he will at last meet with success; and there is not a man in the world more innocent of acts of crime than he is then, when his empty body is satisfied.
column3939: He forgets all past unkindness, and the household that he has threatened to murder has passed out of his recollection for ever.
column3940: People should know that tramps talk aloud to themselves, owing to being so much alone.
column3941: Therefore, when a woman refuses a tramp on the score of a husband doing little work, and the said tramp goes away muttering, she must not at once come to the conclusion, as she always does, that he is cursing her; for it is more than likely that he is cursing some cause he imagines has placed her in such a helpless position.
column3942: There is one thing against a beggar that has been witnessed so often that it would be folly to dispute the truth of it, which is that he throws food away.
column3943: Although he cannot be altogether justified, yet an explanation of the real facts may go far to make people sympathize with his dilemmas.
column3944: People seldom take into consideration that he needs a bed, and they would often rather give him two-penny-worth of food than a halfpenny in money.
column3945: Now a beggar knows that if he asks at a house point-blank for money, nothing will he get; or, occasionally a woman will say, "I will give you something to eat."
column3946: For that reason he always asks for food, and then gets an odd penny here and there--which he would not get if he asked for money.
column3947: But it is often necessary to beg so much food in getting a few coppers for his lodging and a little tea and tobacco, that he soon gets encumbered with more food than he can hide or eat.
column3948: In this case he cannot continue begging--which he must, or go into the workhouse--so he throws the food away and continues to beg more of it, in the hope of getting money for his bed.
column3949: But very few beggars ever threw food away without feeling regret that they had to do so.
column3950: It is for this reason that so many beggars carry a few cheap trifles, such as pins, needles, laces, or some self-made novelty.
column3951: With these things they are sure of getting money for their lodging, and, while doing so, beg food from those that will not buy.
column3952: I hope by these explanations to have made a beggar worthy of kinder consideration, and proved his to be a character to be loved and respected.
column3953: Henceforth let no lady be afraid to walk a lonely road without a dog, for her presence is dreaded by a tramp, however beautiful she may be.
column3954: The tramp has not Tommy Atkins's eye for female beauty.
column3955: Let no total abstainer, who has given a beggar a penny, and sees him enter a public-house, think that the penny goes for beer, for a beggar is more likely to go in to beg instead of buy.
column3956: Think not because you have read of one case where a beggar was arrested and found to have considerable money sewn in his clothes, that every beggar you meet has saved money.
column3957: Think not because a beggar was seen in the morning to pass a barn that was burned to the ground that same night, that he was the guilty one.
column3958: A burning barn would not feed his body, and he would not remain there long enough to warm his feet and dry his socks.
column3959: And if you still believe that beggars mark houses, go to the window and watch every one that leaves, and you are likely to be a great many years before you catch one in the act of doing so.
column3960: Houses _are_ marked, but in nine cases out of ten children are the guilty ones.
column3961: XXXII Lady Tramps Almost all tramps who travel alone object to women in a common lodging-house.
column3962: Even the landlord of such a place soon learns from experience that women take out in accommodation the worth of their money, for they make the place too much of a home.
column3963: If they are bad wives they are continually squabbling with their husbands, or scolding their children; if they are good wives they are always cooking, or covering the limited number of seats and tables with sewing material, or surrounding the fire with newly washed clothes; and the poor bachelor, who is more indifferent to cleanliness, and often prefers a slice of bacon quickly done to the labour of cooking vegetable meals--this poor bachelor complains not only that he cannot get near the fire, but that there is not enough room on the tables to lay his food, which is not often the truth.
column3964: As for the landlords, they are becoming more bitter every day, and these unfortunate women now find it so difficult to get lodgings, that they dare not visit any town haphazard, but must make enquiries of their fellow travellers as to accommodation for women.
column3965: Often they hear, to their disappointment, of houses that formerly lodged women being changed into houses for men only.
column3966: And if these women have children, matters are still worse, for they are objected to on that account.
column3967: It is therefore not the least wonder that when a man, his wife, and two or more children, succeed in being lodged, they are loth to leave that town until they have tapped it thoroughly--north, south, east, and west, house and shop; and sometimes they remain so long in that one town--perhaps three months or more--that their faces become known, and they are not supposed to belong to a tribe of wanderers.
column3968: It is in the summer months, when the nights are warm, and they are independent of lodging-houses, that they prove themselves to be true travellers.
column3969: Perhaps it is because women are so much better beggars than men that they are disliked both by bachelor beggars and lodging-house keepers.
column3970: The former know well that if a woman once starts in a street, she will carry all before her--money, clothes, and food; and the landlords know that a woman is so successful that she is soon back again in the lodging-house; in fact she is often there twenty-three hours out of the twenty-four.
column3971: Whereas the man, however good a beggar he may be, is absent several hours in a day, for he not only takes much longer than a woman to earn a living, but he is fond of standing at street corners, and sometimes he visits a library.
column3972: The woman is instinctively inclined to make the place a home, but the man more often uses it simply as a place wherein to eat and sleep.
column3973: The woman, whether she has little ones or not, is always believed when she claims to have a family, and she receives wearing apparel for them, and food.
column3974: The former she sells cheaply to the poor but more respectable class of people that live in the locality of cheap lodging-houses.
column3975: But the man can never do business with children in the spirit; he needs them in the flesh at his side, or he is not believed to be a father.
column3976: After a woman has been on the road a little time and become familiar with lodging-houses and begging, she finds little difficulty in maintaining a husband that will neither work, beg, nor steal--especially if she has a child for the poor fellow to look after; to wheel in a box, when he must take great care to stop in front of the house where his wife is.
column3977: The most hard-hearted cannot withhold their charity, for the child's sake.
column3978: As soon as the man hears the front door open, he must become very interested in his offspring, and move in a circle round the box, trying to make the child more comfortable.
column3979: His solicitude is almost certain of reward, for the lady of the house cannot fail to see this, and her tender heart overflows in pity for the whole family.
column3980: "Whatever his faults are," thinks she, "he undoubtedly has a father's feeling for the poor child."
column3981: Of course the father is as fond of his child as any other father would be, and he would do anything in reason for it--anything, except work.
column3982: Another objection lodging-house keepers have to women lodgers is that when they begin a quarrel they are so long in bringing it to an end, especially if under the influence of drink.
column3983: Whereas in the case of men it is often a short violent tussle of two or three minutes--fifteen minutes would be unusual for two untrained men--and that is the end of it, for neither one has a wish to renew hostilities.
column3984: It is all over before a constable can be found, much less dragged unwillingly to the battle ground.
column3985: "Yes," I heard one lady lodger say to a landlord, who had threatened to eject her for speaking her mind--"Yes," said she, "and if I had Liverpool Nora and Brummagem Sal at my side, instead of this"--pointing to her husband--"we would soon see who's who in a very short time."
column3986: Some time after I had the pleasure of meeting Liverpool Nora, and my opinion is that if Brummagem Sal was as high-spirited and brawny as that lady, well, it would be folly to aggravate them singly, much less the twain.
column3987: There is one man who favours the presence of women, and that is the true working-man, who is travelling for work, and after paying his last few coppers for a bed, sits hungry in the lodging-house kitchen, for he is a poor beggar indeed.
column3988: As a rule the men are indifferent, but these women always guess his secret and pity him.
column3989: They watch, and if they see no sign of food cooked, or to be cooked, it is not long before he is asked to have a basin of broth or stew, and, if he accepts, the other women--being now correct in their surmises--supply him with bread.
column3990: In fact, after this initial movement, he is certain of a full stomach as long as he remains at that particular house.
column3991: Many a poor fellow would have gone supperless to bed, and begun another weary day's march without breakfast, were it not for some thoughtful and unselfish beggar woman in a lodging-house kitchen.
column3992: Now, as I have said, five women under the influence of drink are less likely to go quietly to bed than twenty or thirty men in the same condition, and that is the landlord's one just objection to female lodgers.
column3993: With regard to his other objections they are of little account; for, though these women are in the kitchen almost the whole day, continually using the cooking utensils and the fire, do they not wash the former and keep the latter's hearth clean?
column3994: If he had all male lodgers he would have to keep a man or woman to do these things, or either he or his wife be kept busy; for no lodger, whether it be man, woman, or child, can be expected to do these things themselves, after paying for accommodation.
column3995: The truth of the matter is that these landlords are like a good many others--they want both rent and possession; and it is the limited number of these places--especially for families--that makes these men so independent.
column3996: Sometimes, where the accommodation is outrageously bad, the woman lodger stores her resentment until it serves her purpose, and, the morning she is going away, she will often make an hour's delay to tell the landlord her opinion of his place, and he never likes to hear the truth; whereas men come and go, and are not so particular.
column3997: On one occasion I had the pleasure of hearing Irish Molly speak her mind to a landlord who begrudged coke for the kitchen fire, making it necessary for lodgers to bring in pieces of wood, picked up in the streets.
column3998: Molly, her husband, and two children, had been here for two weeks, and, having thoroughly begged the town and its surrounding districts, were to seek fresh quarters on the morrow.
column3999: But Molly swore the night before that she would not leave until she told the landlord what she thought of him.
column4000: At nine o'clock on the following morning, they were ready to leave, and in spite of the husband's hurry to be off, Molly would not budge until she saw the lodging-house keeper.
column4001: At last that gentleman entered the kitchen, and Molly at once rose to her feet, and set on him like a fury.
column4002: For a moment the man was astonished, and tried to pacify her, but failing to do so, he hurriedly left the kitchen, and took refuge in his private room.
column4003: Irish Molly at once followed and, standing outside, emphasized her words with her fists on the door.
column4004: For ten minutes she hammered and abused, and the men and women in the kitchen encouraged her with their laughter.
column4005: "I shall send for a constable," shouted the landlord from behind the door.
column4007: "I shall have you locked up," he shouted.
column4008: "Come out, and be knocked down," cried she.
column4009: Now it happened that Molly's husband and two children had stood waiting at the front door all this time.
column4010: More than once he had asked her impatiently if she was coming, and at last, receiving no answer, went away with the children.
